docs.title: Nutrition & Health Reference
docs.text: Welcome to a comprehensive, evidence-based reference covering the full spectrum of human nutrition — from vitamins and minerals to neurotransmitter biochemistry.

docs.text: Section Topics Vitamins All 13 vitamins — A, B1–B12, C, D, E, K — with RDAs, deficiency signs, drug interactions Minerals 16 minerals — from calcium and magnesium to copper, zinc, selenium, and manganese Amino Acids 16 amino acids — essential and conditionally essential — with metabolism and clinical notes Neurotransmitters Serotonin, dopamine, GABA, glutamate, ACh, histamine, melatonin, endorphins + cofactor master reference Antioxidants Glutathione, CoQ10, resveratrol, lycopene, lutein, zeaxanthin, polyphenols, flavonoids Fatty Acids Omega-3 (EPA, DHA, ALA), Omega-6, Omega-9 — structure, function, and clinical use Gut Health Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium, prebiotic fibers, and the gut-brain axis Phytonutrients Carotenoids, flavonoids, glucosinolates, and phytosterols Macronutrients Carbohydrates, proteins, dietary fats, and water Performance Creatine, beta-alanine, caffeine, L-carnitine, and workout nutrition Detox Pathways Phase 1–3 liver detox, methylation, glucuronidation, sulfation, and heavy metal detox Deep Dives COMT, MAO, Krebs cycle, and methylation pathway mechanics

docs.title: Deficiency Index — Symptom → Likely Deficiency
docs.text:
A quick-reference lookup table: start with a symptom or sign and find the likely nutrient deficiencies to investigate. Organised by body system.

Usage note: Deficiency symptoms are rarely pathognomonic — multiple deficiencies often coexist, and symptoms overlap with non-nutritional causes. Use this as a starting point, not a diagnostic tool.

docs.title: Neurological & Cognitive
docs.text: Symptom / Sign Likely Deficiency Key Notes Peripheral neuropathy (glove-and-stocking) B1 (Thiamine), B6, B12, E B12 most common; B6 excess also causes neuropathy Memory loss / dementia picture B1, B3, B12, B9 (Folate) B1 → Wernicke-Korsakoff; B12 → subacute combined degeneration Depression / low mood B9, B12, D, Omega-3 (EPA/DHA), Magnesium, Zinc, Tryptophan Folate/B12 → hyperhomocysteinaemia affecting methylation Anxiety / irritability B1, B3, B6, Magnesium, Zinc Magnesium deficiency is highly underdiagnosed Confusion / delirium B1 (Wernicke's), B3 (Pellagra), B12, Sodium (hyponatraemia) B1 deficiency most acute risk Poor concentration / brain fog B12, D, Iron, Omega-3, Iodine Iodine critical for thyroid-driven cognition Headaches Magnesium, B2 (Riboflavin), CoQ10 Magnesium + B2 used in migraine prophylaxis Seizures B6 (neonatal epilepsy), Calcium, Magnesium Pyridoxine-dependent epilepsy — rare but important Optic neuropathy B12, B1, Copper "Nutritional amblyopia" — bilateral visual loss

docs.title: Musculoskeletal
docs.text: Symptom / Sign Likely Deficiency Key Notes Muscle cramps / tetany Calcium, Magnesium, Potassium, B1 Check serum Ca²⁺, Mg²⁺, K⁺ Muscle weakness (proximal myopathy) D, Potassium, Magnesium, Selenium Vitamin D myopathy often misattributed to ageing Bone pain / tenderness D, Calcium, Phosphorus Osteomalacia — diffuse bone aching Rickets (children) D, Calcium, Phosphorus Bowing of weight-bearing bones Osteoporosis Calcium, D, K2, Magnesium, Protein Multifactorial — always multifactorial Joint pain D, Omega-3, Glucosinolates (anti-inflammatory) Poor wound healing C, Zinc, Vitamin A, Protein (Arginine/Glycine) C needed for hydroxylation of proline/lysine in collagen Growth stunting (children) Zinc, Protein (EAAs), Iodine, D Zinc most common single-nutrient cause globally

docs.title: Haematological
docs.text: Symptom / Sign Likely Deficiency Key Notes Macrocytic (megaloblastic) anaemia B12, B9 (Folate) Distinguish: B12 also has neurological signs Microcytic (hypochromic) anaemia Iron, B6, Copper Iron deficiency most common worldwide Normocytic anaemia Protein (EPO synthesis), Copper, B6 Pallor / fatigue / dyspnoea on exertion Iron, B12, B9, B6, Copper Easy bruising / petechiae C (Scurvy), K, Vitamin K2 Prolonged bleeding / clotting defect Vitamin K PT/INR elevated Haemolytic anaemia Vitamin E, Selenium, Copper E deficiency rare except in fat malabsorption

docs.title: Dermatological
docs.text: Symptom / Sign Likely Deficiency Key Notes Dermatitis (pellagrous, sun-exposed areas) B3 (Niacin) Casal's necklace rash; the "4 Ds" of pellagra Seborrhoeic dermatitis / greasy scaly rash B2, B6, Biotin (B7), Zinc Periorificially distributed Angular cheilitis / cracked mouth corners B2, B3, B6, Iron, Zinc Glossitis (swollen smooth tongue) B2, B3, B9, B12, Iron Atrophic glossitis — magenta/beefy red tongue Perifollicular haemorrhages / follicular hyperkeratosis Vitamin C (Scurvy) Corkscrew hairs also typical Dry/scaly skin (ichthyosis-like) A, EFAs (Omega-3/6), Biotin Acne / poor skin healing Zinc, A, D Hair loss (diffuse) Iron, Zinc, Biotin (B7), Protein, D Biotin deficiency rare unless consuming raw egg whites (avidin) Nail changes (koilonychia = spoon nails) Iron Nail changes (Beau's lines or leukonychia) Zinc, Protein

docs.title: Ocular
docs.text: Symptom / Sign Likely Deficiency Key Notes Night blindness Vitamin A Earliest sign of A deficiency Xerophthalmia / Bitot's spots Vitamin A Severe deficiency; leading cause of preventable blindness Corneal vascularisation B2 (Riboflavin) Dry eyes Omega-3 (DHA/EPA), A Macular degeneration risk Lutein, Zeaxanthin, Omega-3, Zinc Cataracts (oxidative) C, E, Lutein, Riboflavin

docs.title: Cardiovascular
docs.text: Symptom / Sign Likely Deficiency Key Notes Cardiomyopathy B1 (Wet Beri-beri), Selenium (Keshan disease), Carnitine Elevated homocysteine / CV risk B9, B12, B6 Methylation pathway impairment Hypertension Magnesium, Potassium, Calcium, D, Omega-3 Peripheral oedema B1 (wet beri-beri), Protein (hypoalbuminaemia) Arrhythmia Potassium, Magnesium, Calcium Hypomagnesaemia → digoxin toxicity risk

docs.title: Gastrointestinal
docs.text: Symptom / Sign Likely Deficiency Key Notes Diarrhoea B3, Zinc, Magnesium (excess), Probiotics imbalance "3 Ds" of pellagra include diarrhoea Constipation Magnesium (low intake), inadequate fibre, water Glossitis / stomatitis B2, B3, B12, Iron Anorexia / reduced appetite Zinc, B1, B3 Zinc deficiency impairs taste (hypogeusia) Dysphagia (in Plummer-Vinson) Iron Iron-deficiency associated oesophageal web Dysbiosis / altered gut flora Prebiotics (Inulin, FOS), Probiotics (Lactobacillus/Bifidobacterium)

docs.title: Endocrine & Metabolic
docs.text: Symptom / Sign Likely Deficiency Key Notes Goitre / hypothyroidism Iodine, Selenium Selenium needed to convert T4 → T3 Poor insulin sensitivity Chromium, Magnesium, D, Omega-3 Adrenal fatigue / poor stress response B5 (Pantothenic acid), C, Magnesium B5 → CoA synthesis for adrenal steroidogenesis Low testosterone Zinc, D, Magnesium Dysmenorrhoea (painful periods) Magnesium, Omega-3, D, Iron

docs.title: Immune
docs.text: Symptom / Sign Likely Deficiency Key Notes Frequent infections Zinc, Vitamins A, C, D, Selenium Zinc deficiency impairs T-cell function Poor vaccine response Zinc, D, Selenium Slow healing / recurrent ulcers Zinc, C, A, Protein (Arginine) Excessive inflammation Omega-3 (EPA/DHA), D, Polyphenols, Resveratrol

docs.title: Psychiatric & Behavioural
docs.text: Symptom / Sign Likely Deficiency Key Notes Psychosis (pellagra psychosis) B3 (Niacin) "Dementia" in pellagra is a psychiatric picture Neural tube defects (pregnancy) B9 (Folate) Supplementation must be pre-conception Pica (craving non-food items) Iron, Zinc Seasonal mood changes Vitamin D

docs.title: Reproductive
docs.text: Symptom / Sign Likely Deficiency Key Notes Infertility (male) Zinc, Selenium, Antioxidants (CoQ10, E, C) Oxidative damage to sperm Infertility (female) Iron, B9, D, Iodine Neural tube defects (offspring) B9 (Folate) 400 µg/day pre-conception + first trimester Poor foetal growth / SGA Zinc, Iron, B12, Omega-3

docs.title: Three Ds, Four Ds, Mnemonic Summary
docs.text:
Condition Classic Mnemonic Nutrient Scurvy Bleeding gums, perifollicular haemorrhage, poor wound healing Vitamin C Rickets/Osteomalacia Bone pain, deformity, weakness Vitamin D + Calcium Pellagra Dermatitis, Diarrhoea, Dementia (Death) B3 (Niacin) / Tryptophan Beri-beri Dry (neuro) / Wet (cardiac + oedema) B1 (Thiamine) Wernicke-Korsakoff Confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Ataxia → Korsakoff amnesia B1 (Thiamine) Ariboflavinosis Angular cheilitis, corneal vascularisation, seborrhoeic dermatitis B2 (Riboflavin) Hypocalcaemic tetany "Bones, Stones, Groans, Moans" (hypercalcaemia) / Chvostek & Trousseau (hypocalcaemia) Calcium Keshan disease Cardiomyopathy (endemic China) Selenium

docs.title: Food Sources Index — Food → Nutrients Provided
docs.text:
A reverse-lookup index: start with a food and find which nutrients it contributes significantly to. Organised by food category. Bioavailability notes are included where relevant.

Abbreviations: AA = amino acids · EAA = essential amino acids · MUFA = monounsaturated fatty acid · PUFA = polyunsaturated fatty acid · SFA = saturated fatty acid · DV = % Daily Value (US, per serving)

docs.title: Meat, Poultry & Eggs
docs.text: Food Key Nutrients Bioavailability Notes Beef (lean, cooked) B12, Zinc, Iron (haem), Selenium, B3, B6, Phosphorus, Creatine, all EAAs, Carnitine Haem iron absorbed at 15–35% vs 2–20% non-haem Chicken breast (cooked) B3, B6, Phosphorus, Selenium, all EAAs, Carnitine Complete protein; lower fat than red meat Chicken liver Vitamin A (retinol), B12, B2, B9 (Folate), Iron, Copper, Zinc, CoQ10, all EAAs Pre-formed retinol — very high; caution in pregnancy (teratogen above ~3,000 µg/day) Beef liver B12, Vitamin A, B2, B9, Iron, Copper, Zinc, B5, CoQ10, all EAAs Most nutrient-dense single food; Copper content among highest of any food Eggs (whole) B12, B2, B5, B7 (Biotin), D, K2 (MK-4), Selenium, Choline, Lutein, Zeaxanthin, all EAAs Raw avidin in egg white binds biotin — cook eggs to destroy avidin Egg yolk D, K2, A, B12, B2, B5, Choline, Lutein, Zeaxanthin, Phospholipids Choline: ~125 mg/yolk Turkey B3, B6, B12, Selenium, Tryptophan, Zinc, all EAAs High tryptophan → serotonin/melatonin precursor Lamb B12, Zinc, Iron (haem), Selenium, B3, Carnitine, all EAAs Similar profile to beef

docs.title: Seafood & Fish
docs.text: Food Key Nutrients Bioavailability Notes Salmon (wild, cooked) EPA, DHA (Omega-3), D, B12, B3, B6, Selenium, K1, Astaxanthin, all EAAs Wild > farmed for Omega-3 ratio Sardines (canned, with bones) EPA, DHA, D, B12, Calcium (bones), Selenium, CoQ10, all EAAs Bones significantly boost calcium content Mackerel EPA, DHA, D, B12, Selenium, Magnesium, CoQ10 One of highest Omega-3 sources Herring EPA, DHA, D, B12, Selenium, CoQ10 Traditional source in Northern Europe Tuna (canned in water) B3, B12, Selenium, D, all EAAs Albacore higher in mercury than skipjack; limit in pregnancy Cod B12, B3, Selenium, Iodine, Phosphorus, all EAAs Low fat; good lean protein source Oysters Zinc (highest of any food), B12, Copper, Selenium, Iron, D 6 oysters can provide ~33 mg zinc (300% DV) Mussels B12, Iron, Selenium, Manganese, Omega-3, Zinc Excellent complete protein Shrimp/Prawns Iodine, Selenium, B12, Astaxanthin, Phosphorus, all EAAs Good low-calorie protein Seaweed (nori, kelp) Iodine, K1, B12 (in nori, though poorly bioavailable — caution), Calcium, Magnesium, Fucoidan B12 in seaweed is largely inactive analogue

docs.title: Dairy
docs.text: Food Key Nutrients Bioavailability Notes Milk (whole cow's) Calcium, D (fortified), B12, B2, B5, Phosphorus, Potassium, Iodine, all EAAs Highly bioavailable calcium; Iodine content varies with cow feed Yogurt (plain, full-fat) Calcium, B12, B2, Probiotics (Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium), Iodine, complete protein Live cultures improve lactose digestion Cheese (hard, e.g. Parmesan) Calcium, B12, K2 (MK-4 in aged cheeses), Phosphorus, Selenium, Zinc, complete protein K2 highest in aged fermented cheeses Kefir Calcium, B12, B2, Probiotics (30+ strains), Phosphorus Broader probiotic diversity than yogurt Butter / Ghee Vitamins A, D, E, K2 (grass-fed), Butyrate (short-chain fatty acid) Grass-fed butter has ~5× more K2 than grain-fed Whey protein All EAAs (highest BCAA content), B12, Calcium, Selenium Fastest-digesting complete protein; high leucine triggers MPS

docs.title: Legumes & Pulses
docs.text: Food Key Nutrients Bioavailability Notes Lentils (cooked) B9 (Folate), Iron, Manganese, Molybdenum, B1, B6, Copper, Phosphorus, Fibre (prebiotic), Protein Non-haem iron — pair with Vitamin C to improve absorption Chickpeas (cooked) B9, Manganese, Copper, Iron, Phosphorus, B6, Zinc, Fibre, Protein Soaking / sprouting reduces phytates Black beans (cooked) B9, Manganese, Iron, Magnesium, Phosphorus, B1, Antioxidants, Fibre, Protein Fibre acts as prebiotic (FOS/inulin) Edamame (soybeans) All EAAs, Isoflavones (Phytoestrogens), B9, K1, Iron, Manganese, Copper Complete protein; isoflavones have mixed receptor effects Kidney beans (cooked) Iron, B9, Manganese, Phosphorus, Molybdenum, Fibre Raw kidney beans contain lectins (phytohaemagglutinin) — always cook thoroughly Peanuts B3, B7 (Biotin), Manganese, Magnesium, B1, Resveratrol, Protein, MUFA Technically a legume; also a tree-nut substitute

docs.title: Nuts & Seeds
docs.text: Food Key Nutrients Bioavailability Notes Almonds Vitamin E, Magnesium, Calcium, B2, Manganese, MUFA, Fibre Soaking reduces phytates; blanched retain more E Walnuts ALA (Omega-3), Manganese, Copper, Gamma-tocopherol (E), Folate, Polyphenols Highest nut ALA content; convert ~5–10% to EPA/DHA Flaxseeds (ground) ALA (Omega-3), Lignans (phytoestrogens), B9, Magnesium, Manganese, Fibre Grinding required for bioavailability; whole seeds pass undigested Chia seeds ALA, Calcium, Manganese, Phosphorus, Fibre (prebiotic), Iron Good vegan omega-3 source Sunflower seeds Vitamin E (highest of seeds), B1, B5, B6, Magnesium, Selenium, Copper, Linoleic acid (Omega-6) Pumpkin seeds (pepitas) Zinc, Magnesium, Iron, Phosphorus, Manganese, Copper, Tryptophan One of best plant zinc sources (~2.5 mg/28g) Brazil nuts Selenium (highest of any food — 1 nut = ~70–91 µg; UL = 400 µg/day), Magnesium, Copper Limit to 1–3 nuts/day; selenium toxicity (selenosis) possible Cashews Zinc, Copper, Magnesium, Iron, B1, MUFA Most iron-rich nut Hemp seeds All EAAs (complete protein), ALA, GLA (Omega-6), Magnesium, Zinc, Iron One of few plant complete proteins

docs.title: Vegetables
docs.text: Food Key Nutrients Bioavailability Notes Spinach (cooked) B9, Vitamin K1, A (β-carotene), Iron, Manganese, Calcium High oxalate reduces Ca and Iron bioavailability; cooking reduces oxalate somewhat Kale (raw/cooked) K1, C, A (β-carotene), Calcium, Manganese, Glucosinolates, Flavonoids, Lutein, Zeaxanthin Low-oxalate green → better calcium absorption than spinach Broccoli C, K1, B9, Sulforaphane (from Glucoraphanin), Indole-3-carbinol, Calcium, Chromium Sulforaphane peaks when raw or lightly steamed; myrosinase destroyed by overcooking Sweet potato (baked) β-Carotene (Vitamin A), Manganese, Potassium, B6, B5, C, Fibre Fat improves β-carotene bioavailability (provitamin A → retinol conversion) Carrot β-Carotene, Biotin (B7), K1, B6, Potassium Cooking + fat increases β-carotene absorption Tomato (cooked) Lycopene (highest in cooked/processed), Vitamin C, K1, Potassium, Chromium Lycopene bioavailability greatly enhanced by cooking and oil Garlic Allicin, Selenium, B6, Allium polyphenols, FOS (prebiotic) Crush/chop 10 minutes before eating to maximise allicin Onion Quercetin, FOS/Inulin (prebiotic), B6, B9, Chromium, Flavonoids Cooking reduces quercetin; raw preferred for flavonoid content Red/yellow bell pepper Vitamin C (highest of any vegetable — ~150 mg/100g), B6, A (β-carotene), Flavonoids Better C source than oranges by weight Asparagus B9, K1, Inulin (prebiotic), B1, B2, Chromium Avocado K1, B5, B9, B6, Potassium, C, MUFA (Oleic acid), Lutein, Zeaxanthin, Fibre Healthy fat enhances absorption of fat-soluble nutrients in the meal Mushrooms (UV-exposed) Vitamin D2 (ergocalciferol), B2, B3, B5, Selenium, Copper, Ergothioneine Exposing gills to midday sun for 30 min generates 100s of IU D2 Brussels sprouts K1, C, B9, Glucosinolates, Sulforaphane Beetroot Nitrates, B9, Manganese, Potassium, Betaine, Iron, Fibre Nitrates → nitric oxide → vasodilation (athletic performance) Sea vegetables (kelp/nori) Iodine, Fucoxanthin, Fucoidan, Magnesium, Calcium Iodine highly variable; kelp can cause excess iodine

docs.title: Fruits
docs.text: Food Key Nutrients Bioavailability Notes Orange Vitamin C, B9, Potassium, Flavanones (Hesperidin, Naringenin), Fibre C enhances iron absorption from co-consumed foods Berries (blueberries, strawberries, raspberries) Vitamin C, Anthocyanins, Quercetin, Pterostilbene, Resveratrol (in grapes/berries), Manganese, Fibre Among highest ORAC (antioxidant capacity) foods Kiwi Vitamin C (92 mg/100g), K1, Actinidin (digestive enzyme), Folate, Potassium Banana Potassium, B6, B5, C, Manganese, resistant starch (prebiotic function) Underripe banana has more resistant starch Mango β-Carotene, C, B9, B6, Mannoheptulose, Polyphenols Pomegranate Punicalagins → Urolithin A (gut-derived), C, B9, K1, Potassium, Polyphenols Grapefruit C, Naringenin, Lycopene (pink/red grapefruit), B9, Potassium Inhibits CYP3A4 → dangerous interactions with many drugs (statins, CCBs, immunosuppressants) Papaya C, β-Carotene, B9, Papain (digestive enzyme), Lycopene, K1 Cherries (tart) Anthocyanins, Melatonin, Quercetin, Potassium, C Used in exercise recovery (anti-inflammatory) Grapes (red/purple) Resveratrol (skin), Quercetin, Anthocyanins, K1, B1 Resveratrol concentrated in skin; red wine is more bioavailable source (with risk)

docs.title: Grains & Cereals
docs.text: Food Key Nutrients Bioavailability Notes Oats (whole) B1, B5, Manganese, Phosphorus, Magnesium, Iron, Beta-glucan (prebiotic fibre), Zinc Beta-glucan lowers LDL-C; slows glucose absorption Brown rice Manganese, Selenium, Magnesium, B1, B3, B6, Fibre Milling removes bran → white rice loses most B vitamins Quinoa All EAAs (complete protein), Manganese, Magnesium, Iron, B9, Phosphorus, Fibre One of few plant complete proteins; gluten-free Wheat germ Vitamin E, B1, B9, B6, Manganese, Zinc, Selenium Concentrated nutritional fraction of wheat Fortified cereals B1, B2, B3, B9, B12 (rarely), Iron, D (some fortified) Check labels — significant variation; often manufactured folic acid (not natural folate) Buckwheat Rutin (Flavonoid), B9, Magnesium, Manganese, all EAAs Gluten-free; high in Rutin → capillary strengthening

docs.title: Oils & Fats
docs.text: Food Key Nutrients Bioavailability Notes Extra-virgin olive oil MUFA (Oleic acid, Omega-9), Polyphenols (Oleocanthal, Hydroxytyrosol), Vitamin E, K1, Squalene Cold-pressed retains most polyphenols; high heat degrades them Coconut oil Lauric acid (C12 SFA), MCTs (medium-chain triglycerides) MCTs enter portal circulation directly; does not require lipoprotein transport Flaxseed oil ALA (Omega-3) ~57%, Lignans Highly perishable; store in fridge, away from light Fish oil (supplement) EPA, DHA (Omega-3) Ethyl ester vs triglyceride form — TG form ~70% better absorbed Palm oil (red) β-Carotene, Tocotrienols (Vitamin E), Vitamin K1 Red palm oil (unrefined) vs white (refined) — very different nutrient profiles

docs.title: Fermented & Probiotic Foods
docs.text: Food Key Nutrients Bioavailability Notes Yogurt (live cultures) Probiotics (L. bulgaricus, S. thermophilus, L. acidophilus), Calcium, B12, B2 Check label for live culture CFU count Kefir Probiotics (30+ strains includig L. kefiri, L. reuteri), Calcium, Tryptophan, B12 Transient colonisation; daily intake needed for effect Kimchi Probiotics (Lactobacillus kimchii), Vitamin C, K1, Glucosinolates (from Baechu cabbage), Capsaicin, Fibre Fermentation enhances folate content Sauerkraut Probiotics (Lactobacillus plantarum), Vitamin C, K1, Glucosinolates, Isothiocyanates Unpasteurised only — pasteurisation kills probiotics Miso Probiotics, B12 (small amount), Zinc, Copper, Manganese, Isoflavones (from soy) Fermentation reduces anti-nutrient phytates Tempeh Probiotics, All EAAs (complete protein), Iron, Calcium, Manganese, Isoflavones, B12 (some) Fermentation increases bioavailability of iron and zinc vs unfermented soy Natto K2 (MK-7 — highest dietary source, ~800–1000 µg/100g), Probiotics (B. subtilis natto), All EAAs, Iron, Calcium MK-7 half-life ~70 hours; 1 serving can maintain K2 for several days Kombucha Probiotics, B vitamins, Organic acids (acetic, glucuronic) Alcohol content 0.5–3%; caution in pregnancy/alcohol sensitivity Apple cider vinegar (raw) Probiotics (mother), Acetic acid Evidence for health benefits largely anecdotal

docs.title: Herbs, Spices & Specialty Items

docs.title: Nutrient Interactions — Synergies & Antagonisms
docs.text:
A reference for how nutrients enhance or inhibit each other's absorption, metabolism, and function. Knowing these relationships is essential for optimising supplementation timing and food combinations.

Key: ✅ Synergy (beneficial co-administration) · ⛔ Antagonism (harmful, avoid co-administration) · ⚠️ Context-dependent

docs.title: Vitamins
docs.text: Interaction Type Mechanism Practical Guidance Vitamin C + Iron (non-haem) ✅ Synergy C reduces Fe³⁺ → Fe²⁺ (the absorbable form); also forms soluble chelate in intestine Take vitamin C with iron-rich plant meals; e.g., orange juice with lentils Vitamin D + Calcium ✅ Synergy 1,25(OH)₂D₃ upregulates TRPV6 channel and calbindin-D → active Ca²⁺ absorption in duodenum Supplement calcium and D together; D deficiency makes Ca supplementation largely ineffective Vitamin D + Magnesium ✅ Synergy Magnesium is required for all vitamin D hydroxylation steps (25-hydroxylase and 1α-hydroxylase) Concurrent Mg supplementation required for D activation; Mg deficiency makes high-dose D ineffective Vitamin D + K2 ✅ Synergy D increases calcium absorption; K2 (MK-7) activates osteocalcin to incorporate Ca into bone matrix and activates Matrix Gla Protein (MGP) to prevent arterial calcification Co-administer D3 + K2 to direct calcium appropriately Fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) + Dietary Fat ✅ Synergy Fat-soluble vitamins require bile salt-facilitated micelle formation for absorption Always consume fat-soluble vitamins with a fat-containing meal Vitamin A + Zinc ✅ Synergy Zinc required for synthesis of retinol-binding protein (RBP) — the transport protein for Vitamin A Zinc deficiency can cause functional vitamin A deficiency even with adequate A intake Vitamin E + Vitamin C ✅ Synergy Vitamin C regenerates oxidised (radical) Vitamin E (tocopheroxyl radical → tocopherol) Protective synergy — both are antioxidants operating at different compartments Beta-carotene + Fat ✅ Synergy Carotenoid absorption requires lipid-rich micelles Add fat to carotene-rich meals (e.g., olive oil to cooked carrots) Vitamin K1 vs K2 ⚠️ Context K1 (phylloquinone) primarily reaches liver for clotting factors; K2 (menaquinone) reaches peripheral tissues (bone, artery). They are not equivalent. For bone/cardiovascular benefit, specifically target K2 (MK-7 from natto/supplements) Vitamin B12 + Folate (B9) ✅ Synergy B12 is required to regenerate methyltetrahydrofolate (active folate) from the methylfolate trap; both required for homocysteine remethylation Supplementing folate without B12 can mask B12 deficiency while neurological damage progresses

docs.title: Minerals
docs.text: Interaction Type Mechanism Practical Guidance Calcium vs Iron ⛔ Antagonism Ca²⁺ competitively inhibits both haem and non-haem iron absorption at shared transporter (DMT1) Do not take calcium supplements with iron-rich meals or iron supplements Calcium vs Zinc ⛔ Antagonism High calcium intake decreases zinc absorption; both compete at intestinal level High-dose Ca supplements can worsen zinc status Calcium vs Magnesium ⛔ Antagonism (high doses) At very high doses, Ca and Mg compete for shared transporters. At normal dietary intakes, they are somewhat interdependent. Ratio Ca:Mg ~2:1 generally recommended; avoid very high Ca without matching Mg Zinc vs Copper ⛔ Antagonism High zinc induces metallothionein in intestinal cells, which preferentially sequesters copper → copper deficiency Long-term zinc supplementation (>40 mg/day) should include 1–2 mg copper; therapeutic use of high zinc (Wilson's disease) intentionally uses this mechanism Iron vs Zinc ⛔ Antagonism Competitive absorption at DMT1 Separate iron and zinc supplements by 2+ hours Iron vs Calcium ⛔ Antagonism (see above) — — Iron vs Manganese ⛔ Antagonism Both share DMT1 transporter Iron deficiency increases manganese absorption; excess manganese in iron-deficient children is a toxicity concern Magnesium + Potassium ✅ Synergy Magnesium is required for Na/K-ATPase activity; Mg deficiency impairs the ability to restore intracellular potassium → refractory hypokalaemia In hospitalised patients, hypokalaemia not responding to K supplementation should prompt checking Mg status Selenium + Iodine ✅ Synergy Selenium (as selenocysteine) is the active site of iodothyronine deiodinase, which converts T4 → T3. Selenium also protects thyroid from H₂O₂ damage during thyroid hormone synthesis Correct selenium deficiency alongside iodine deficiency; selenium alone without iodine can worsen autoimmune thyroiditis Iron + Hepcidin (inflammation) ⚠️ Context Inflammation raises hepcidin → blocks ferroportin → traps iron in reticuloendothelial cells → anaemia of chronic disease. Oral iron is ineffective in active inflammation. IV iron bypasses hepcidin block; oral iron ineffective when CRP is high Oxalate vs Calcium, Iron, Magnesium ⛔ Antagonism Oxalate forms insoluble complexes with Ca²⁺, Fe²⁺, Mg²⁺ → greatly reduces absorption High-oxalate foods (spinach, beet greens, rhubarb) are poor sources of calcium and iron; pair with low-oxalate sources Phytate vs Iron, Zinc, Calcium, Mg ⛔ Antagonism Phytic acid (inositol hexaphosphate) chelates divalent cations → reduced absorption from legumes, grains Soaking, sprouting, fermenting, and cooking degrades phytate and significantly improves mineral bioavailability Tannins (tea/coffee) vs Iron ⛔ Antagonism Polyphenolic tannins form insoluble complexes with non-haem iron Do not drink tea or coffee within 1 hour of an iron-rich meal or iron supplement

docs.title: Metabolic Partnerships (Functional Synergies)
docs.text:
These interactions occur at the level of metabolism rather than absorption.

Nutrients Relationship Mechanism B1 + B2 + B3 + B5 + Mg ✅ Team All required for the TCA cycle / energy metabolism (pyruvate decarboxylase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, etc.) B6 + B9 + B12 ✅ Team One-carbon (methyl) metabolism / methylation cycle; homocysteine remethylation requires all three B12 + Intrinsic Factor (IF) ✅ Dependency Without gastric parietal cell-derived IF, oral B12 requires massive doses for passive absorption (~1% of dose) Tryptophan + B6 + B3 ✅ Dependency B6 (as PLP) is required for conversion of tryptophan → niacin (kynurenine pathway, 60 mg Trp → ~1 mg niacin) Vitamin C + Iron (metabolic) ✅ Synergy C is required as a cofactor for prolyl/lysyl hydroxylases (collagen cross-linking) — independently of absorption enhancement Selenium + Glutathione + Vitamin E ✅ Team Selenium is the active site of Glutathione Peroxidase (GPx); E is the membrane-phase antioxidant; glutathione is the primary intracellular antioxidant Creatine + Carbohydrate (post-exercise) ✅ Synergy Insulin stimulates muscle creatine transporter (SLC6A8) — carbohydrate co-ingestion enhances creatine uptake into muscle Beta-alanine → Carnosine (with Histidine) ✅ Dependency Carnosine = Beta-alanine + Histidine; beta-alanine is rate-limiting in muscle; histidine availability also matters L-Carnitine (Lysine + Methionine + C + B6 + Fe + Niacin) ✅ Team Carnitine biosynthesis requires Lysine, Methionine, Ascorbate (C), B6, Fe²⁺, and niacin as cofactors CoQ10 + Selenium + Vitamin E ✅ Team CoQ10 is regenerated from ubiquinol (reduced) to ubiquinone by Vitamin E and GPx (selenium) Omega-3 (EPA/DHA) + Vitamin E ✅ Synergy PUFAs are highly susceptible to lipid peroxidation; Vitamin E protects cell membranes from oxidative damage Glucosinolates + Myrosinase ✅ Dependency Glucosinolates (in cruciferous vegetables) are only converted to bioactive isothiocyanates (e.g., sulforaphane) by the enzyme myrosinase, which is destroyed by heat Curcumin + Piperine ✅ Synergy Piperine inhibits CYP1A2/CYP3A4 and glucuronidation (Phase II metabolism) → bioavailability of curcumin increases ~20-fold Probiotics + Prebiotics (= Synbiotics) ✅ Synergy Prebiotics (FOS, inulin, pectin) provide fermentable substrate for probiotic bacteria, enhancing their colonisation and effect

docs.title: Drug–Nutrient Interactions
docs.text: These interactions are clinically significant. Cross-reference with individual mineral/vitamin notes.

docs.title: Nutrient Levels Reduced by Drugs
docs.text: Drug Nutrient Depleted Mechanism Metformin B12 (significant), B9 Impairs ileal B12-IF complex absorption; reduces methylation Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) B12, Magnesium, Iron, Zinc, Calcium Reduced gastric acid → impaired absorption of acid-dependent nutrients H2 Blockers (ranitidine, famotidine) B12 Reduced acid production reduces IF-mediated B12 absorption Oral Contraceptive Pill (OCP) B6, B9, B12, Riboflavin (B2), C, Zinc, Magnesium Estrogen affects B-vitamin metabolism Corticosteroids (long-term) Calcium, Vitamin D, Zinc, B6, K Induce renal Ca wasting; impair intestinal Ca absorption Cholestyramine / Colestipol (bile acid sequestrants) Vitamins A, D, E, K, Beta-carotene, B12 Bind bile acids → impair fat-soluble vitamin absorption Loop diuretics (furosemide) Potassium, Magnesium, Calcium, Thiamine (B1), Zinc Increase urinary excretion of divalent cations Thiazide diuretics Potassium, Magnesium, Zinc Increase K⁺ and Mg²⁺ excretion; decrease Ca excretion → hypercalcaemia risk Antiepileptics (phenytoin, phenobarbital, carbamazepine) Vitamin D, B9, B6, B12, K Induce CYP enzymes → accelerated catabolism of D and B vitamins Isoniazid (INH — TB drug) B6 (Pyridoxine) INH is a B6 antagonist — classic cause of drug-induced B6 deficiency neuropathy Statins (HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors) CoQ10 Block mevalonate pathway → CoQ10 synthesis (same pathway as cholesterol) Methotrexate B9 (Folate) Folic acid antagonist — inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) Trimethoprim (antibiotic) B9 (Folate) Also DHFR inhibitor; folate supplementation may be needed

docs.title: Nutrients That Affect Drug Efficacy
docs.text: Nutrient / Food Drug Affected Effect Vitamin K (high K1 foods) Warfarin / Acenocoumarol K1 reverses anticoagulant effect — maintain consistent K1 intake; do not rapidly change dietary K1 Calcium Fluoroquinolones, Tetracyclines, Levothyroxine, Bisphosphonates Forms insoluble chelate/complex → significantly reduced drug absorption Magnesium, Iron, Zinc Fluoroquinolones, Tetracyclines Same chelation mechanism as calcium Grapefruit / Grapefruit juice Statins (atorvastatin, simvastatin), Calcium channel blockers, Cyclosporine, some antiretrovirals Puranocoumarins in grapefruit irreversibly inhibit intestinal CYP3A4 → massive increase in drug bioavailability → toxicity St John's Wort (Hypericum) Warfarin, OCP, HIV antiretrovirals, Cyclosporine, Digoxin Potent CYP3A4 inducer → accelerated drug metabolism → treatment failure High-fat meal Fat-soluble drugs (e.g., Griseofulvin, Spironolactone, Isotretinoin) Increases bioavailability → take with food as directed High-protein diet Levodopa (Parkinson's) Large neutral amino acids compete with levodopa for intestinal and CNS transport → take 30 min before meals Caffeine Adenosine receptor drugs (e.g., Dipyridamole, Regadenoson, Adenosine) Caffeine is an adenosine receptor antagonist; invalidates pharmacological cardiac stress tests Tyramine-rich foods (aged cheese, cured meat, fermented) MAO Inhibitors (MAOIs — e.g., Phenelzine) MAOIs block tyramine breakdown → hypertensive crisis; strict dietary tyramine restriction essential

docs.title: Supplementation Timing Guide
docs.text: Supplement Best Time Reason Fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) With largest meal (containing fat) Require bile/micelles for absorption Calcium carbonate With meals Requires gastric acid for dissolution Calcium citrate Anytime (with or without food) Does not require stomach acid Iron On empty stomach (or with Vitamin C) Avoid taking with tea, coffee, calcium, dairy Magnesium (glycinate/malate) Evening Promotes relaxation; better sleep quality Zinc Away from meals (if nausea-tolerant); else with small amount of food Food reduces absorption but helps tolerance B vitamins complex Morning with food B vitamins are energising; evening use may affect sleep Vitamin B12 Morning May increase alertness / energy Probiotics (capsule form) With or just before a meal (not on empty stomach) Food buffers stomach acid, increasing probiotic survival Omega-3 fatty acids With meals containing fat Reduces fishy reflux; fat enhances absorption Creatine monohydrate Post-workout with carbohydrates Insulin enhances muscle creatine uptake Beta-alanine Pre-workout or split across day Minimise paraesthesia by using smaller more frequent doses Caffeine 30–60 min pre-exercise Ergogenic window; avoid within 6–8 h of sleep CoQ10 With fat-containing meal Fat-soluble; co-ingestion with fat improves absorption Vitamin C Split through the day (2–3 doses) Saturable transport — 200 mg × 3 absorbed better than 1000 mg × 1 Curcumin With fat + black pepper Dramatically improves bioavailability Resveratrol Separate from Metformin by 2+ h Both activate SIRT1/AMPK — possible additive hypoglycaemia risk

docs.title: Competitive Absorption Summary (Quick Reference)
docs.text:
At the intestinal transporter level, these nutrients compete:

DMT1 (divalent metal transporter):  Fe²⁺ ←→ Zn²⁺ ←→ Cu²⁺ ←→ Mn²⁺ ←→ Cd²⁺
                                     (all inhibit each other at high doses)

Shared Ca²⁺ channel / passive diffusion:  Ca²⁺ ←→ Mg²⁺ ←→ Zn²⁺

Folate transporter (PCFT/RFC):  Folate antagonists (methotrexate, trimethoprim) block folate entry

Rule of thumb: Divalent cations (Fe²⁺, Zn²⁺, Cu²⁺, Mg²⁺, Ca²⁺, Mn²⁺) all compete at shared transporters. Do not mega-dose one without considering impact on others.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Arginine is a conditionally essential amino acid — it is synthesised endogenously from citrulline (via the urea cycle) in adults, but synthesis is insufficient during periods of rapid growth, critical illness, injury, or metabolic stress. Arginine is the direct precursor of nitric oxide (NO) — the principal mediator of vascular tone, immune killing, and cell signalling. It is also a central component of the urea cycle and a precursor of creatine, polyamines, and proline.

  • Classification: Conditionally essential
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Arg / R
  • Side chain: Guanidinium group; strongly basic (pKa ~12.5); always positively charged at physiological pH
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Glucogenic (→ α-ketoglutarate via ornithine → glutamate pathway)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements
docs.text:
Age / Group Estimated need Infants 161 mg/kg/day (essential at this age) Adults (endogenous synthesis adequate) ~5–6 g/day from mixed diet typical Critical illness / wound healing Greatly increased; supplemental doses 15–30 g/day studied

No established RDA or UL from food for adults under normal conditions. Preterm infants cannot synthesise sufficient arginine — considered essential in this group.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Nitric Oxide (NO) Synthesis: Arg + O₂ → NO + Citrulline (by nitric oxide synthase; NOS1/nNOS, NOS2/iNOS, NOS3/eNOS; requires BH4, NADPH, FAD, FMN, calmodulin)
  • eNOS (endothelial): vasodilation, inhibits platelet aggregation, anti-atherosclerotic
  • nNOS (neuronal): neurotransmission, learning and memory
  • iNOS (inducible, macrophages): high-output NO for microbial killing (bactericidal, tumoricidal)
  • Urea Cycle: Arginine → ornithine + urea (arginase) — the final, essential step in ammonia detoxification; ornithine then regenerates citrulline to sustain the cycle
  • Creatine Synthesis: Arginine + Glycine → Guanidinoacetate (in kidney) → Creatine (SAM methylation in liver); creatine phosphate is the primary rapid-energy buffer in muscle
  • Polyamine Synthesis: Ornithine → Putrescine → Spermidine → Spermine (polyamines; essential for cell proliferation, DNA stability, and apoptosis regulation)
  • Proline Synthesis: Ornithine → proline (for collagen synthesis)
  • Growth Hormone Secretion: Arginine stimulates pituitary GH release (by inhibiting somatostatin); used as a GH stimulation test
  • Immune Function: iNOS-derived NO is a critical antimicrobial and antitumour effector; arginine availability governs macrophage killing capacity

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Endogenous synthesis Citrulline (from intestinal enterocytes; glutamine/proline origin) → Arginine (kidney, via ASS + ASL enzymes) Urea cycle Carbamoyl phosphate + Ornithine → Citrulline → Argininosuccinate → Arginine → Ornithine + Urea NO production Arg → NO + Citrulline (NOS isoforms) Creatine Arg + Gly → guanidinoacetate (AGAT) → creatine (GAMT + SAM) Key enzymes Arginase (Arg → Orn + Urea); NOS isoforms; AGAT; argininosuccinate synthase (ASS); lyase (ASL)

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text: Food Serving Arginine (mg) Pumpkin seeds 28g ~1,400 mg Turkey (roasted) 85g ~1,650 mg Pork loin (cooked) 85g ~1,550 mg Chicken breast 85g ~1,500 mg Peanuts 28g ~950 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~1,240 mg Soybeans (cooked) 170g ~1,900 mg Walnuts 28g ~700 mg

docs.title: Urea Cycle Disorders
docs.text:
• Defects in urea cycle enzymes (OTC, CPS1, ASS — citrullinaemia, ASL — argininosuccinic aciduria, ARG — hyperargininaemia)
  • Results in hyperammonaemia — encephalopathy, liver disease, developmental delay
  • Arginine is supplemented in most urea cycle disorders (except ARG deficiency) to maintain urea cycle flux
  • Treatment: low-protein diet, nitrogen scavengers (sodium benzoate, sodium phenylacetate), arginine supplementation, liver transplant

docs.title: Citrullinaemia Type I (ASS Deficiency)
docs.text:
• Inability to convert citrulline → argininosuccinate → arginine; accumulates citrulline and ammonia
  • Treated with arginine supplementation (bypasses the defect by providing arginine directly)

docs.title: Sepsis and Critical Illness
docs.text:
• NO-mediated vasodilation is pathological in septic shock (iNOS-generated NO causes uncontrolled vasodilation)
  • Arginine supplementation in critically ill patients is controversial — may be harmful in septic shock (worsens vasodilation) but beneficial post-surgery (immune nutrition formulations)

docs.title: Cardiovascular Disease
docs.text:
• Arginine → eNOS → NO → vasodilation → reduced blood pressure, reduced platelet aggregation, reduced LDL oxidation
  • Arginine supplementation trials show modest BP reduction; conflicting CVD mortality data
  • L-Arginine supplementation post-MI showed increased mortality in one trial (VINTAGE MI) — caution in acute MI

docs.title: Lysine-Arginine Competition (Herpes Simplex)
docs.text: • HSV requires arginine for replication; high lysine intake competes with arginine at shared transporters → reduced intracellular arginine → inhibits viral replication (see Lysine note)

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect BH4 (Tetrahydrobiopterin) Essential NOS cofactor; BH4 deficiency → uncoupled NOS → superoxide instead of NO (oxidative stress) Lysine Competitive intestinal uptake (shared cationic transporter); high lysine lowers arginine availability Asymmetric dimethylarginine (ADMA) Endogenous NOS inhibitor; elevated in CKD, hypertension, diabetes — blocks NO from arginine Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (sildenafil) Work downstream of NO (prevent cGMP breakdown); arginine → NO → cGMP → vasodilation — synergistic effect; risk of hypotension if combined with arginine supplements Creatine Arginine spares creatine synthesis need — high dietary creatine reduces arginine use for AGAT reaction

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• L-Arginine (2–6 g/day): Used for erectile dysfunction (limited evidence), hypertension (modest effect), exercise performance (via NO-mediated muscle blood flow)
  • Arginine + Citrulline: Citrulline often preferred — better oral bioavailability, fewer GI side effects, and effectively raises plasma arginine more than arginine itself (bypasses first-pass intestinal arginase)
  • Immune nutrition (perioperative immunonutrition): Enteral formulas enriched with arginine, glutamine, omega-3 FAs — evidence supports better surgical outcomes in elective major surgery; controversial in sepsis
  • Growth Hormone testing: IV arginine infusion (0.5 g/kg over 30 min) — standard GH stimulation test
  • Avoid in: Septic shock (worsens vasodilation), herpes simplex outbreaks (arginine promotes HSV replication)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Cysteine is a conditionally essential amino acid — it can be synthesised from methionine via the transsulphuration pathway (with adequate B6, folate, B12), but becomes essential when methionine intake is insufficient or in premature infants, individuals with liver disease, and critically ill patients. Cysteine is the rate-limiting precursor of glutathione (GSH) — the body's primary antioxidant tripeptide — and is a key component of proteins requiring structural disulphide bonds. Its thiol (–SH) group is highly reactive and participates in redox chemistry, metal binding, and enzyme catalysis.

  • Classification: Conditionally essential
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Cys / C
  • Side chain: Thiol (–CH₂–SH); pKa ~8.3; the most nucleophilic and oxidation-sensitive side chain
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Glucogenic (→ pyruvate)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements
docs.text:
Age / Group Notes Adults Can be synthesised from methionine; RDA expressed as combined Met + Cys (~19 mg/kg/day) Preterm infants Essential — limited transsulphuration capacity → must be provided in formula Liver disease / critically ill Hepatic transsulphuration impaired → dietary cysteine becomes essential

No established UL for food cysteine. Cysteine is unstable in solution (oxidises to cystine); parenteral nutrition formulas use N-acetylcysteine (NAC) to deliver cysteine.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Glutathione (GSH) Synthesis: Cys is the rate-limiting precursor of GSH (γ-glutamyl-cysteinyl-glycine). GSH is the cell's major antioxidant, detoxification agent (Phase II conjugation), and redox buffer. GSH levels critically depend on cysteine availability.
  • Disulfide Bond Formation: Cys residues in proteins form S–S bonds (oxidation; creating cystine) — essential for extracellular protein structure (immunoglobulins, albumin, elastin, insulin, keratin, receptor ligand-binding domains)
  • Taurine Synthesis: Cys → cysteine sulphinic acid → hypotaurine → taurine (requires B6) — taurine is a conditionally essential compound critical in bile acid conjugation, cardiac function, vision (retinal), and neurological development (especially in infants)
  • Coenzyme A (CoA) Synthesis: Pantothenic acid (B5) + cysteine → CoA — Cys sidechain provides the crucial thiol of CoA's active site
  • Enzyme Catalysis: Cys is the active-site nucleophile in cysteine proteases (papain, calpain, caspases, cathepsins) and in many other thiol-catalysed enzymes
  • Metal Binding/Sensing: Cys thiol groups coordinate Fe, Zn, Cu in metalloenzymes and metal-responsive transcription factors (e.g., MTF-1 responds to zinc via cys-containing zinc fingers)
  • Redox Signalling: Reversible oxidation of protein cys thiols (to sulfenic acid, disulphide, glutathionylation) — key mechanism in redox-regulated signalling and oxidative stress sensing
  • Ferroptosis Regulation: Cysteine (via system Xc⁻ glutamate/cystine antiporter) feeds GSH synthesis, which via GPx4 prevents lipid peroxidation — blockage of system Xc⁻ induces ferroptosis (cell death by lipid peroxidation)
  • Keratin and Hair/Nail Structure: ~10–14% of keratin is cysteine — intermolecular disulphide bonds give hair strength and curling (chemical perms break these bonds)

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Synthesis Homocysteine + Serine → Cystathionine (CBS; B6) → Cysteine + α-ketobutyrate (CTH; B6) GSH synthesis Glu + Cys → γ-Glu-Cys (GCL; rate-limiting; inhibited by BSO) + Gly → GSH (GSS) Taurine Cys → cysteine sulphinic acid → taurine (CSADase; B6 cofactor) Catabolism Cys → pyruvate (glucogenic); also cys → H₂S (gasotransmitter) via CBS, CSE, MST enzymes H₂S production Cysteine → hydrogen sulphide (H₂S) — a gaseous signalling molecule; vasodilator, neuroprotectant

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Cysteine (mg) Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~350 mg Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~330 mg Egg 1 large ~150 mg Sunflower seeds 28g ~230 mg Oats (dry) 40g ~155 mg Ricotta cheese 120g ~180 mg Brazil nuts 28g ~140 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~230 mg

N-Acetylcysteine (NAC) and whey protein are common supplemental sources of cysteine.

docs.title: Paracetamol (Acetaminophen) Overdose
docs.text:
• Paracetamol → NAPQI (toxic reactive metabolite via CYP2E1/CYP3A4)
  • NAPQI depletes hepatic glutathione → hepatocellular necrosis
  • N-acetylcysteine (NAC) IV/oral is the antidote: replenishes cysteine → GSH → detoxifies remaining NAPQI
  • NAC must be given within 8–16 hours of ingestion for maximum efficacy

docs.title: Cystinuria
docs.text:
• Defect in the rBAT-SLC7A9 dibasic amino acid transporter (also affects arginine, ornithine, lysine)
  • Cystine (oxidised dimer of cysteine) is insoluble in urine → cystine kidney stones (recurrent, staghorn calculi)
  • Treatment: high fluid intake (>3 L/day), urine alkalinisation (cystine more soluble at pH >7), D-penicillamine or tiopronin (form soluble complexes with cystine), dietary sodium and animal protein restriction

docs.title: Cystinosis
docs.text:
• Lysosomal cystine transporter (cystinosin) defect → cystine crystal accumulation in lysosomes of all tissues
  • Most common cause of inherited Fanconi syndrome in children; progresses to chronic kidney disease
  • Treatment: cysteamine (reacts with intralysosomal cystine → mixed disulphide that can exit lysosomes); renal replacement therapy; transplant

docs.title: Homocystinuria (Overlap with Methionine note)
docs.text:
• CBS deficiency → impaired Hcy → cystathionine → cysteine → secondary cysteine deficiency
  • Treated partly with cystine supplementation to compensate for inability to synthesise cysteine

docs.title: COPD / Pulmonary Mucus
docs.text: • NAC (600–1,200 mg/day) reduces mucus viscosity by breaking disulphide bonds in mucin glycoproteins → mucolytic; used in COPD and cystic fibrosis

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect Methionine Upstream precursor (transsulphuration) — cysteine can spare methionine requirements Vitamin B6 Required for CBS and CTH (both transsulphuration enzymes); deficiency impairs cysteine synthesis Folate + B12 Regulate homocysteine → methionine flux; deficiency pushes Hcy toward transsulphuration, increasing cysteine but also increasing demands on CBS Selenium Selenocysteine biosynthesis uses serine + selenophosphate analogously to cysteine biosynthesis Copper Excess copper oxidises cysteine thiols → may reduce enzyme thiol function; GSH chelates copper NAC + nitroglycerin NAC co-administration with nitroglycerin reduces nitrate tolerance; clinically relevant in chest pain management BSO (buthionine sulfoximine) Research tool — inhibits GCL → depletes GSH by blocking cysteine incorporation

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• NAC (N-Acetylcysteine, 600–2,400 mg/day):
  • Mucolytic (COPD, CF, bronchitis)
  • Antidote for paracetamol overdose (IV protocol)
  • Antioxidant / GSH precursor
  • Used in psychiatric research (OCD, schizophrenia, addiction — oxredox hypothesis)
  • Modest evidence for reducing contrast-induced nephropathy (pretreatment)
  • Whey protein: Rich in cysteine + branched-chain amino acids — effectively raises GSH levels in ageing adults
  • Cystine (oxidised dimer): Poorly soluble; not effective as a supplement
  • High-dose cysteine alone (unchelated) can be pro-oxidant at very high concentrations — NAC form is preferred for supplementation

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Glutamine is the most abundant free amino acid in the human body (plasma concentration ~500–900 μmol/L; ~60% of the free amino acid pool in muscle). It is classified as conditionally essential — synthesised de novo from glutamate + ammonia (via glutamine synthetase), but demand exceeds synthesis capacity during catabolic states (surgery, trauma, burns, sepsis, prolonged exercise). Glutamine is a critical fuel for rapidly proliferating cells (enterocytes, lymphocytes) and is the principal vehicle for inter-organ nitrogen transport and ammoniagenesis in the kidney during acidosis.

  • Classification: Conditionally essential
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Gln / Q
  • Side chain: Amide group (–CONH₂); polar, uncharged at physiological pH
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Glucogenic (→ α-ketoglutarate → TCA cycle; or → glucose via gluconeogenesis)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements
docs.text:
Condition Notes Healthy adults Synthesised endogenously; no established RDA; ~3–6 g/day from dietary proteins Critical illness / trauma Conditionally essential; supplemental doses of 20–40 g/day studied Athletes (intense training) Plasma Gln falls after prolonged endurance exercise → increased demand

No established UL. High-dose glutamine (>40 g/day) in critically ill patients without monitoring has been associated with adverse outcomes in some trials (REDOXS trial, AKI/MI context).

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Primary Fuel for Enterocytes: Small intestinal enterocytes preferentially oxidise glutamine (not glucose) for energy — via glutaminolysis (Gln → Glu → α-KG → TCA). Critical for mucosal integrity, villus structure, and gut barrier function.
  • Lymphocyte & Macrophage Fuel: Rapidly dividing immune cells rely heavily on glutamine as an oxidative and biosynthetic fuel — immune function declines in glutamine-depleted states (major surgery, critical illness)
  • Nitrogen Shuttle (Inter-Organ Nitrogen Transport):
  • Muscle releases glutamine (from glutamate + NH₄⁺ via glutamine synthetase) → liver and kidney take up glutamine
  • Liver: Gln → glutamate → urea cycle (ammonia disposal) / gluconeogenesis
  • Kidney: Gln → NH₄⁺ + glutamate → α-KG (renal ammoniagenesis; excretes acid during acidosis)
  • Ammonia Homeostasis: Glutamine synthetase in astrocytes detoxifies NH₃ → Gln (critical in liver failure/hepatic encephalopathy — cerebral Gln accumulates → astrocyte dysfunction)
  • Nucleotide Synthesis: Gln donates its amide nitrogen in purine and pyrimidine ring biosynthesis — essential for DNA/RNA synthesis in all dividing cells
  • Gluconeogenesis Substrate: Major precursor for hepatic glucose production during fasting; muscle-derived glutamine → renal/hepatic gluconeogenesis
  • Acid-Base Balance: Renal glutamine uptake → NH₄⁺ excretion in urine → net acid excretion → alkalinises blood during metabolic acidosis
  • GSH Synthesis Substrate: Gln → Glu → one of three GSH precursors (with cysteine and glycine)
  • mTORC1 Activation (indirect): Glutamine is required for leucine-induced mTORC1 activation via the SLC38A9/Ragulator/v-ATPase sensing system; glutamine also activates mTORC1 through GATOR2/FLCN pathway
  • Neurotransmitter Cycle: Astrocytes convert synaptically released glutamate → Gln (via glutamine synthetase) → shuttle Gln to neurons → neurons release Glu (glutamate) or GABA; disruption of the glutamine-glutamate cycle is implicated in epilepsy and hepatic encephalopathy

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Synthesis Glutamate + NH₄⁺ + ATP → Glutamine (glutamine synthetase; GS; ubiquitous, especially muscle + astrocytes) Catabolism Gln → Glu + NH₄⁺ (glutaminase; kidney, liver, lymphocytes, enterocytes) TCA entry Glu → α-ketoglutarate (GDH or transaminases) → Krebs cycle Gluconeogenesis Gln → Glu → α-KG → OAA → PEP → Glucose Nucleotide synthesis Gln amide N donates to PRPP → purine synthesis; to UMP → pyrimidine synthesis Renal ammoniagenesis Kidney glutaminase → NH₄⁺ (excreted) + Glu → α-KG → glucose

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Glutamine (mg, approx.) Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~1,200 mg Chicken (cooked) 85g ~1,100 mg Fish (cooked) 85g ~900–1,000 mg Eggs 1 large ~300 mg Milk (whole) 240 mL ~320 mg Tofu (firm) 100g ~550 mg Cabbage (raw) 90g ~170 mg Wheat germ 28g ~340 mg

Glutamine is labile — easily destroyed by heat and prolonged cooking. High-heat processing of protein foods significantly reduces free glutamine content.

docs.title: Critical Illness and ICU Nutrition
docs.text:
• Plasma glutamine falls dramatically after major surgery, burns, trauma, sepsis → "glutamine debt"
  • Glutamine supplementation in parenteral nutrition (PN): 0.3–0.5 g/kg/day (usually as glutamine dipeptide alanine-glutamine or glycine-glutamine for stability)
  • REDOXS Trial (2013): High-dose IV + enteral glutamine supplementation in MICU patients with multi-organ failure → increased 28-day mortality and AKI in sickest patients (MOF, AKI at baseline) — suggests glutamine supplementation is harmful in severe MOF
  • Current ESPEN guidelines: glutamine supplementation may be beneficial in burns and elective surgery; avoid in unstable MOF/AKI
  • Benefit confirmed in parenteral nutrition patients (reduces infections, hospital LOS in stable critically ill)

docs.title: Gut Integrity and Short Bowel Syndrome
docs.text:
• Short bowel syndrome (SBS): massively reduced absorptive surface → enterocyte glutamine deficiency → mucosal atrophy
  • Glutamine supplementation (30 g/day) as part of bowel rehabilitation protocols; often combined with growth hormone and modified diet (the Byrne-Wilmore protocol)

docs.title: Hepatic Encephalopathy
docs.text:
• In liver failure, glutamine accumulates in astrocytes (liver cannot clear NH₄⁺ → peripherally converted to Gln via GS)
  • Cerebral oedema and astrocyte swelling → HE symptoms
  • Paradox: glutamine synthesis normally detoxifies ammonia (protective), but glutamine itself accumulates and is re-metabolised in mitochondria (glutaminase) → releases NH₃ intramitochondrially → oxidative stress ("Trojan horse" hypothesis)

docs.title: Cancer Metabolism
docs.text:
• Many cancers are glutamine-addicted — rely on glutaminolysis to fuel TCA/anaplerosis, nucleotide synthesis, GSH, and reductive carboxylation for lipid synthesis in hypoxia
  • Glutaminase inhibitors (CB-839, telaglenastat) in clinical trials for solid tumours
  • The concept of "glutamine depletion" therapy — reduce tumour fuel supply

docs.title: Sickle Cell Anaemia
docs.text:
• Endari (L-glutamine oral powder, 10 g twice daily): FDA-approved for adults and paediatric patients ≥5 years with sickle cell disease
  • Mechanism: Gln → NAD⁺ synthesis → reduces oxidative stress in sickle RBCs → fewer vaso-occlusive crises
  • Reduces hospitalisation frequency by ~25%

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect Leucine (mTORC1) Glutamine is required for leucine-induced mTORC1 activation; glutamine depletion blunts mTOR signalling even with leucine Cysteine + Glycine All three are GSH precursors — glutamine→glutamate feeds GSH first peptide step Methotrexate / Azathioprine Inhibit nucleotide synthesis (purine/pyrimidine) — pathways that require glutamine as N-donor; glutamine availability affects efficacy/toxicity Glucocorticoids Increase muscle glutamine release and whole-body glutamine flux; chronic use → muscle glutamine depletion and wasting Ammonia Glutamine synthesis removes NH₃; glutaminase releases NH₃ — the two reactions must be balanced; GS inhibitors (e.g., MSO) raise ammonia

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• Powder form (5–15 g/day): Used by athletes post-exercise to replenish plasma glutamine; evidence for immune benefit is modest in recreational athletes; more relevant in intense military training or ultra-endurance athletes
  • Bowel disease: Some use in IBD/IBS for mucosal support; evidence is limited (Crohn's trials negative; some benefit in IBS-D at 5 g three times daily)
  • Cancer patients on chemotherapy: QoL support; some protocols include 10–30 g/day to reduce mucositis — mixed evidence; not standard of care
  • Stability: Free L-glutamine powder is stable at room temperature but degrades in solution over time; alanyl-glutamine dipeptide is more stable for parenteral/enteral use
  • Caution: Do not supplement at high doses (>40 g/day) in patients with AKI, MOF, or hepatic encephalopathy

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Glycine is the simplest amino acid — it is the only amino acid without a chiral centre, with a hydrogen atom as its side chain. It is classified as conditionally essential: synthesised from serine (primarily), threonine, and choline, but endogenous synthesis (~3 g/day) is insufficient to meet total body demands, especially for collagen synthesis (estimated need ~10–14 g/day). Glycine is the most abundant amino acid in collagen (~33% of all collagen residues), a key inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brainstem and spinal cord, and a primary conjugate for bile acid and xenobiotic detoxification.

  • Classification: Conditionally essential (non-essential classically, but often insufficient endogenously)
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Gly / G
  • Side chain: Hydrogen (–H); no chirality; smallest amino acid; allows unusual main-chain flexibility
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Glucogenic (→ serine → pyruvate)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements
docs.text:
Condition Notes Healthy adults No RDA established; estimated total need ~10–14 g/day; endogenous synthesis ~3 g/day → dietary shortfall of ~7–10 g/day Collagen synthesis demand Collagen is ~33% glycine; growing children, pregnancy, wound healing, athletes significantly increase demand Critical illness Increased demand for detoxification, GSH synthesis (glycine is a GSH precursor), repair

No established UL. High doses (≥90 g/day) may cause CNS depression via glycine receptor activation. Typical supplemental doses (3–15 g/day) are well-tolerated.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Collagen Structure: Every third residue in the collagen triple helix is glycine (Gly-X-Y repeating unit) — the small side chain is essential to fit inside the helix. Collagen is the most abundant protein in the body (~25% of total protein); glycine demand for collagen synthesis far exceeds endogenous synthesis capacity.
  • Inhibitory Neurotransmitter (CNS): Glycine is a major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brainstem, spinal cord, and retina — acts via strychnine-sensitive glycine receptors (GlyR; chloride channel). Inhibits motoneuron discharge → muscle relaxation and spinal reflex control.
  • NMDA Receptor Co-agonist: Glycine (or D-serine) is a mandatory co-agonist at the glycine binding site of NMDA glutamate receptors — both glycine and glutamate must bind for NMDA receptor to open. Important in synaptic plasticity, learning, memory.
  • Glutathione (GSH) Precursor: γ-glutamyl-cysteinyl-glycine — glycine is the third tripeptide component of GSH; glycine availability can limit GSH synthesis (especially in elderly and critically ill).
  • Bile Acid Conjugation: Glycine (and taurine) conjugate primary bile acids (cholate, chenodeoxycholate) in the liver → glycocholate, glycochenodeoxycholate → emulsify dietary fats; facilitate fat-soluble vitamin absorption.
  • Creatine Synthesis: Arginine + Glycine → Guanidinoacetate (AGAT; kidney) + Ornithine → Creatine (GAMT; liver). Creatine synthesis is a major consumer of dietary glycine.
  • One-Carbon Metabolism: Glycine ↔ Serine (serine hydroxymethyltransferase; SHMT; B6, THF) — contributes one-carbon units to folate cycle for methylation and nucleotide synthesis.
  • Porphyrin / Haem Synthesis: Glycine + Succinyl-CoA → δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) — the first and rate-limiting step in haem biosynthesis (ALA synthase; B6-dependent).
  • Purine Synthesis: Glycine is directly incorporated into the purine ring (as C4, C5, N7 of the imidazole ring) — essential for nucleotide biosynthesis.
  • Detoxification (Conjugation): Glycine conjugates benzoate → hippurate (excreted in urine); conjugates xenobiotics and drug metabolites for urinary excretion.
  • Anti-inflammatory Glycine Receptor (Gly-activated Cl⁻ channel on macrophages and hepatocytes): Glycine hyperpolarises macrophages and Kupffer cells via GlyR → reduces TNF-α, IL-1, NO release → anti-inflammatory. Active area in liver protection and surgery research.

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Synthesis Serine → Glycine (SHMT; B6, THF; reversible); Threonine aldolase (minor); Choline → betaine → glycine Degradation Glycine cleavage system (GCS/GLDC; P, H, T, L proteins; requires B2, B6, lipoic acid) — glycine → CO₂ + NH₄⁺ + methylene-THF Collagen pathway Gly incorporated into pro-collagen Gly-X-Y repeats; hydroxylation of X and Y (Pro, Lys) requires Vit C Haem synthesis Gly + Succinyl-CoA → ALA (ALA synthase; B6) → porphyrins → haem Creatine Gly + Arg → Guanidinoacetate (AGAT; kidney) → Creatine (GAMT; liver; SAM)

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Glycine (mg) Pork skin / gelatin 10g dry gelatin ~2,000–2,500 mg Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~1,350 mg Chicken (cooked) 85g ~1,100 mg Collagen peptide powder 10g ~2,000–2,600 mg Salmon (cooked) 85g ~730 mg Pumpkin seeds 28g ~430 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~580 mg Egg 1 large ~200 mg

Collagen is the richest food source of glycine; muscle meat (fillets) is lower in glycine than connective tissue–rich cuts (oxtail, bone broth, pig's trotters, skin). Bone broth provides significant glycine.

docs.title: Non-Ketotic Hyperglycinaemia (NKH / Glycine Encephalopathy)
docs.text:
• Defect in the glycine cleavage system (GCS); autosomal recessive
  • Accumulation of glycine in blood and CSF → neonatal hypotonia, seizures, apnoea, severe intellectual disability or death
  • Excess glycine over-activates NMDA receptors (co-agonist site) + glycine receptors → excitotoxicity paradoxically from an inhibitory amino acid at non-inhibitory receptors
  • Treatment: sodium benzoate (conjugates glycine → hippurate, excreted), NMDA antagonists (dextromethorphan, ketamine) — outcomes are poor in severe forms

docs.title: Methylmalonic Acidaemia / Propionic Acidaemia
docs.text: • Glycine conjugates propionyl-CoA → propionylglycine; urinary propionylglycine is a diagnostic marker

docs.title: Strychnine Poisoning
docs.text:
• Strychnine blocks glycine receptors (GlyR) in spinal cord → loss of inhibitory interneuron function → violent tetanic convulsions (muscle hyperexcitability)
  • Antidote: supportive care, benzodiazepines; highlights critical role of glycine in spinal inhibition

docs.title: Schizophrenia (NMDA Hypofunction Hypothesis)
docs.text:
• Glycine (3–80 g/day) and D-cycloserine (partial GlyR agonist) studied as adjuncts in schizophrenia to enhance NMDA receptor co-agonist activity
  • Some trials show modest improvement in negative symptoms; not standard of care

docs.title: Metabolic Syndrome and Insulin Resistance
docs.text:
• Low plasma glycine is consistently observed in obesity, insulin resistance, and T2DM
  • Glycine supplementation (9 g/day) in one RCT improved insulin sensitivity in obese subjects; mechanism unclear (possibly improved mitochondrial function, reduced inflammation, improved GSH)

docs.title: Sleep Quality
docs.text:
• Glycine 3 g orally before bedtime: RCTs show improved subjective sleep quality, reduced daytime sleepiness, and reduced core body temperature (possibly via hypothalamic glycine receptors)
  • One of the better-supported non-pharmacological sleep interventions

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect Vitamin B6 SHMT (Gly↔Ser), ALA synthase (haem), and glycine cleavage H-protein all require PLP Folate (THF) SHMT reaction couples glycine-serine interconversion to the folate one-carbon cycle Vitamin C Required for prolyl/lysyl hydroxylation in collagen (acts on the X and Y positions adjacent to glycine) Zinc Supports ALA dehydratase (second step of haem synthesis, downstream of glycine entry); also binds metalloproteins where glycine-rich motifs are present Sodium benzoate Conjugates with glycine → hippurate (excreted in urine) → reduces plasma glycine; used therapeutically in NKH and urea cycle disorders NMDA receptor drugs Glycine co-agonist site is target for memantine (partial), D-cycloserine, and is relevant in ketamine mechanism of action

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• Collagen peptide supplements (5–15 g/day): Rich in glycine, proline, hydroxyproline; evidence supports joint pain reduction (knee OA), skin elasticity improvement, and reduction in exercise-related joint discomfort
  • L-Glycine powder (3–5 g before bed): Well-supported for improving sleep quality (RCTs); also used for anxiety and GI comfort
  • Glycine for metabolic health: Early evidence for insulin sensitivity, anti-inflammatory effects; larger trials needed
  • Both glycine and taurine (another Cys/Met-derived compound) are essential for bile acid conjugation — together they ensure adequate fat-soluble vitamin absorption
  • High-quality protein with organ meats, connective tissue, and bone broth increases dietary glycine significantly compared to a muscle-meat–only diet

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Histidine is an essential amino acid — it cannot be synthesised in adequate amounts by the body and must be obtained from the diet. It is unique among essential amino acids in that it was historically classified as "semi-essential" because adults can synthesise small amounts, but this is insufficient for normal function. It is the precursor of histamine, a key mediator of immune responses, gastric acid secretion, and neurotransmission. It also forms part of the active site of many enzymes (as the imidazole side chain acts as both a proton donor and acceptor near physiological pH).

  • Classification: Essential (9 essential amino acids)
  • IUPAC abbreviation: His / H
  • Side chain: Imidazole group; pKa ~6.0 — unique buffering capacity near physiological pH
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Glucogenic (converted to α-ketoglutarate)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA (mg/kg/day) Approximate daily need Infants 0–6 months ~36 mg/kg/day — Children 1–3 years ~22 mg/kg/day ~490 mg/day Adults 19+ ~14 mg/kg/day ~980 mg/day (70 kg adult) Pregnant Women Higher requirements ~1,000–1,100 mg/day

No established UL for histidine from food. High-dose supplements (> 4 g/day) have been associated with adverse effects.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Histamine Precursor: Decarboxylated by histidine decarboxylase to form histamine — mediates allergic responses, gastric acid secretion (H2 receptors on parietal cells), vasodilation, wakefulness, and neurotransmission.
  • Haemoglobin Buffering: The imidazole side chains of histidine residues in haemoglobin (the Bohr effect) facilitate CO₂ transport and O₂ release in tissues.
  • Carnosine Synthesis: β-alanine + histidine → carnosine (dipeptide) — high concentrations in muscle and brain; buffers lactic acid during exercise, antioxidant, inhibits protein glycation.
  • Enzyme Active Sites: Histidine residues are critical catalytic residues in serine proteases (trypsin, chymotrypsin, thrombin), kinases, and phosphatases.
  • Metal Chelation: Imidazole ring coordinates zinc, copper, iron in metalloenzymes (e.g., carbonic anhydrase).
  • Folate Metabolism: Histidine is catabolised through the formiminoglutamate (FIGLU) pathway, consuming tetrahydrofolate — FIGLU accumulates in folate deficiency (used in FIGLU excretion test for folate status).
  • Immune Regulation: Histamine derived from histidine modulates innate and adaptive immune responses.

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Absorption Active transport in the small intestine (SLC6A19, SLC36 transporters) Catabolism Histidine → urocanate → imidazolonepropionate → formimino-glutamate → glutamate → TCA cycle Key enzyme Histidase (HAL gene) — deficiency causes histidinaemia Histamine synthesis Histidine decarboxylase (HDC) — mast cells, enterochromaffin-like cells, neurons, macrophages

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text: Food Serving Histidine (mg) Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~880 mg Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~800 mg Tuna (canned) 85g ~870 mg Salmon (cooked) 85g ~750 mg Parmesan cheese 28g ~440 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~530 mg Quinoa (cooked) 185g ~360 mg Egg 1 large ~295 mg

docs.title: Histidinaemia
docs.text:
• Autosomal recessive deficiency of histidase
  • Accumulation of histidine and downstream metabolites (urocanate, imidazole pyruvate)
  • Historically considered benign; surveillance continues but severe neurological effects are uncommon

docs.title: Histamine Intolerance / Mast Cell Activation
docs.text:
• Excess dietary histidine or histamine (aged cheese, fermented foods, wine) → symptoms in individuals with reduced diamine oxidase (DAO) or histamine N-methyltransferase (HNMT) activity
  • Symptoms: flushing, urticaria, rhinorrhoea, headache, palpitations

docs.title: Folate Deficiency Diagnosis
docs.text:
• FIGLU excretion test: oral histidine load → measure urinary FIGLU
  • Elevated FIGLU indicates folate deficiency (impaired FIGLU conversion requires tetrahydrofolate)

docs.title: Joint Conditions
docs.text:
• Histidine is depleted in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients — mechanism unclear; possibly due to elevated histaminase or increased demand
  • Some trials have supplemented histidine in RA with modest benefit

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect Folate (B9) Required for FIGLU → glutamate conversion; histidine loading reveals folate status Zinc / Copper Histidine chelates and aids transport of zinc and copper across intestinal epithelium Antihistamines (H1/H2 blockers) Block histamine receptors — do not affect histidine absorption but modulate downstream histamine effects Proton pump inhibitors Reduce gastric acid — same target pathway as histamine (H2 receptor on parietal cells)

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• Carnosine supplements provide histidine + β-alanine; used by athletes for intramuscular buffering
  • High-dose isolated histidine supplementation (>4 g/day) is not recommended without medical supervision
  • Histidine-rich infant formulas are critical — infants have higher relative requirements than adults

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Isoleucine is an essential amino acid and one of three branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs), alongside leucine and valine. While leucine is the dominant mTORC1 activator, isoleucine's primary metabolic role is in glucose transport and uptake in muscle — it independently stimulates GLUT4 translocation and glucose disposal. Isoleucine is both glucogenic and ketogenic, and its catabolism is tightly linked to energy metabolism in muscle.

  • Classification: Essential; Branched-Chain Amino Acid (BCAA)
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Ile / I
  • Side chain: Branched aliphatic (methylethyl group); has two stereocentres
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Both (→ succinyl-CoA [glucogenic] and acetyl-CoA [ketogenic])

docs.title: Dietary Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA (mg/kg/day) Approximate daily need Infants 0–6 months ~58 mg/kg/day — Children 1–3 years ~36 mg/kg/day ~800 mg/day Adults 19+ ~19 mg/kg/day ~1,330 mg/day (70 kg adult)

No established UL for isoleucine from food. Taken in isolation, high-dose isoleucine may disturb BCAA balance by competing with leucine and valine at shared transporters.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Glucose Uptake in Muscle: Isoleucine independently stimulates GLUT4 translocation to the plasma membrane in skeletal muscle — increases glucose uptake even in the absence of insulin (via PI3K/Akt signalling). This is distinct from leucine's role and makes isoleucine important for post-exercise glucose disposal.
  • Glycogen Synthesis: Promotes muscle glycogen resynthesis in the post-exercise window.
  • mTORC1 Activation (minor): Contributes to mTOR signalling but is significantly less potent than leucine.
  • Haemoglobin Structure: Isoleucine is a component of haemoglobin — the substitution Glu6→Val (sickle cell) is adjacent; comparable mutations at other sites can affect stability.
  • Immune Function: Supports synthesis of β-defensins (antimicrobial peptides produced by intestinal epithelium), contributing to innate mucosal immunity.
  • Protein Synthesis Substrate: Essential structural component of muscle, connective tissue, and visceral proteins.
  • Energy Supply: Catabolised in muscle during prolonged exercise, providing acetyl-CoA to the TCA cycle.

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Absorption Active transport via LAT1 (SLC7A5) — shared transporter with leucine, valine, and aromatic amino acids First-pass metabolism Low hepatic extraction; preferentially taken up by muscle and adipose tissue Catabolism Ile → α-methylbutyryl-CoA → propionyl-CoA (→ succinyl-CoA, glucogenic) + acetyl-CoA (ketogenic) Key enzyme Branched-Chain α-Keto Acid Dehydrogenase (BCKD) complex — same as leucine and valine Regulation Muscle exercise increases BCKD activity; insulin inhibits BCAA catabolism (promotes protein synthesis)

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text: Food Serving Isoleucine (mg) Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~1,100 mg Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~1,050 mg Canned tuna 85g ~1,000 mg Egg 1 large ~340 mg Milk (whole) 240 mL ~450 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~700 mg Pumpkin seeds 28g ~380 mg Whey protein isolate 30g ~1,200 mg

docs.title: Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD)
docs.text:
• BCKD complex deficiency — isoleucine accumulates alongside leucine and valine
  • Isoleucine is toxic in excess (neurological), but leucine is the primary driver of encephalopathy
  • Management: BCAA-restricted diet; branched-chain keto acid–supplemented medical formulas; liver transplant

docs.title: Isovaleric Acidaemia (not isoleucine-specific)
docs.text: • Affects leucine catabolism (isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase); isoleucine catabolism is separate

docs.title: Post-Exercise Glucose Disposal
docs.text: • GLUT4 translocation by isoleucine is relevant in the context of post-workout nutrition — supports glycogen resynthesis and mirrors some insulin-like actions

docs.title: BCAA Ratio in Supplementation
docs.text: • Excess isolated leucine supplementation reduces isoleucine plasma concentration (transporter competition) — reinforces the importance of balanced BCAA ratios (2:1:1 Leu:Ile:Val)

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Factor Effect Leucine + Valine Compete at LAT1; high leucine reduces isoleucine uptake; balanced BCAA ratios recommended B vitamins (B1, B2, B3, lipoic acid) Required cofactors for the BCKD complex — isoleucine catabolism depends on these Insulin Insulin suppresses BCAA (incl. isoleucine) catabolism — promotes protein anabolism Glucose Isoleucine-mediated GLUT4 upregulation is additive with insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• Sold as part of BCAA supplements (typically 2:1:1 Leu:Ile:Val)
  • Rarely supplemented in isolation; imbalance without co-supplementation of leucine/valine is counterproductive
  • Some evidence that BCAAs (including isoleucine) reduce exercise-induced muscle soreness and protect lean mass during caloric restriction
  • Athletes consuming sufficient high-quality protein (≥1.6 g/kg/day) are unlikely to need additional BCAA supplementation

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Leucine is an essential amino acid and the most abundant branched-chain amino acid (BCAA) by proportion in muscle protein. It is the primary nutritional signal that activates mTORC1 (mechanistic target of rapamycin complex 1), making it the key anabolic trigger for muscle protein synthesis. Unlike other amino acids, leucine is catabolised primarily in skeletal muscle (not the liver), making its plasma level an important metabolic signal in the postprandial state.

  • Classification: Essential; Branched-Chain Amino Acid (BCAA)
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Leu / L
  • Side chain: Isobutyl (aliphatic, hydrophobic)
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Exclusively ketogenic (→ acetyl-CoA and acetoacetate; does not contribute to gluconeogenesis)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA (mg/kg/day) Approximate daily need Infants 0–6 months ~103 mg/kg/day — Children 1–3 years ~73 mg/kg/day ~1,600 mg/day Adults 19+ ~39 mg/kg/day ~2,730 mg/day (70 kg adult) Athletes / high protein need Higher 3,000–4,000 mg/day

No established UL from food sources. Leucine supplements at very high doses (>10 g/day) may impair isoleucine and valine status and cause mild hyperammonaemia.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• mTORC1 Activation (Master Anabolic Signal): Leucine directly activates mTORC1 via the Rag GTPase–Ragulator complex and Sestrin2 sensor — initiates protein synthesis through phosphorylation of S6K1 and 4E-BP1. No other amino acid has this potency.
  • Muscle Protein Synthesis: Acts as both a substrate and regulatory signal; the "leucine threshold" concept — a minimum intracellular leucine concentration must be reached to maximally stimulate MPS.
  • Insulin Secretion: Stimulates pancreatic β-cell insulin secretion independently of glucose (via glutamate dehydrogenase activation).
  • Protein Sparing: During energy restriction, leucine catabolism can generate ketone bodies and acetyl-CoA for energy substrate.
  • Wound Healing: Provides substrate for tissue repair; upregulates protein synthesis in recovering tissues.
  • Glucose Homeostasis: High leucine activates mTORC1 → S6K1 → IRS-1 serine phosphorylation, which can impair insulin signalling at high doses (mechanistic link between high BCAA diets and insulin resistance).

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Absorption Transported by LAT1 (SLC7A5) — shared with other BCAAs, tyrosine, phenylalanine First-pass metabolism Minimal hepatic extraction (~5%); primarily taken up by muscle Catabolism Leucine → α-ketoisocaproate (KIC) via BCAA aminotransferase → isovaleryl-CoA → acetyl-CoA + acetoacetate (via BCKD complex) Key enzyme Branched-Chain α-Keto Acid Dehydrogenase (BCKD) — requires B1, B2, B3, lipoic acid Regulation BCKD is inactivated by phosphorylation; activated by dephosphorylation in muscle with exercise

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Leucine (mg) Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~2,150 mg Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~2,090 mg Canned tuna 85g ~1,900 mg Milk (whole) 240 mL ~800 mg Whey protein isolate 30g ~2,900 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~1,300 mg Edamame (cooked) 155g ~1,200 mg Parmesan cheese 28g ~870 mg

Whey protein is notably leucine-rich (~10–11%) and rapidly absorbed, making it particularly effective for MPS stimulation.

docs.title: Leucinosis / Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD)
docs.text:
• Autosomal recessive deficiency of the BCKD complex — all three BCAAs (leucine, isoleucine, valine) accumulate
  • Leucine is the primary neurotoxin — causes encephalopathy, cerebral oedema
  • Classic MSUD: neonatal onset; characteristic maple syrup odour in urine/cerumen
  • Management: BCAA-restricted diet; leucine-reduced medical formulas; liver transplant (curative — restores hepatic BCKD activity)

docs.title: Sarcopenia & Ageing
docs.text:
• Anabolic resistance — older muscle requires higher leucine doses to maximally activate MPS
  • Leucine-enriched protein supplements (leucine ≥ 3g per meal) may partially overcome anabolic resistance in elderly

docs.title: Hyperleucinaemia and Insulin Resistance
docs.text:
• Chronically elevated plasma BCAA (incl. leucine) — strong biomarker associated with insulin resistance and T2DM risk
