  • Mechanistic: S6K1 → IRS-1 Ser307 phosphorylation → impairs insulin signalling

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Factor Effect Isoleucine + Valine BCAAs compete for the same transporter (LAT1); excess leucine can lower plasma isoleucine and valine — BCAA supplements should contain balanced ratios (typically 2:1:1 Leu:Ile:Val) B vitamins (B1, B2, B3, lipoic acid) Cofactors for the BCKD complex — deficiency slows leucine catabolism Insulin Leucine stimulates insulin; insulin drives leucine into muscle — synergistic for post-meal anabolism Rapamycin / mTOR inhibitors Block leucine's anabolic signalling — clinically relevant in transplant and oncology patients

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• BCAA supplements: Most commonly 2:1:1 (Leu:Ile:Val) ratio; used peri-workout to limit muscle catabolism
  • Leucine-enriched protein meals: Effective strategy for elderly or those with anabolic resistance
  • HMB (β-hydroxy β-methylbutyrate): Metabolite of leucine (via KIC); marketed for anti-catabolic effects — evidence is stronger in untrained individuals and clinical muscle-wasting states
  • Isolated high-dose leucine (>10–15 g/day chronically) is not advised due to aminoaciduria and potential metabolic imbalances

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Lysine is an essential amino acid and the most commonly limiting amino acid in cereal-grain–based diets. It is critical for collagen synthesis and cross-linking, immune function, and carnitine biosynthesis. Lysine has a positively charged ε-amino group that participates in key post-translational modifications (acetylation, methylation, ubiquitination) on histone proteins — directly linking lysine to epigenetic regulation of gene expression.

  • Classification: Essential (9 essential amino acids)
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Lys / K
  • Side chain: ε-amino group (pKa ~10.5); positively charged at physiological pH
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Exclusively ketogenic (along with leucine — the only two strictly ketogenic essential amino acids; → acetyl-CoA and acetoacetate)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA (mg/kg/day) Approximate daily need Infants 0–6 months ~99 mg/kg/day — Children 1–3 years ~62 mg/kg/day ~1,365 mg/day Adults 19+ ~38 mg/kg/day ~2,660 mg/day (70 kg adult) Pregnant Women Higher ~3,100 mg/day

No established UL from food sources. Supplemental doses of 1–3 g/day are used clinically. Very high doses (>15 g/day) have caused GI symptoms and tubulointerstitial nephritis in isolated case reports.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Collagen Synthesis: Lysine residues are hydroxylated by prolyl hydroxylase (requires vitamin C) to form hydroxylysine — essential for cross-linking collagen fibrils via lysyl oxidase (requires copper). Without adequate lysine or vitamin C → weakened connective tissue, poor wound healing.
  • Carnitine Biosynthesis: Lysine (and methionine) → butyrobetaine → L-carnitine (requires vitamin C, B6, niacin, iron as cofactors). Carnitine is essential for long-chain fatty acid transport into mitochondria for β-oxidation.
  • Calcium Absorption: Lysine increases intestinal calcium absorption and reduces urinary calcium excretion — may play a role in bone mineral density maintenance.
  • Antiviral Activity (Herpes simplex): Arginine is required for HSV replication; lysine competes with arginine for intestinal absorption and intracellular uptake — lysine supplementation reduces HSV recurrence frequency and severity in clinical trials.
  • Histone Modification: ε-amino groups of histone lysine residues undergo:
  • Acetylation (by HATs) → gene activation
  • Methylation (by HMTs) → activation or repression depending on position (H3K4me3 = active; H3K27me3 = repressive)
  • Ubiquitination → protein degradation (via proteasome) or signalling
  • Enzyme Structure: Lysine residues form hydrogen bonds and ion pairs central to enzyme active site architecture.
  • Antibody Production: Lysine availability supports immunoglobulin synthesis.

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Absorption Active transport via b⁰,⁺ transporter (SLC7A9 / BAT1) and rBAT — shared with arginine, ornithine, cystine Catabolism (main) Saccharopine pathway (liver): Lys → saccharopine → aminoadipate semialdehyde → α-ketoadipate → acetyl-CoA Alternative pathway Pipecolic acid pathway (active in brain and peroxisomes) Carnitine synthesis Lys → ε-N-trimethyllysine → 3-hydroxy-trimethyllysine → carnitine precursors Hydroxylation Prolyl hydroxylase-like enzymes → hydroxylysine in collagen

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Lysine (mg) Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~2,300 mg Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~2,200 mg Tuna (canned) 85g ~2,100 mg Eggs 1 large ~455 mg Milk (whole) 240 mL ~660 mg Parmesan cheese 28g ~780 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~1,240 mg Quinoa (cooked) 185g ~440 mg Seitan (wheat gluten) 100g very low — lysine-deficient

Wheat, corn, and most cereal grains are poor in lysine — the primary limiting amino acid in plant-based and cereal-dominant diets. Legumes compensate (high lysine, low methionine).

docs.title: Lysinuric Protein Intolerance (LPI)
docs.text:
• Defect in the y⁺LAT1–4F2hc transporter (dibasic amino acid transporter)
  • Impaired intestinal absorption and renal reabsorption of lysine, arginine, ornithine
  • Results in urea cycle disruption (hyperammonaemia), protein intolerance, lung disease (PAP), haematological findings
  • Treatment: low-protein diet, citrulline supplementation to bypass the defect, lysine supplementation (oral)

docs.title: Familial Hyperlysinaemia
docs.text:
• Bifunctional enzyme deficiency (aminoadipic semialdehyde synthase — AASS); generally benign
  • Elevated plasma and urine lysine; usually an incidental amino acid screen finding

docs.title: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Recurrence
docs.text:
• Lysine supplementation (500–3,000 mg/day) reduces frequency and severity of HSV outbreaks
  • Mechanism: competes with arginine (required for HSV replication) at shared intestinal and cellular transporters
  • Evidence: meta-analyses support decreased recurrence; effect size is moderate

docs.title: Collagen Disorders / Wound Healing
docs.text:
• Lysine deficiency → impaired collagen cross-linking → delayed healing, fragile connective tissue
  • Relevant in severe malnutrition, elderly with protein-energy malnutrition

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect Vitamin C Required for hydroxylysine formation (hydroxylation of lysine in collagen) and for carnitine synthesis Arginine Competitive antagonist — high arginine impairs lysine absorption; lysine:arginine ratio is relevant for HSV management Copper Lysyl oxidase (copper-dependent) forms collagen and elastin cross-links with hydroxylysine B6, B3, Iron Cofactors for carnitine biosynthesis from lysine and methionine Calcium Lysine enhances intestinal Ca²⁺ absorption; potential for co-supplementation in bone health protocols

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• L-Lysine supplements (500–3,000 mg/day): Used for HSV recurrence prevention; widely available OTC
  • Combined with Vitamin C: Sometimes co-supplemented for collagen synthesis / wound healing support
  • Athletes: Lysine is rarely limiting if total protein intake is adequate with varied sources (meat, dairy, legumes)
  • Vegan diets: Should ensure adequate lysine through legumes (lentils, chickpeas, soy, tofu) — cereal-only diets risk lysine insufficiency

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Methionine is an essential amino acid and the only sulphur-containing essential amino acid (alongside the conditionally essential cysteine). It is the universal methyl group donor via its activated form S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), making it central to epigenetic regulation, neurotransmitter inactivation, creatine synthesis, and the transsulphuration pathway that produces cysteine and ultimately glutathione. All mammalian protein synthesis begins with methionine (start codon: AUG).

  • Classification: Essential (9 essential amino acids)
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Met / M
  • Side chain: Thioether (–CH₂–CH₂–S–CH₃); sulphur-containing, hydrophobic
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Glucogenic (→ succinyl-CoA via propionate)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA (combined Met + Cys, mg/kg/day) Approximate daily need Infants 0–6 months ~43 mg/kg/day — Children 1–3 years ~28 mg/kg/day ~615 mg/day Adults 19+ ~19 mg/kg/day ~1,330 mg/day (70 kg adult)

RDA is expressed as combined methionine + cysteine (cysteine can spare methionine). No established UL from food. High supplemental methionine (>5 g/day) increases plasma homocysteine significantly.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• S-Adenosylmethionine (SAM) — Universal Methyl Donor:
  • Methionine + ATP → SAM (via methionine adenosyltransferase)
  • SAM donates methyl groups to DNA (DNA methylation → gene silencing), histones, RNA, neurotransmitters, phospholipids, creatine, and dozens of other substrates
  • SAM → S-adenosylhomocysteine (SAH) → homocysteine → re-methylated to methionine (requires folate, B12) or directed to transsulphuration
  • Methionine Cycle (One-Carbon Metabolism):
  • Remethylation: Homocysteine + 5-methylTHF → Methionine (requires B12 as cofactor for methionine synthase)
  • Transsulphuration: Homocysteine → Cystathionine (CBS, B6-dependent) → Cysteine → Glutathione, taurine, sulphate
  • Initiation of Protein Synthesis: All eukaryotic mRNAs are translated from AUG (methionine) start codon; the initiator Met is frequently co-translationally cleaved
  • Creatine Synthesis: SAM donates a methyl group in guanidinoacetate → creatine conversion (in liver); creatine synthesis consumes ~40–45% of daily SAM methyl groups
  • Phosphatidylcholine Synthesis: SAM methylates phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) → phosphatidylcholine (PC) — critical for cell membrane function and VLDL secretion from liver
  • Epigenetic Regulation: DNA methylation (by DNMTs using SAM) controls gene expression across development, ageing, and disease
  • Antioxidant Precursor: Via transsulphuration → Cysteine → Glutathione (GSH), taurine

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Absorption Active transport (intestinal – SLC7A9, SLC6A19) Activation Met + ATP → SAM (methionine adenosyltransferase, MAT1A/MAT2A) Methylation SAM → SAH → Homocysteine Remethylation Hcy + 5-MTHF → Met (methionine synthase; B12-dependent) Transsulphuration Hcy → cystathionine (CBS; B6) → Cysteine Catabolism Cysteine → pyruvate / sulphate / taurine; Met → α-ketobutyrate → propionyl-CoA → succinyl-CoA

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Methionine (mg) Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~680 mg Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~650 mg Canned tuna 85g ~700 mg Egg 1 large ~210 mg Brazil nuts 28g ~640 mg Parmesan cheese 28g ~490 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~310 mg Sesame seeds 28g ~335 mg

Animal proteins are consistently high in methionine. Plant proteins (particularly legumes) tend to be methionine-limited (complemented by cereals which are methionine-rich but lysine-poor).

docs.title: Homocystinuria (Classical)
docs.text:
• Deficiency of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS); autosomal recessive
  • Homocysteine accumulates to very high levels (plasma Hcy >100 μmol/L)
  • Features: Marfanoid habitus, ectopia lentis (downward lens dislocation — opposite of Marfan), intellectual disability, osteoporosis, thromboembolic events (DVT, stroke)
  • Treatment: B6 (many are pyridoxine-responsive), methionine-restricted + cystine-supplemented diet, betaine (alternative methyl donor for remethylation), folate + B12

docs.title: Hyperhomocysteinaemia
docs.text:
• Mild-moderate elevation (15–100 μmol/L): B12, folate, B6 deficiency; CKD; hypothyroidism; MTHFR C677T polymorphism
  • Independent risk factor for cardiovascular disease, stroke, dementia
  • Treatment: B12 + folate (± B6) supplementation lowers Hcy levels; evidence for CVD risk reduction is mixed

docs.title: Methionine Restriction (Longevity Research)
docs.text:
• Dietary methionine restriction extends lifespan in rodents — mechanism: reduced IGF-1, reduced mitochondrial ROS generation, altered methionine cycle flux
  • Human relevance under investigation; not a current clinical recommendation

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect Folate (B9) + B12 Required for remethylation of homocysteine → methionine; deficiency causes Hcy accumulation Pyridoxine (B6) CBS cofactor for transsulphuration; deficiency causes homocystinuria (partially reversible with B6) Riboflavin (B2) Cofactor for MTHFR (converts dietary folate to 5-MTHF); relevant especially with MTHFR C677T Cysteine Cysteine can spare methionine requirements by reducing the transsulphuration demand Betaine Alternative methyl donor remethylating homocysteine (BHMT pathway); used in homocystinuria management Nitrous oxide (N₂O) Irreversibly inactivates B12 → blocks methionine synthase → acute functional methionine cycle impairment

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• SAMe (S-adenosylmethionine) supplements: Used for depression, osteoarthritis, liver disease; effective SAM precursor; doses 400–1,600 mg/day
  • Methionine supplementation is rarely needed in individuals with adequate dietary protein
  • High-protein diets elevate methionine intake and can raise homocysteine — especially relevant if B vitamin status is suboptimal
  • NAC (N-acetylcysteine) provides cysteine, which can reduce the methionine burden on the transsulphuration pathway

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid and the metabolic precursor of tyrosine, dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine, melanin, and thyroid hormones. Its conversion to tyrosine by phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) is the most clinically significant reaction, and deficiency of PAH causes the well-known inborn error phenylketonuria (PKU). Phenylalanine exists as two enantiomers: L-phenylalanine (proteinogenic) and D-phenylalanine (inhibits enkephalin degradation).

  • Classification: Essential (9 essential amino acids)
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Phe / F
  • Side chain: Benzyl group (phenyl + methylene); large, hydrophobic, aromatic
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Both (glucogenic via fumarate; ketogenic via acetoacetate)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA (combined Phe + Tyr, mg/kg/day) Approximate daily need Infants 0–6 months ~98 mg/kg/day — Children 1–3 years ~69 mg/kg/day ~1,500 mg/day Adults 19+ ~33 mg/kg/day ~2,300 mg/day (70 kg adult)

RDA is expressed as combined phenylalanine + tyrosine (since Phe → Tyr via PAH). Individuals with PKU must restrict Phe drastically and supplement with tyrosine.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Tyrosine Synthesis: PAH + tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) → hydroxylates Phe → Tyr; this is the rate-limiting step for catecholamine and thyroid hormone production
  • Catecholamine Precursor Chain: Phe → Tyr → L-DOPA → Dopamine → Norepinephrine → Epinephrine
  • Melanin Synthesis: Phe → Tyr → DOPA → eumelanin / pheomelanin (via tyrosinase)
  • Thyroid Hormone Precursor: Tyr residues in thyroglobulin are iodinated → T3/T4 (requires PAH-generated tyrosine)
  • Protein Structure: Aromatic side chain participates in hydrophobic core packing, π-stacking, and cation-π interactions in protein folding
  • Aspartame Metabolism: Aspartame (artificial sweetener) = Asp + Phe methyl ester; hydrolysis releases phenylalanine — critical PKU warning on all aspartame-containing products
  • Enkephalin Degradation Inhibition (D-Phe): D-phenylalanine inhibits carboxypeptidase A and enkephalinase → prolongs endogenous opioid (enkephalin) activity — used in some analgesic formulations as DL-phenylalanine (DLPA)

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Absorption Active transport via LAT1 (SLC7A5); same transporter as BCAAs and tyrosine Hydroxylation Phe + O₂ + BH4 → Tyr + BH2 (phenylalanine hydroxylase, PAH; liver) BH4 regeneration DHPR enzyme (dihydropteridine reductase); requires NADH Catabolism Tyr → 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate → homogentisate → maleylacetoacetate → fumarate + acetoacetate Aromatic metabolites Phenylpyruvate, phenylacetate (PKU markers); trace amounts in normal catabolism

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text: Food Serving Phenylalanine (mg) Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~1,000 mg Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~980 mg Canned tuna 85g ~950 mg Egg 1 large ~340 mg Milk (whole) 240 mL ~420 mg Soy protein isolate 30g ~1,310 mg Pumpkin seeds 28g ~415 mg Parmesan cheese 28g ~630 mg

docs.title: Phenylketonuria (PKU)
docs.text:
• Cause: Autosomal recessive deficiency of PAH (or its cofactor BH4) → phenylalanine accumulates
  • Classic PKU: PAH activity <1%; plasma Phe > 1,200 μmol/L
  • Pathophysiology: Excess Phe competes with LAT1 for transport across the blood-brain barrier → reduces brain aromatic amino acids → decreased dopamine, serotonin, myelin synthesis → intellectual disability, seizures, musty odour (phenylacetate), eczema, fair skin/hair (reduced melanin)
  • Newborn Screening: Universal in most countries (Guthrie test / tandem MS); treatment must begin within 3 weeks of birth to prevent irreversible neurological damage
  • Treatment:
  • Phe-restricted diet with amino acid formula (Phe-free) + supplemental tyrosine (lifelong)
  • Sapropterin (Kuvan): Synthetic BH4; works in BH4-responsive PKU variants (~25–50% of patients) — lowers plasma Phe levels
  • Pegvaliase (Palynziq): PEGylated phenylalanine ammonia lyase (bacterial enzyme) — metabolises Phe to ammonia + trans-cinnamic acid; for adults with uncontrolled PKU
  • Maternal PKU: Women with PKU must maintain Phe <360 μmol/L throughout pregnancy to prevent embryopathy

docs.title: BH4 Deficiencies (Non-classic Hyperphenylalaninaemia)
docs.text:
• Defects in BH4 synthesis/recycling (DHPR, PTPS, GCH1 deficiencies) → neurotransmitter deficiencies despite near-normal Phe levels (since BH4 is also cofactor for tyrosine and tryptophan hydroxylases)
  • Treated with BH4 + neurotransmitter precursors (L-DOPA, 5-HTP)

docs.title: Alkaptonuria
docs.text:
• Deficiency of homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase (downstream in phenylalanine/tyrosine catabolism)
  • Accumulation of homogentisic acid → excreted in urine (darkens on standing), deposited in connective tissue (ochronosis) → arthritis, darkened sclerae and ear cartilage

docs.title: Albinism (Oculocutaneous)
docs.text: • Tyrosinase deficiency → impaired melanin synthesis from Tyr (Phe/Tyr pathway intact; block is downstream)

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) Essential PAH cofactor; riboflavin and NADH maintain BH4 in active form Tyrosine Product of Phe hydroxylation — spares Phe requirements; supplemented in PKU to prevent catecholamine deficiency LAT1 transporter competitors BCAAs (leucine, isoleucine, valine) share LAT1 — very high BCAA intake reduces Phe/Tyr brain transport (used experimentally to lower Phe in brain in PKU) Aspartame Releases Phe on hydrolysis — all aspartame products carry PKU warning MAOIs Block monoamine oxidase — excess tyramine/phenylalanine can cause hypertensive crisis with certain foods; Phe relevance is indirect via tyrosine/tyramine

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• DL-Phenylalanine (DLPA): Combination of L- and D-enantiomers; marketed for pain relief (D-form inhibits enkephalin degradation) and mood support — limited clinical evidence; avoid in PKU
  • L-Phenylalanine: Rarely supplemented alone; used in some vitiligo protocols (with UVA therapy) to increase melanin synthesis
  • Contraindicated in PKU — any phenylalanine supplement is dangerous for PKU patients
  • Excess phenylalanine suppresses tryptophan and tyrosine brain uptake via LAT1 competition — relevant at very high supplement doses

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Proline is a conditionally essential amino acid with a unique cyclic structure — its side chain is bonded to both the α-carbon and the nitrogen, forming a pyrrolidine ring. This makes proline the only imino acid among the standard 20 amino acids and gives it exceptional conformational rigidity. Proline is the second most abundant amino acid in collagen (after glycine), essential for forming the collagen triple helix, and plays distinctive roles in protein folding, turn formation, and as a stress-responsive osmolyte in many organisms. It can be synthesised from glutamate or arginine.

  • Classification: Conditionally essential
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Pro / P
  • Side chain: Pyrrolidine ring (cyclic — N is part of the ring); rigid; disrupts α-helices and β-sheets → introduces β-turns
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Glucogenic (→ glutamate → α-ketoglutarate)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements
docs.text:
Condition Notes Healthy adults Synthesised from glutamate; no established RDA; estimated 2–4 g/day from mixed diet Collagen synthesis / growth / healing Increased demand; connective tissue synthesis requires proline and hydroxyproline in large amounts Premature infants / severe illness Endogenous synthesis may be insufficient

No established UL. Proline supplementation in typical doses (1–10 g/day) is considered safe.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Collagen Triple Helix Formation: Collagen Gly-X-Y repeating structure uses proline (Pro) frequently in the X position and hydroxyproline (Hyp) in the Y position. Hydroxylation of Pro → 4-hydroxyproline (by prolyl 4-hydroxylase; requires vitamin C and iron) creates hydrogen bonds that stabilise the three-chain triple helix — without hydroxyproline, collagen unwinds and becomes non-functional (scurvy mechanism).
  • Protein Structure and Folding: The cyclic ring prevents rotation around the N-Cα bond → induces σ-turns, β-turns, poly-proline helices. Prolines break α-helices and redirect polypeptide chain direction → critical in signalling peptides and receptor binding regions.
  • Collagen Post-Translational Processing: Pro is also 3-hydroxylated (by P3H1) in collagen → 3-hydroxyproline; contributes to fibril architecture.
  • Energy Substrate (especially in insects; lesser role in mammals): Proline → glutamate → α-KG → TCA cycle; serves as mobile fuel in flight muscle of insects; in humans provides gluconeogenic substrate during fasting.
  • Antioxidant / Stress Osmolyte: Proline accumulates in plants under osmotic/salt/drought stress and protects macromolecules. In humans, elevated proline levels are found in certain stressed cells; role as osmolyte is minor compared to plants.
  • Skin and Joint Integrity: Hydroxyproline is ~13% of collagen; dietary hydroxyproline (from collagen-rich foods) and proline availability are rate-limiting factors for de novo collagen synthesis in skin, cartilage, tendons, and bone matrix.
  • Glutamate Metabolism: Proline ↔ glutamate interconversion (via P5CS, PYCR, and PRODH enzymes) — connects the urea cycle, TCA cycle, and amino acid metabolism. Proline dehydrogenase (PRODH) in the mitochondria generates ROS (used to signal apoptosis in cancer cells).
  • Gut Microbiome Metabolism: Proline-rich proteins (salivary proteins, collagen) are a substrate for gut bacteria; the microbiome modulates proline availability.

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Synthesis from Glu Glu → Glu-5-semialdehyde (P5CS; ATP + NADPH) → Δ¹-pyrroline-5-carboxylate (P5C) → Proline (PYCR; NADPH) Synthesis from Arg Arg → Ornithine → P5C → Proline (PRODH/P5CR pathway in some tissues) Collagen hydroxylation Pro → 4-hydroxyproline (prolyl 4-hydroxylase; O₂, α-KG, Fe²⁺, ascorbate) Catabolism Pro → P5C (PRODH; mitochondria) → Glu → α-KG → TCA cycle Urea cycle connection Ornithine (from arginine/urea cycle) → P5C → Proline

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Proline (mg) Gelatin / collagen peptide 10g ~2,100–2,800 mg Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~800–1,000 mg Chicken (cooked) 85g ~750–900 mg Bone broth (1 cup) 240 mL ~1,200 mg Egg white 1 large ~190 mg Whole wheat flour 30g ~400 mg Casein protein 30g ~800 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~540 mg

Animal connective tissue (skin, cartilage, tendons) and gelatin are the richest dietary sources. Collagen peptide supplements are primarily glycine + proline + hydroxyproline.

docs.title: Scurvy (Vitamin C Deficiency)
docs.text:
• Vitamin C is the cofactor for prolyl hydroxylase → without ascorbate, proline cannot be hydroxylated → immature collagen chains unfold (lack of hydroxyproline-mediated hydrogen bonds) → structurally weak collagen
  • Results in: perifollicular haemorrhages, gingival disease, poor wound healing, corkscrew hairs, subperiosteal haemorrhages → clinically, this is primarily a proline hydroxylation failure

docs.title: Hyperprolinaemia
docs.text:
• Type I: PRODH deficiency — proline accumulates; associated with schizophrenia (PRODH gene at chromosome 22q11.2 — DiGeorge/velo-cardio-facial syndrome region); 22q11.2 deletion includes PRODH
  • Type II: P5CDH deficiency — P5C and proline accumulate; more severe; intellectual disability, seizures, renal reabsorption defect; elevated plasma + urine proline; P5C accumulates and inactivates pyridoxal phosphate → secondary B6 deficiency

docs.title: Cartilage and Joint Disease
docs.text:
• Hydroxyproline is the most abundant amino acid in cartilage collagen; joint tissue turnover depends on dietary proline availability
  • Collagen peptide supplementation (5–15 g/day) → randomised trials show improvements in knee OA pain and function (WOMAC scores); evidence for athletes re: cartilage regeneration is building

docs.title: DiGeorge Syndrome / 22q11.2 Deletion
docs.text:
• PRODH (proline dehydrogenase) gene deletion → hyperprolinaemia type I
  • PRODH links proline to mitochondrial ROS production and synaptic glutamate → neurodevelopmental effects; possible mechanism for psychiatric features of 22q11.2 deletion syndrome

docs.title: EhlersDanlos Syndrome / Osteogenesis Imperfecta
docs.text:
• Genetic defects in collagen synthesis enzymes (prolyl hydroxylases, collagen chain genes) → structurally weak collagen despite adequate proline
  • Demonstrates that proline availability alone is necessary but not sufficient; enzymatic machinery is equally critical

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect Vitamin C Essential cofactor for prolyl 4-hydroxylase; deficiency → unhydroxylated collagen → unstable triple helix Iron (Fe²⁺) Also a cofactor for prolyl hydroxylase; iron deficiency can impair collagen maturation (independent of Vit C) Glycine Co-dominant in collagen (Gly-Pro-Hyp is the canonical collagen tripeptide) — both must be co-adequate Glutamate / Arginine Upstream precursors of proline — adequate glutamate and arginine availability supports proline synthesis B6 (PLP) Type II hyperprolinaemia — accumulated P5C inactivates PLP → functional B6 deficiency, seizures

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• Collagen peptide supplements (5–15 g/day): Most widely used form; rich in glycine, proline, and hydroxyproline; bioavailable di/tripeptides (Pro-Hyp, Gly-Pro-Hyp) reach blood and joints intact
  • Evidence base: Joint health (OA), skin elasticity (reduces wrinkles modestly), bone mineral density (combined with calcium)
  • L-Proline powder: Available but less studied than collagen peptides; proline in collagen hydrolysate form is better absorbed and targeted than free L-proline
  • Bone broth: Natural source of proline + hydroxyproline + glycine; variable amounts; flavourful but difficult to quantify exact content
  • No documented toxicity at typical supplemental doses; extremely high doses not studied systematically

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Serine is a conditionally essential amino acid with a hydroxymethyl side chain, synthesised de novo primarily from 3-phosphoglycerate (a glycolytic intermediate) via the phosphoserine pathway. It is a metabolic crossroads amino acid: serine is the direct precursor of glycine, cysteine, sphingolipids, phosphatidylserine, D-serine, and it feeds one-carbon units into the folate cycle, nucleotide synthesis, and the methionine cycle. Serine is also the most common site of protein phosphorylation by serine/threonine kinases in cell signalling.

  • Classification: Conditionally essential
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Ser / S
  • Side chain: Hydroxymethyl (–CH₂–OH); polar, uncharged, small — hydroxyl can participate in H-bonding and phosphorylation
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Glucogenic (→ pyruvate)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements
docs.text:
Condition Notes Healthy adults Synthesised endogenously; no established RDA; ~2–3 g/day from typical diet Phosphoserine pathway defects Serine becomes fully essential in these rare inborn errors Neurological conditions / myelination High demand; CNS-specific serine synthesis (PHGDH) is particularly important in astrocytes

No established UL. Supplemental doses up to 10 g/day studied without significant adverse effects in certain conditions.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Glycine Precursor: Serine → Glycine (serine hydroxymethyltransferase; SHMT1/2; PLP, THF) + 5,10-methylene-THF — the primary route of glycine production in the body and a major one-carbon donor to the folate cycle.
  • Cysteine Precursor: Serine + Homocysteine → Cystathionine (CBS; PLP) → Cysteine — serine provides the carbon backbone for cysteine in the transsulphuration pathway.
  • One-Carbon Metabolism / Folate Cycle: The SHMT reaction interconverts Ser ↔ Gly and couples to the folate one-carbon cycle — supplies methylene-THF for thymidylate (dTMP) synthesis and formyl-THF for purine synthesis → links serine to DNA replication and methylation.
  • Sphingolipid Synthesis: Serine + Palmitoyl-CoA → Sphinganine (serine palmitoyltransferase; SPT) — first and rate-limiting step in de novo sphingolipid synthesis. Sphingolipids (sphingomyelin, ceramide, gangliosides) are critical membrane components, especially in myelin, and act as bioactive lipid signalling molecules (ceramide → apoptosis; sphingosine-1-phosphate → survival/migration).
  • Phosphatidylserine (PS) Synthesis: Serine head group is incorporated into phosphatidylserine in the endoplasmic reticulum (by PS synthase 1 and 2) → PS is a major inner-leaflet phospholipid of cell membranes. PS flips to outer leaflet during apoptosis (eat-me signal for phagocytes). Brain PS is abundant — modulates protein kinase C, AKT, and PLC signalling.
  • D-Serine (NMDA Receptor Co-agonist): Serine is racemised to D-serine by serine racemase (SRR) in astrocytes and neurons → D-serine is the principal endogenous co-agonist at the glycine-binding site of NMDA receptors in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus (where it predominates over glycine). D-serine is critical for synaptic plasticity (LTP), learning, and memory.
  • Protein Phosphorylation Site: The hydroxyl of serine is phosphorylated by serine/threonine kinases (PKA, PKC, AKT, mTOR, CDK, CK2, etc.) → phosphoserine is the most abundant form of protein phosphorylation in cells; regulates virtually all cellular signalling processes.
  • Active Site Nucleophile (Serine Proteases): Serine is the catalytic nucleophile in the active-site triad of serine proteases (trypsin, chymotrypsin, elastase, thrombin, plasmin, complement proteases, subtilisins) and serine hydrolases (acetylcholinesterase, lipases) — arguably the most catalytically important amino acid in biology.
  • Gluconeogenesis: Serine → pyruvate (serine dehydratase; PLP) → gluconeogenesis substrate

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details De novo synthesis 3-Phosphoglycerate (glycolysis) → 3-Phosphoserine → Serine (phosphoserine pathway; 3 enzymes: PHGDH, PSAT1, PSPH) Serine ↔ Glycine SHMT1 (cytosolic) + SHMT2 (mitochondrial); PLP + THF cofactors; reversible D-Serine synthesis Serine racemase (SRR) → D-serine (brain-enriched) Catabolism Serine → Pyruvate (serine dehydratase; PLP) → TCA / gluconeogenesis Collagen-linked Serine provides the initiating sugar-attachment site for glycosaminoglycans (O-xylosylation) in proteoglycans

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text: Food Serving Serine (mg) Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~950 mg Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~900 mg Canned tuna 85g ~880 mg Egg 1 large ~370 mg Milk (whole) 240 mL ~340 mg Pumpkin seeds 28g ~340 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~630 mg Soybeans (cooked) 170g ~820 mg

docs.title: Serine Deficiency Syndromes (Phosphoserine Pathway Defects)
docs.text:
• 3-Phosphoglycerate Dehydrogenase (PHGDH) Deficiency: Most common and severe; presents with congenital microcephaly, intractable seizures (infantile onset), profound intellectual disability, peripheral neuropathy
  • Phosphoserine Aminotransferase (PSAT1) Deficiency and Phosphoserine Phosphatase (PSPH) Deficiency: Similar but variable severity
  • Treatment: Oral L-serine supplementation (200–600 mg/kg/day) + glycine — dramatically improves seizure control and neurodevelopmental outcomes if started early; serine is the full therapeutic; one of the best examples of dietary amino acid as effective treatment for a neurological disorder

docs.title: Neu-Laxova Syndrome
docs.text: • Severe lethal form of serine deficiency (PHGDH/PSAT1/PSPH defects) — multiple malformations including ichthyosis, limb abnormalities, brain anomalies; typically lethal perinatally

docs.title: Schizophrenia and D-Serine Hypofunction
docs.text:
• D-serine is the principal NMDA co-agonist in prefrontal cortex → D-serine depletion → NMDA hypofunction → psychosis-like symptoms (consistent with the glutamate hypothesis of schizophrenia)
  • D-serine or L-serine (as D-serine precursor) supplementation trials in schizophrenia have shown improvement in negative and cognitive symptoms
  • Sarcosine (N-methylglycine) inhibits glycine reuptake transporter (GlyT1) → increases glycine/D-serine levels at NMDA receptors → similar rationale

docs.title: Cancer Metabolism (Serine Synthesis Pathway)
docs.text:
• Many cancers overexpress PHGDH (especially triple-negative breast cancer, melanoma, glioma) — divert glycolytic flux → serine synthesis → one-carbon metabolism → nucleotides and NADPH for proliferation and redox defence
  • PHGDH inhibitors and serine restriction are active areas of cancer metabolism research

docs.title: Lipid Disorders (SPT dysfunction)
docs.text:
• Serine palmitoyltransferase (SPT) mutations → hereditary sensory neuropathy type 1 (HSAN1) — toxic 1-deoxy-sphinganine (doxSA) accumulates (due to using alanine instead of serine as substrate for SPT)
  • Oral L-serine supplementation competes with alanine at SPT → reduces doxSA → improves neuropathy in clinical trials

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect Vitamin B6 (PLP) Required for SHMT (Ser↔Gly), serine dehydratase, CBS (Ser + Hcy → cystathionine → cysteine); multiple serine-related enzymes need PLP Folate (THF) SHMT couples Ser→Gly to methylene-THF generation — serine is effectively a one-carbon donor to the folate pool Methionine cycle Serine → Gly → methylene-THF → 5-methyl-THF → methionine synthase → SAM — serine feeds into methylation capacity Glycine Interconvertible via SHMT; combined supplementation (Ser + Gly) is the standard treatment in serine deficiency disorders Palmitoyl-CoA Substrate partner in SPT reaction; dietary palmitate availability modulates ceramide and sphingolipid synthesis from serine D-Amino acid oxidase (DAAO) Degrades D-serine in the cerebellum/brainstem; DAAO inhibitors proposed as adjuncts for NMDA hypofunction conditions

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• L-Serine (200–600 mg/kg/day) for serine deficiency disorders: The most evidence-based use — dramatic improvements in neuropaediatric outcomes; essentially a therapeutic amino acid
  • L-Serine for HSAN1 (1-deoxy-sphingolipid neuropathy): Phase 2 RCT (Fridman et al.) showed reduction in doxSA and stabilisation of neuropathy; FDA Orphan Drug designation
  • D-Serine supplements: Available; studied for schizophrenia and cognitive enhancement — clinical use is investigational; liver/kidney DAAO activity breaks down D-serine
  • Phosphatidylserine (PS) soft gels (100–300 mg/day): Related to serine but specifically the phospholipid form; FDA-qualified health claim for cognitive decline attenuation; cortisol blunting in athletes; some evidence for memory/focus in the elderly — though the PS on labels is soy-derived (plant PS ≠ bovine cortex PS used in older studies)
  • Dietary serine needs are typically met in protein-replete individuals; deficiency most relevant in metabolic disorders and rare genetic conditions

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Threonine is an essential amino acid with a hydroxyl group on its side chain, making it a target for common post-translational modifications. It is one of the three hydroxyl-containing amino acids (alongside serine and tyrosine). Threonine is critical for mucin glycoprotein synthesis (intestinal mucosal barrier), collagen and elastin structure, and serves as a precursor for glycine and succinyl-CoA. It is the second most limiting amino acid in human diets after lysine in plant-protein–based diets.

  • Classification: Essential (9 essential amino acids)
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Thr / T
  • Side chain: β-hydroxy group (–CHOH–CH₃); has two stereocentres; hydroxyl participates in H-bonding, phosphorylation, O-glycosylation
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Both (→ glycine + acetyl-CoA [ketogenic]; → succinyl-CoA [glucogenic])

docs.title: Dietary Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA (mg/kg/day) Approximate daily need Infants 0–6 months ~73 mg/kg/day — Children 1–3 years ~33 mg/kg/day ~730 mg/day Adults 19+ ~15 mg/kg/day ~1,050 mg/day (70 kg adult)

No established UL for threonine from food. IV threonine infusions at very high doses have caused motor dysfunction in animal models.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Mucin & Glycoprotein Synthesis: Threonine is the most abundant amino acid in mucin-core proteins (MUC2, MUC5B, MUC5AC) — its hydroxyl group is the site of O-linked glycan attachment that gives mucins their gel-like properties. Critical for intestinal mucosal barrier integrity and respiratory tract protection.
  • Collagen & Connective Tissue: Threonine is incorporated into collagen and elastin where it contributes hydrogen bonds and β-sheet structures in fibrous proteins.
  • Glycine Precursor: Threonine → glycine (via threonine aldolase) + acetaldehyde; provides ~10–20% of glycine requirements.
  • Immune Function: Threonine depletion impairs T-cell proliferation and immunoglobulin synthesis; first-pass intestinal mucosal uptake is very high (gut uses ~50–70% of dietary threonine before systemic delivery).
  • Central Nervous System: Glycine, derived from threonine, is an inhibitory neurotransmitter; levels of threonine affect CNS inhibitory tone. High threonine intake → increased spinal cord glycine levels (used in clinical trials for spasticity).
  • Post-Translational Modifications:
  • Phosphorylation (by serine/threonine kinases — e.g., PKA, PKC, AKT): Regulates enzyme/protein activity throughout cell signalling
  • O-glycosylation (O-GlcNAcylation): Links cell metabolism (UDP-GlcNAc from glucose) to protein activity; competes with phosphorylation at the same residues
  • Liver Function: Required for synthesis of fibronectin and plasma proteins; moderate deficiency → hepatic steatosis in animal models.

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Absorption Active transport (SLC6A19/B0AT1; SLC1A5/ASCT2) in small intestine First-pass gut utilisation Very high — intestinal epithelium and microbiome consume majority of dietary threonine Catabolism (main) Thr → 2-oxobutyrate → propionyl-CoA → succinyl-CoA (glucogenic) Alternative pathway Thr → glycine + acetaldehyde (threonine aldolase); acetaldehyde → acetyl-CoA (ketogenic) Serine-glycine interplay Shares one-carbon metabolism with serine and glycine in the folate cycle

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text: Food Serving Threonine (mg) Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~1,050 mg Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~1,000 mg Canned tuna 85g ~990 mg Egg 1 large ~295 mg Milk (whole) 240 mL ~360 mg Greek yoghurt 170g ~550 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~610 mg Wheat germ 28g ~310 mg

docs.title: Mucosal Barrier and Gut Health
docs.text:
• Intestinal threonine utilisation is extremely high — up to 70% of absorbed threonine goes to gut epithelium
  • Dietary threonine deficiency → reduced mucin synthesis → impaired mucosal barrier → increased intestinal permeability
  • Relevant in: critical illness, inflammatory bowel disease, neonatal gut development, premature infants

docs.title: Threonine and Spasticity
docs.text:
• Intrathecal glycine has well-established muscle-relaxant / antispastic properties
  • Oral L-threonine (4.5–6 g/day) increases CSF glycine → some studies show modest reduction in spasticity in multiple sclerosis and spinal cord injury patients
  • Evidence is limited; not a first-line treatment

docs.title: Inborn Errors (Rare)
docs.text: • Isolated threonine catabolism defects are extremely rare; propionyl-CoA downstream defects (propionic acidaemia, methylmalonic acidaemia) affect the glucogenic arm of threonine catabolism

docs.title: Protein Quality Assessment
docs.text:
• Threonine is the second most limiting essential amino acid in wheat-based diets (after lysine)
  • The DIAAS (Digestible Indispensable Amino Acid Score) uses threonine as a reference amino acid for food quality comparative scoring

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Factor Effect Glycine Threonine is a dietary precursor of glycine; glycine availability depends partly on threonine intake Folate cycle Glycine interconverts with serine in the folate one-carbon cycle — threonine→glycine feeds into this Intestinal microbiome Gut bacteria utilise threonine as carbon/nitrogen source; large intestinal fermentation produces threonine-derived metabolites Mucin synthesis Adequate threonine is particularly critical in neonates and ICU patients requiring enteral nutrition — commercially formulated feeds account for intestinal extraction

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• Rarely supplemented in isolation in healthy adults
  • Used in clinical research for spasticity (high-dose oral L-Thr to raise CSF glycine) — not standard of care
  • Important in infant formula and neonatal parenteral nutrition design — high gut extraction means formulas need more threonine than systemic requirement models would predict
  • Plant-based diets combining cereals (threonine-limited) with legumes (threonine-adequate) generally meet requirements

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Tryptophan is an essential amino acid with the largest and most structurally complex aromatic side chain of any standard amino acid. It is the sole precursor of serotonin (5-HT), melatonin, and niacin (vitamin B3) in humans. Despite being the least abundant essential amino acid in most dietary proteins, it plays an outsized role in mood regulation, sleep, immune function, and cellular energy metabolism. Its metabolism branches into three major pathways: the kynurenine pathway (~95%), serotonin/melatonin pathway (~1–2%), and direct protein incorporation.

  • Classification: Essential (9 essential amino acids)
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Trp / W
  • Side chain: Indole ring (benzene + pyrrole fused); most hydrophobic and bulky aromatic side chain
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Both (→ acetoacetyl-CoA [ketogenic]; TCA intermediates via kynurenine pathway [glucogenic])

docs.title: Dietary Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA (mg/kg/day) Approximate daily need Infants 0–6 months ~17 mg/kg/day — Children 1–3 years ~12 mg/kg/day ~266 mg/day Adults 19+ ~5 mg/kg/day ~350 mg/day (70 kg adult)

Lowest absolute requirement of the essential amino acids. No established UL from food. Eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome (EMS) in 1989 was linked to a contaminated L-tryptophan batch, not tryptophan itself.

docs.title: Serotonin / Melatonin Pathway (~1–2% of Trp)
docs.text:
• Trp → 5-hydroxytryptophan (5-HTP) (tryptophan hydroxylase; requires BH4, Fe²⁺, O₂) → Serotonin (5-HT) (aromatic L-amino acid decarboxylase; requires B6)
  • Serotonin → N-acetylserotonin → Melatonin (AANAT + ASMT enzymes; in pineal gland, regulated by darkness)
  • Serotonin functions: mood, appetite, gut motility (90% of 5-HT is in enterochromaffin cells), platelet aggregation, vasoconstriction, sexual function, sleep
  • Melatonin: circadian rhythm regulation, antioxidant, immune modulation

docs.title: Kynurenine Pathway (~95% of Trp catabolism)
docs.text:
• Trp → Kynurenine (indoleamine 2,3-dioxygenase, IDO — major; or tryptophan 2,3-dioxygenase, TDO — liver-specific)
  • Kynurenine branches:
  • → Kynurenic acid (KYNA): NMDA receptor antagonist, neuroprotective (B6-dependent)
  • → Quinolinic acid (QUIN): NMDA agonist, excitotoxic, pro-inflammatory; neurotoxic at high levels
  • → Nicotinamide / NAD⁺: ~60 mg Trp → ~1 mg niacin (very inefficient; requires thiamine, B2, B6, iron)
  • → Picolinic acid: Zinc chelator; modulates immune function
  • IDO is upregulated by interferons and inflammation — the body diverts Trp away from serotonin synthesis during infection/inflammation (mechanism of infection-related depression and fatigue)

docs.title: Niacin Synthesis
docs.text:
• Trp is the only endogenous source of niacin — though conversion is inefficient (60:1 ratio by weight)
  • Protein-replete individuals can generate some niacin from Trp; pellagra occurs when both niacin and Trp are deficient (corn- and sorghum-dominant diets)

docs.title: Immune Regulation (IDO-mediated)
docs.text:
• IDO in antigen-presenting cells depletes local Trp → starves T cells → immune tolerance
  • Critical in: tumour immune evasion, maternal tolerance of fetus, transplant tolerance
  • IDO inhibitors are in clinical trials as cancer immunotherapy adjuncts

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Absorption Active transport via LAT1 (SLC7A5) and B0AT1 (SLC6A19); competes with other large neutral amino acids Blood-brain barrier Transported by LAT1 — BCAAs reduce Trp brain uptake (competitive transport) Hydroxylation Tryptophan hydroxylase-1 (TPH1, periphery/gut) and TPH2 (brain) — rate-limiting for serotonin synthesis; requires BH4 Kynurenine pathway IDO (widespread, inducible by IFN-γ) and TDO (liver, inducible by Trp itself and glucocorticoids) Half-life (plasma Trp) Relatively short; ~1–2 hours; plasma Trp is mostly albumin-bound (~80–90%)

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Tryptophan (mg) Turkey (roasted) 85g ~250 mg Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~240 mg Tuna (canned) 85g ~290 mg Milk (whole) 240 mL ~110 mg Greek yoghurt 170g ~115 mg Egg 1 large ~75 mg Pumpkin seeds 28g ~170 mg Tofu (firm) 100g ~130 mg Chocolate (dark, 70%) 28g ~65 mg

The "turkey makes you sleepy" myth — turkey Trp is similar to other meats; the effect is more related to large carbohydrate meals (insulin lowers competing amino acids → relative Trp advantage at BBB).

docs.title: Carcinoid Syndrome
docs.text:
• Neuroendocrine tumours (carcinoid) produce large amounts of serotonin from Trp — up to 70% of Trp is diverted
  • Results in niacin deficiency (pellagra-like) due to Trp diversion away from NAD⁺ synthesis
  • Features: flushing, diarrhoea, bronchospasm, right heart valve disease

docs.title: Depression and the Serotonin Hypothesis
docs.text:
• Tryptophan depletion (acute dietary Trp lowering) causes temporary depressive symptoms in recovered depressed individuals — evidence for the serotonin-Trp-mood link
  • SSRIs work downstream of Trp (block 5-HT reuptake) — Trp availability is the upstream precursor constraint
  • Dietary Trp alone does not reliably improve depression in unselected individuals

docs.title: Pellagra and Niacin
docs.text:
• Classic pellagra from corn-dominant diets (niacin in corn is bound, unavailable; corn is also Trp-poor)
  • Treated with nicotinamide/niacin supplementation
  • Occurs in Hartnup disease (Trp absorption disorder — see below)

docs.title: Hartnup Disease
docs.text:
• Defect in SLC6A19 (B0AT1) — impaired intestinal and renal absorption of neutral amino acids including tryptophan
  • Features: pellagra-like rash (photosensitive), cerebellar ataxia, psychiatric symptoms (intermittent)
  • Treatment: high-protein diet + nicotinamide supplementation

docs.title: IDO and Cancer / Inflammation
docs.text:
• IDO-high tumours deplete local Trp → suppress tumour-infiltrating T cells → immune evasion
  • IDO inhibitors (epacadostat) in clinical trials for cancer immunotherapy; most have failed as monotherapy but combinations continue
  • Chronic inflammation → high IDO → Trp→Kynurenine shift → reduced serotonin, increased QUIN (neurotoxic) — proposed mechanism for depression in inflammatory diseases

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect BCAAs (Leu, Ile, Val) Compete with Trp at LAT1 for BBB entry — high BCAA intake reduces brain serotonin synthesis Carbohydrates Insulin release lowers plasma BCAAs → relatively increases Trp brain ratio → increased 5-HT synthesis (post-meal effect) Vitamin B6 (PLP) Cofactor for 5-HTP → serotonin decarboxylation AND for kynurenine → kynurenic acid (KYAT) pathway Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) Cofactor for tryptophan hydroxylase — deficiency reduces 5-HT synthesis SSRIs Act downstream; patient response may be affected by baseline Trp availability MAOIs Block serotonin degradation (MAO-A); combining with high Trp or 5-HTP risks serotonin syndrome 5-HTP supplements Direct precursor to serotonin; bypasses tryptophan hydroxylase; should not be combined with MAOIs or SSRIs without medical supervision

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• L-Tryptophan (500 mg – 2 g/day): Used for sleep, mild depression, premenstrual dysphoria; limited but positive evidence
  • 5-HTP (50–300 mg/day): More readily crosses BBB and enters serotonin synthesis; better-studied than L-Trp for mood/sleep; don't combine with MAOIs/SSRIs (serotonin syndrome risk)
  • Melatonin: Downstream product of Trp; 0.5–5 mg for sleep onset; shorter-acting than L-Trp supplementation
  • Take Trp or 5-HTP with carbohydrates for best brain uptake (reduces competing amino acids)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Tyrosine is a conditionally essential amino acid — it is synthesised from phenylalanine by phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH), but becomes dietary-essential when phenylalanine intake is insufficient or in phenylketonuria (PKU), where PAH is deficient. Tyrosine is the precursor to the catecholamines (dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine), thyroid hormones (T3, T4), and melanin. Its hydroxyl-containing phenol ring makes it a site of post-translational modifications including phosphorylation by receptor tyrosine kinases.

  • Classification: Conditionally essential (essential in PKU)
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Tyr / Y
  • Side chain: Para-hydroxyphenyl (phenol); weakly acidic hydroxyl (pKa ~10.1); aromatic, partially hydrophobic
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Both (→ fumarate [glucogenic] + acetoacetate [ketogenic])

docs.title: Dietary Requirements
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA (combined Phe + Tyr, mg/kg/day) Adults ~33 mg/kg/day (combined); tyrosine spares ~50% of phenylalanine need PKU patients Tyrosine becomes fully essential; supplemented in all PKU formulas

No established UL for dietary tyrosine. Isolated supplemental tyrosine at high doses (>7 g/day) may cause hyperthymia, anxiety, or headache in sensitive individuals.

docs.title: Catecholamine Synthesis
docs.text:
Tyrosine → L-DOPA (tyrosine hydroxylase; TH; requires BH4, Fe²⁺) → Dopamine (AADC; B6) → Norepinephrine (DBH; vitamin C, copper) → Epinephrine (PNMT; SAM methyl donor)

  • Dopamine: Motor control (basal ganglia), reward/motivation, prolactin inhibition, cognition, mood
  • Norepinephrine: Sympathetic nervous system tone, arousal, attention, fight-or-flight vasoconstriction
  • Epinephrine: Adrenal medulla; systemic stress response, glycogenolysis, lipolysis, cardiac stimulation

docs.title: Thyroid Hormone Synthesis
docs.text:
• Tyrosine residues in thyroglobulin are iodinated (TPO + I⁻) → MIT and DIT → coupled → T4 and T3
  • T4 is converted to active T3 by iodothyronine deiodinases (selenium-dependent)

docs.title: Melanin Synthesis
docs.text:
• Tyr → DOPA → dopaquinone → eumelanin (black-brown) / pheomelanin (red-yellow) via tyrosinase (copper-dependent)
  • Determines skin, hair, and eye pigmentation

docs.title: Protein Post-Translational Modifications
docs.text:
• Tyrosine phosphorylation by receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs — EGFR, VEGFR, INSR, etc.) and non-receptor tyrosine kinases (Src, JAK family) — central to growth factor signalling, insulin signalling, immune receptor activation
  • Tyrosine nitration (by peroxynitrite): oxidative stress marker on proteins
  • Tyrosine sulfation (in Golgi): modifies extracellular proteins and GPCRs

docs.title: Cognitive Performance Under Stress
docs.text: • Catecholamines in the prefrontal cortex (dopamine, NE) are consumed during acute stress → tyrosine replenishment may maintain cognitive performance under cold, noise, or sleep-deprivation stress

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Synthesis from Phe Phe + O₂ + BH4 → Tyr + BH2 (phenylalanine hydroxylase, PAH; liver) Catecholamine pathway Tyr → L-DOPA (TH; BH4) → Dopamine (AADC; B6) → NE (DBH; Vit C, Cu) → Epi (PNMT; SAM) Thyroid pathway Tyr in thyroglobulin → iodinated by TPO → T3/T4 Melanin pathway Tyr → DOPA → dopaquinone → melanin (tyrosinase; Cu) Catabolism Tyr → 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate → homogentisate → maleylacetoacetate → fumarate + acetoacetate

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text: Food Serving Tyrosine (mg) Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~955 mg Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~900 mg Canned tuna 85g ~900 mg Parmesan cheese 28g ~770 mg Egg 1 large ~300 mg Milk (whole) 240 mL ~390 mg Edamame (cooked) 155g ~680 mg Almonds 28g ~215 mg

docs.title: Phenylketonuria (PKU)
docs.text:
• PAH deficiency → Phe accumulates → Tyr is depleted (cannot be made from Phe)
  • PKU patients must supplement tyrosine as part of their Phe-restricted amino acid formula
  • Tyr-deficient PKU → additional catecholamine and melanin deficiency (fair skin/hair, mood/cognitive issues)

docs.title: Alkaptonuria
docs.text:
• Homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase deficiency (downstream tyrosine catabolism)
  • Accumulation of homogentisic acid → ochronosis (connective tissue darkening), arthritis, urine darkens on standing

docs.title: Tyrosinaemia (Types I, II, III)
docs.text:
• Type I (Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase deficiency — FAH): Hepatorenal tyrosinaemia; severe liver disease, renal Fanconi syndrome, neurological crises, hepatocellular carcinoma risk; succinylacetone (marker) inhibits porphyrin synthesis → porphyria-like crises
  • Treatment: Nitisinone (NTBC) — inhibits 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (upstream, prevents accumulation of toxic metabolites) + low Tyr/Phe diet + liver transplant
  • Type II (Tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency): Ocular (corneal crystals), palmoplantar keratoderma, intellectual disability; treatment: low Tyr/Phe diet
  • Type III (HPD deficiency, 4-HPPD): Mild; intermittent ataxia and intellectual disability

docs.title: Parkinson's Disease
docs.text:
• Loss of dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra
  • Treatment: L-DOPA (bypasses tyrosine hydroxylase rate-limiting step; given with carbidopa to prevent peripheral conversion)
  • Tyrosine supplementation does not significantly boost CNS dopamine in established PD (TH is severely depleted)

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Drug Effect BH4 (Tetrahydrobiopterin) Rate-limiting cofactor for tyrosine hydroxylase (catecholamine synthesis) and phenylalanine hydroxylase Vitamin C Required for dopamine β-hydroxylase (NE synthesis); deficiency reduces NE production SAM (Methionine) Methyl donor for PNMT (epinephrine synthesis from NE) Copper DBH (NE synthesis), tyrosinase (melanin) — deficiency reduces NE and melanin Iodine + Selenium Required for thyroid hormone synthesis from tyrosine MAO inhibitors Block catecholamine/tyramine degradation — tyramine (from Tyr) in food can precipitate hypertensive crisis Levodopa (L-DOPA) Competes with tyrosine (and other large neutral amino acids) at LAT1 transporter; protein meals reduce L-DOPA absorption/efficacy Thyroid medications Levothyroxine is a synthetic form of T4 (tyrosine backbone + iodines)

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• L-Tyrosine (500–2,000 mg, 30–60 min pre-stressor): Used for acute cognitive performance under stress (sleep deprivation, cold, noise exposure) — several RCTs show modest benefit; effect is short-lived (acute dosing)
  • NALT (N-Acetyl-L-Tyrosine): More water-soluble but evidence for superior bioavailability is mixed; some studies show lower plasma Tyr conversion than L-Tyr
  • Not effective for: Chronic mood disorders in the absence of catecholamine demand (baseline catecholamine-sufficient individuals); Parkinson's disease (TH enzyme is the absent bottleneck, not substrate)
  • Caution: Avoid high-dose Tyr with MAOIs (tyramine accumulation risk); caution with hyperthyroidism (excess Tyr substrate for T3/T4 synthesis)
  • PKU formula: All PKU amino acid formulas contain added tyrosine as an essential inclusion

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Valine is an essential amino acid and the smallest of the three branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs). It plays multiple roles in muscle protein synthesis, CNS function, and energy metabolism. Unlike leucine (purely ketogenic) and isoleucine (both), valine is exclusively glucogenic — it provides an important glucose-sparing or gluconeogenic contribution during prolonged exercise and fasting. Its catabolism takes place primarily in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and brain.

  • Classification: Essential; Branched-Chain Amino Acid (BCAA)
  • IUPAC abbreviation: Val / V
  • Side chain: Isopropyl (branched aliphatic, hydrophobic)
  • Glucogenic / Ketogenic: Exclusively glucogenic (→ succinyl-CoA via propionyl-CoA)

docs.title: Dietary Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA (mg/kg/day) Approximate daily need Infants 0–6 months ~87 mg/kg/day — Children 1–3 years ~43 mg/kg/day ~950 mg/day Adults 19+ ~24 mg/kg/day ~1,680 mg/day (70 kg adult)

No established UL. Excessive isolated valine supplementation without leucine/isoleucine can disrupt BCAA balance and impair the others' LAT1 transport.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Muscle Protein Synthesis Substrate: Component of muscle structural proteins; contributes to mTORC1 activation alongside leucine (though less potently).
  • Gluconeogenic Substrate: Valine is catabolised to succinyl-CoA, which feeds into the TCA cycle or can exit for gluconeogenesis — important fuel source during prolonged starvation or endurance exercise when muscle proteins are catabolised.
  • Nitrogen Balance: Like all BCAAs, valine is transaminated in muscle (rather than liver) — the released amino group is transferred to pyruvate → alanine → exported to liver for urea synthesis (glucose-alanine cycle).
  • Myelin Synthesis: Propionyl-CoA and succinyl-CoA from valine catabolism contribute to neuronal lipid synthesis; severe MSUD (with valine accumulation) contributes to white matter abnormalities.
  • Haemoglobin Participation: Val6 in the β-globin chain — the canonical target of the sickle cell mutation (Glu→Val substitution creates HbS).
  • CNS Function: Valine competes with tryptophan and other large neutral amino acids at LAT1 for blood-brain barrier entry — high BCAA levels (including valine) reduce serotonin synthesis by limiting Trp brain uptake.

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Absorption LAT1 (SLC7A5) — competitive with leucine, isoleucine, phenylalanine, tyrosine, tryptophan First-pass metabolism Minimal hepatic extraction; preferentially metabolised in skeletal muscle and brain Transamination Val → 2-ketoisovalerate (KIV) by BCAA aminotransferase (BCAT1, BCAT2) — releases NH₂ to α-ketoglutarate → glutamate Oxidative decarboxylation KIV → isobutyryl-CoA (BCKD complex; requires B1, B2, B3, lipoic acid) Glucogenic end products Isobutyryl-CoA → methylmalonyl-CoA → succinyl-CoA → TCA / gluconeogenesis

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text: Food Serving Valine (mg) Beef (lean, cooked) 85g ~1,180 mg Chicken breast (cooked) 85g ~1,080 mg Canned tuna 85g ~1,050 mg Egg 1 large ~380 mg Milk (whole) 240 mL ~500 mg Lentils (cooked) 200g ~870 mg Edamame (cooked) 155g ~810 mg Whey protein isolate 30g ~1,450 mg

docs.title: Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD)
docs.text:
• Deficiency of the BCKD complex — all three BCAAs (leucine, isoleucine, valine) accumulate
  • Valine and isoleucine contribute to general amino acid toxicity and osmotic effects; leucine is considered the primary neurotoxicant
  • Classic presentation: failure to thrive, encephalopathy, alternating hypotonia and hypertonia, maple syrup odour (isovaleric acid)
  • Management: BCAA-restricted diet using synthetic formula; leucine-lowered specifically; liver transplant (curative)

docs.title: Sickle Cell Disease
docs.text: • Val6 in β-globin (Glu6Val mutation) — substituting a charged residue (glutamate) with hydrophobic valine creates a hydrophobic patch that promotes HbS polymerisation under low O₂ → sickling of erythrocytes

docs.title: Methylmalonic Acidaemia (MMA)
docs.text:
• Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase deficiency (or B12 deficiency of adenosylcobalamin form) → methylmalonyl-CoA accumulates → methylmalonic acid in blood/urine
  • Valine, isoleucine, methionine, threonine all contribute propionyl-CoA → methylmalonyl-CoA (this pathway is affected)
  • Treatment: protein restriction, high-carbohydrate diet, B12 supplementation (if responsive), organ transplant

docs.title: Propionic Acidaemia
docs.text:
• Propionyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency → propionyl-CoA accumulates (from valine, isoleucine, methionine, threonine, odd-chain fatty acids)
  • Hyperammonaemia, metabolic acidosis, cardiomyopathy
  • Treatment: low-protein diet, biotin supplementation (cofactor), liver/heart-liver transplant

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Factor Effect Leucine + Isoleucine Compete at LAT1 transporter; must be balanced in supplements (2:1:1 Leu:Ile:Val) B vitamins (B1, B2, B3, lipoic acid) Cofactors for the BCKD complex — valine catabolism depends on adequate B-vitamin status B12 (adenosylcobalamin) Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase requires adenosylcobalamin — B12 deficiency → methylmalonic acid accumulation from valine catabolism Tryptophan High valine (and BCAA) intakes reduce tryptophan CNS uptake via LAT1 competition → reduced serotonin synthesis Insulin Insulin drives BCAA uptake into muscle and suppresses catabolism — promotes protein anabolism

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• Sold as part of BCAA supplements (2:1:1 Leu:Ile:Val ratio); rarely supplemented in isolation
  • Isolated valine supplementation disrupts leucine/isoleucine balance and is not recommended
  • BCAA supplements show modest evidence for:
  • Reducing exercise-induced muscle damage and soreness (DOMS)
  • Preserving lean mass during caloric restriction
  • Reducing hepatic encephalopathy symptoms (high BCAA:aromatic amino acid ratio — Fischer ratio — used in hepatic encephalopathy nutrition protocols)
  • Adequate dietary protein (≥1.6 g/kg/day) from quality sources makes BCAA supplements unnecessary for most people

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Beta-carotene is the most well-known provitamin A carotenoid — upon absorption, it can be cleaved by intestinal beta-carotene 15,15'-monooxygenase (BCMO1) into two molecules of retinal (vitamin A aldehyde), making it the most abundant dietary source of preformed-equivalent vitamin A globally, particularly in plant-based diets. It is an orange-yellow pigment synthesised by plants, algae, and fungi but not by animals; its characteristic colour reflects 9 conjugated double bonds that can absorb blue-violet light (~450 nm). Beyond its provitamin A role, beta-carotene functions as a membrane antioxidant and lipid-soluble free radical scavenger at normal physiological concentrations. However, two landmark clinical trials (ATBC and CARET) found that high-dose beta-carotene supplementation significantly increased lung cancer risk in smokers — a sobering example of how a nutrient's safety profile in food differs radically from pharmacological supplementation.

  • Classification: Carotenoid; provitamin A (most potent dietary provitamin A); symmetric bicyclic carotene
  • Structure: 40-carbon symmetric carotene; two β-ionone rings connected by a polyene chain; 9 conjugated double bonds (responsible for orange colour)
  • Key property: 1 molecule β-carotene → theoretical maximum 2 molecules retinal (vitamin A); actual yield varies by conversion efficiency, food matrix, individual genetics (BCMO1 polymorphisms)
  • Vitamin A equivalence: 12 µg dietary β-carotene from food = 1 µg retinol activity equivalent (RAE) [WHO]; 6 µg = 1 RAE for supplements

docs.title: Provitamin A Conversion
docs.text:
Step Enzyme Details Intestinal cleavage BCMO1 (beta-carotene monooxygenase 1; symmetric cleavage) β-Carotene → 2× retinal (centric cleavage at 15,15' double bond); reaction requires O₂, FAD, Fe²⁺ Reduction Retinal reductase Retinal → retinol (vitamin A alcohol) in enterocytes Esterification LRAT (lecithin:retinol acyltransferase) Retinol → retinyl esters → incorporated into chylomicrons Hepatic storage Hepatic stellate cells (Ito cells) Retinyl esters stored as fat droplets; ~80–90% of body retinol stored in liver Eccentric cleavage BCMO2 (beta-carotene oxygenase 2) Alternative asymmetric cleavage → β-apo-carotenals (smaller fragments with antioxidant activity)

BCMO1 genetic polymorphisms: ~45% of women are poor converters due to common BCMO1 variants (R267S, A379V) → significantly lower vitamin A yield from plant foods → these individuals depend more on preformed vitamin A (liver, dairy, eggs); a concern for vegans with these polymorphisms.

docs.title: Provitamin A Activity
docs.text:
• Provides vitamin A for all retinol-dependent functions: rhodopsin synthesis (night vision), retinoic acid signalling (cell differentiation, immune function, embryogenesis), mucosal integrity, immune competence
  • In developing countries where preformed vitamin A is scarce (no liver, eggs, or dairy), beta-carotene from orange/yellow fruits and vegetables is the primary vitamin A source

docs.title: Antioxidant Activity
docs.text:
• At physiological concentrations (pO₂ <150 mmHg), beta-carotene is an effective singlet oxygen quencher and lipid peroxyl radical chain-breaking antioxidant in cell membranes
  • pO₂-dependent behaviour: At high partial oxygen pressures (e.g., in lung tissue of smokers with supplemental oxygen or high-dose supplementation), beta-carotene can become a pro-oxidant rather than antioxidant — generating peroxyl radicals; this is the mechanistic explanation for the ATBC/CARET findings

docs.title: Immune Function (via Vitamin A)
docs.text:
• Vitamin A derived from beta-carotene supports:
  • Mucosal barrier integrity (respiratory, GI)
  • T-cell and B-cell differentiation
  • NK cell and neutrophil function
  • IgA production at mucosal surfaces

docs.title: Metabolism and Bioavailability
docs.text: Factor Effect Food matrix Dense chromoplast packaging in carrots and pumpkin significantly reduces bioaccessibility; cooking (particularly with fat) disrupts chromoplasts and increases bioavailability 5–6× Dietary fat Required for micellar solubilisation and absorption; eating cooked carrots with butter/olive oil dramatically increases beta-carotene absorption Food processing Juicing > blending > cooking > raw (for most vegetables); fine particle size aids release from cellular structures Absorption Passive diffusion via SR-BI and CD36; incorporated into chylomicrons as either intact beta-carotene or retinyl esters Regulatory absorption Unlike preformed vitamin A (which can accumulate toxically), beta-carotene absorption decreases at high intake — downregulation of SR-BI and upregulation of BCMO1 limits accumulation (safety mechanism that breaks down with very high-dose supplementation) Genetic variation (BCMO1) Poor converters absorb intact beta-carotene well but convert less to retinol; higher serum beta-carotene but lower vitamin A yield Intestinal conversion efficiency Highly variable: 3–28% of absorbed beta-carotene converted to retinol depending on vitamin A status, genetics, food matrix

docs.title: Dietary Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Beta-carotene (mg) RAE (µg) Sweet potato (baked, flesh) 1 medium (114 g) 9.4 mg ~781 µg RAE Carrot (raw) 1 medium (61 g) 5.1 mg ~427 µg RAE Carrot juice 240 mL 22 mg ~1,830 µg RAE Pumpkin (canned) ½ cup (123 g) 8.5 mg ~708 µg RAE Butternut squash (cooked) 1 cup (205 g) 9.4 mg ~781 µg RAE Spinach (cooked) 1 cup (180 g) 8.7 mg ~730 µg RAE Kale (cooked) 1 cup (130 g) 5.3 mg ~440 µg RAE Cantaloupe melon 1 cup (160 g) 2.6 mg ~216 µg RAE Red sweet pepper (raw) 1 medium (119 g) 2.1 mg ~175 µg RAE Apricots (raw) 3 medium 1.1 mg ~92 µg RAE

RAE estimates assume 12 µg dietary β-carotene = 1 µg RAE (WHO/IOM), which is conservative; cooked vegetables with fat are approximately twice as efficient (~6 µg = 1 RAE per some guidelines).

docs.title: Vitamin A Deficiency (Global Burden)
docs.text:
• Vitamin A deficiency (VAD) affects ~190 million preschool children and 19 million pregnant women globally, primarily in sub-Saharan Africa and South/Southeast Asia
  • Night blindness: The earliest clinical sign of VAD; reversible with adequate beta-carotene or retinol
  • Xerophthalmia and corneal blindness: Advanced VAD; irreversible; leading cause of preventable childhood blindness
  • Biofortification: Golden Rice (transgenic rice expressing β-carotene in the endosperm) and biofortified orange sweet potato are strategies to increase beta-carotene delivery in VAD-endemic regions

docs.title: The ATBC and CARET Trials — Landmark Cautionary Findings
docs.text:
[!CAUTION] ATBC trial (1994): 29,133 male Finnish smokers; beta-carotene 20 mg/day for 5–8 years → 18% increased lung cancer incidence, 8% increased overall mortality vs placebo. CARET trial (1996): 18,314 smokers/asbestos workers; 30 mg beta-carotene + 25,000 IU retinyl palmitate → 28% increased lung cancer incidence, 17% increased overall mortality → trial stopped early. Neither supplement group showed benefit in any subgroup.

  • Mechanism (proposed): In the oxidant-rich lung environment of smokers, pharmacological beta-carotene generates reactive beta-carotene radicals → propagate lipid peroxidation → carcinogenic arachidonic acid derivatives; also interferes with RA (retinoic acid) signalling → loss of tumour suppression
  • Key lesson: Food-form beta-carotene is safe (associated with lower cancer risk in observational studies); isolated high-dose supplement beta-carotene is harmful in smokers and possibly in heavy exercisers (similar mechanism)

docs.title: Beta-Carotene vs. Lutein/Zeaxanthin in AMD
docs.text: • AREDS1 formula contained 15 mg beta-carotene; AREDS2 replaced it with 10 mg lutein + 2 mg zeaxanthin: non-inferior for AMD protection, superior in smokers (beta-carotene concerns), and no competitive absorption issues for macular carotenoids

docs.title: Carotenodermia (Hypercarotenaemia)
docs.text: • Harmless orange-yellow discolouration of the skin (palms, soles, nasolabial folds) from very high dietary beta-carotene intake (>30 mg beta-carotene/day from food, e.g., carrot juice drinkers); reversible on reducing intake; does not cause hypervitaminosis A (unlike retinol supplementation)

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Factor Interaction Vitamin A (retinol) status When vitamin A stores are replete, BCMO1 activity decreases → less beta-carotene converted → more passes as intact carotenoid; when deficient, conversion upregulated Dietary fat Required for absorption; critical importance to consume with fat-containing foods Lutein and zeaxanthin Compete for intestinal absorption via shared SR-BI transporter; high-dose beta-carotene supplements reduce plasma lutein/zeaxanthin levels Iron and zinc Deficiencies impair beta-carotene conversion to retinol (iron: required by BCMO1; zinc: required for retinol mobilisation from liver via RBP) Vitamin E Both are fat-soluble antioxidants in membranes; synergistic antioxidant protection at physiological concentrations Alcohol Impairs retinol mobilisation from liver; combined with beta-carotene supplements, alcohol increases hepatotoxicity risk Orlistat (fat absorption blocker) Significantly reduces absorption of all fat-soluble nutrients including beta-carotene; patients on orlistat need vitamin A monitoring Smoking In smokers, beta-carotene supplementation is contraindicated; dietary beta-carotene from food remains safe; smoking directly depletes plasma carotenoids

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• From food: safe and beneficial — high dietary beta-carotene from fruits and vegetables is consistently associated with lower cancer and CVD risk in epidemiological studies
  • Supplemental beta-carotene:
  • Contraindicated in smokers and asbestos-exposed individuals (ATBC/CARET evidence)
  • Not recommended as an isolated supplement for general population (WCRF, WHO, ACS)
  • Still present in some multivitamins — smokers should choose vitamin A as retinyl palmitate instead
  • For vitamin A supplementation: Preformed retinyl palmitate (IU-dosed) is safer and more reliable than beta-carotene for people with BCMO1 polymorphisms, malabsorption, or significant VAD
  • Natural mixed carotenoids (from algae: Dunaliella salina — contains alpha-carotene, beta-carotene, lutein, zeaxanthin together): may be safer than pure synthetic beta-carotene due to the antioxidant buffering of the other carotenoids; not definitively proven
  • Note for vegans: Those following strict vegan diets should assess beta-carotene intake and, if BCMO1 poor-converter status is suspected (genetic testing available), consider preformed vitamin A from supplements or fortified foods

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Coenzyme Q10 (CoQ10), also known as ubiquinone (from ubiquitous quinone), is a fat-soluble, vitamin-like compound found in every cell in the human body, with the highest concentrations in mitochondria-rich organs: heart, liver, kidney, and skeletal muscle. It is endogenously synthesised via the mevalonate pathway (shared with cholesterol synthesis), making it non-essential in healthy individuals. CoQ10 serves two fundamental roles: as a mobile electron carrier in the mitochondrial electron transport chain (ETC), and as the only endogenous lipid-soluble antioxidant generated by the body itself — protecting cell membranes and mitochondrial membranes from lipid peroxidation.

  • Type: Fat-soluble quinone; endogenously synthesised; found in all cells
  • Redox forms: Ubiquinone (CoQ; fully oxidised), Ubisemiquinone (CoQ•; radical intermediate), Ubiquinol (CoQH₂; fully reduced, antioxidant form)
  • Structure: Benzoquinone ring + isoprenoid side chain (10 isoprene units in humans; coenzyme Q10)
  • Key fact: Biosynthesis uses the same mevalonate pathway as cholesterol; statins inhibit HMG-CoA reductase → reduce both cholesterol AND CoQ10 synthesis

docs.title: Biosynthesis
docs.text:
Stage Key Enzyme / Pathway Details Mevalonate pathway HMG-CoA reductase (HMGCR) — rate-limiting Acetyl-CoA → mevalonate → IPP → farnesyl-PP → (shared with cholesterol synthesis) → decaprenyl-PP (10-unit tail of CoQ10) Quinone ring synthesis Tyrosine → 4-hydroxybenzoate (via PAH/ADCK3 pathway) Provides the benzoquinone ring head group Assembly COQ complex (COQ3–COQ9 enzymes) Assembly of head group + tail → CoQ10 in the inner mitochondrial membrane

Statin effect: Statins inhibit HMGCR → reduce synthesis of both mevalonate-derived cholesterol AND the isoprenoid tail of CoQ10. CoQ10 plasma levels fall 16–54% with intensive statin therapy. This biochemical fact is mechanistically plausible as a contribution to statin-associated muscle symptoms (SAMS), though clinical evidence remains debated.

docs.title: Electron Transport Chain (Primary Role)
docs.text:
• CoQ10 is the mobile hydrophobic electron shuttle between Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) and Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the inner mitochondrial membrane
  • Complex I → CoQ10 (ubiquinone + 2e⁻ + 2H⁺ → ubiquinol); Complex III → accepts electrons from ubiquinol → regenerates ubiquinone
  • Net: CoQ10 cycling in ETC is essential for ~95% of cellular ATP through oxidative phosphorylation

docs.title: Antioxidant Functions
docs.text:
• Ubiquinol (CoQH₂) is the most potent known lipid-soluble antioxidant in biological membranes
  • Directly quenches superoxide, lipid peroxyl radicals, peroxynitrite in the mitochondrial and cell membranes
  • Regenerates vitamin E (tocopheryl radical → α-tocopherol) by donating electrons — CoQ10 is upstream of vitamin E in the membrane antioxidant hierarchy
  • Prevents oxidative modification of LDL cholesterol (CoQ10-enriched LDL is more resistant to oxidation)

docs.title: Other Functions
docs.text:
• NF-κB inhibition: Ubiquinol downregulates NF-κB-mediated inflammatory gene expression (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β) at the transcriptional level
  • Membrane integrity: Maintains mitochondrial membrane potential (ΔΨm); CoQ10 interacts with uncoupling proteins (UCPs) to regulate proton leak
  • Sulphide oxidation: CoQ10 is the electron acceptor for sulphide:quinone oxidoreductase (SQR) — the enzyme that detoxifies hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) in mitochondria; relevant in gut bacterially-producing H₂S environments

docs.title: Metabolism and Bioavailability
docs.text: Aspect Details Endogenous synthesis Produced in liver and other tissues via mevalonate pathway; peak production at age ~20, declines ~0.5%/year thereafter Dietary absorption Absorbed in the small intestine with dietary fat; incorporated into chylomicrons → lymph → plasma; fat-containing meals significantly improve CoQ10 absorption Plasma transport Primarily carried in LDL and HDL; oxidised to ubiquinol in plasma; plasma CoQ10 correlates with LDL particle number (not independent) Tissue distribution Heart >> liver >> kidney >> skeletal muscle >> brain > lung > plasma; cardiac CoQ10 declines significantly in heart failure Bioavailability of supplements Standard crystal form: poor (hydrophobic, poor dissolution); solubilised/soft-gel formulations (ubiquinol or solubilised ubiquinone) achieve 3–4× higher plasma levels vs crystal powder Half-life in plasma ~33 hours; steady state achieved after ~3–4 weeks of supplementation

docs.title: Dietary Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving CoQ10 Content (mg) Beef heart 100 g 11.3 mg Beef (lean) 100 g 3.1 mg Pork 100 g 2.4 mg Chicken (leg) 100 g 1.6 mg Sardines (tinned) 100 g 2.7 mg Salmon (cooked) 100 g 0.9 mg Soybean oil 1 tbsp 1.0 mg Sesame seeds 28 g 0.7 mg Broccoli 100 g 0.6 mg Cauliflower 100 g 0.6 mg

Dietary CoQ10 intake from typical Western diets is ~3–5 mg/day — far below therapeutic supplemental doses. Cooking destroys some CoQ10 (heat-labile). Heart and organ meats are richest sources.

docs.title: Heart Failure
docs.text:
• Cardiac CoQ10 levels are inversely correlated with severity of heart failure (NYHA class)
  • Q-SYMBIO trial (2014; n=420): CoQ10 300 mg/day for 2 years in heart failure → 43% reduction in major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE), reduced all-cause mortality vs placebo — landmark trial, though awaiting replication at scale
  • Proposed mechanism: improves mitochondrial ATP production in the energy-starved failing heart, reduces oxidative stress, improves endothelial function

docs.title: Statin-Associated Muscle Symptoms (SAMS)
docs.text:
• 5–10% of statin users experience myalgia; severe rhabdomyolysis rare but serious; statin-induced CoQ10 depletion is a proposed (but not confirmed) mechanism
