  • Omega-3 supplementation reduces hepatic fat content in NAFLD (multiple RCTs) but does not consistently improve fibrosis scores.

docs.title: Gallstone Disease
docs.text:
• Very low-fat diets paradoxically increase gallstone risk — gallbladder requires fat stimulation (via CCK) to contract and empty; stasis → cholesterol gallstone formation.
  • Moderate fat intake (especially MUFA) stimulates adequate gallbladder motility.

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Factor Effect Fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) Dietary fat required for micelle formation and absorption; inadequate dietary fat → deficiencies even with adequate vitamin intake; fat-rich meals improve vitamin D absorption 2-fold Omega-6:Omega-3 ratio Western diet ratio ~15–20:1 (excess n-6); optimal estimated at 4:1 or below for anti-inflammatory balance; excess n-6 competes with n-3 for Δ6-desaturase and membrane incorporation Bile acids Bile (from cholesterol) essential for fat digestion; enterohepatic recycling; dietary fibre binds bile acids → excretion → increased LDL-receptor expression (LDL-C lowering) Carbohydrates (refined) Replacing dietary fat with refined carbohydrate raises TG, lowers HDL-C, raises small dense LDL particles — net adverse effect on lipid profile despite lowering total LDL-C Vitamin E Tocopherols protect PUFAs from oxidation in membranes and food; high PUFA diets increase vitamin E requirement; sunflower, safflower oils (high LA) naturally contain α-tocopherol Carnitine Transports long-chain FA across inner mitochondrial membrane for β-oxidation; carnitine deficiency impairs fat oxidation (clinical carnitine deficiency is rare, primarily in haemodialysis patients) Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) Insulin activates LPL → clears TG from circulation; LPL activity is reduced in insulin resistance → hypertriglyceridaemia; omega-3 FA and fibrates increase LPL activity Cholesterol absorption (dietary) Dietary cholesterol has modest effect on blood cholesterol in most people (hyperresponders: ~25% of population); phytosterols (plant sterols) competitively inhibit cholesterol absorption → lower LDL-C by 8–10% at 2 g/day

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• Fish oil (EPA+DHA): Most evidence-based omega-3 supplement; 1–4 g EPA+DHA/day; reduces TG; reduces CVD risk in high-risk patients; prescription-grade icosapentaenoic acid (Vascepa) at 4 g/day has RCT evidence for MACE reduction; common side effect: fishy burps (mitigated by enteric-coated formulas, taking with meals, freezing capsules)
  • Algal oil (DHA): Vegan alternative, derived from the marine algae that fish consume; provides preformed DHA (~250–500 mg/serve); less EPA than fish oil; appropriate for vegans/vegetarians
  • MCT oil (medium-chain triglycerides): C8 (caprylic) and C10 (capric) glycerides; rapidly absorbed via portal vein, do not require carnitine for mitochondrial entry; used in ketogenic diets and as an easily digested fat for malabsorption; C8 most ketogenic; GI intolerance at doses >30 g/day when titrated rapidly
  • Conjugated linoleic acid (CLA): Ruminant-derived TFA (natural); modestly reduces body fat in RCTs (~0.09 kg/week at 3.2 g/day vs placebo — small but consistent); found naturally in dairy and beef
  • Phytosterol/stanol supplements: 2 g/day reduces LDL-C by 8–10%; available in fortified margarines, capsules; most effective when taken with fat-containing meals; do not use in phytosterolaemia (rare genetic condition) or in children except under medical supervision
  • Krill oil: Contains EPA+DHA in phospholipid form (potentially better bioavailability vs ethyl ester fish oil); also contains astaxanthin (antioxidant carotenoid); smaller capsule; higher cost per gram EPA+DHA vs fish oil

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Proteins are the most structurally diverse macronutrient, serving as the building blocks for virtually every functional and structural component in the body — from enzymes and hormones to immune antibodies and contractile muscle fibres. They are polymers of amino acids linked by peptide bonds, providing 4 kcal/gram. Unlike carbohydrates and fats, the body has no dedicated protein storage depot — "stored" protein exists functionally (as muscle, organ tissue, enzymes), making adequate daily intake essential. Dietary protein quality depends on both amino acid composition (completeness) and digestibility.

  • Classification: Macronutrient; 4 kcal/g
  • Building blocks: 20 standard amino acids (9 essential, 7 conditionally essential, 4 non-essential)
  • Key roles: Structural (collagen, actin, myosin), catalytic (enzymes), regulatory (hormones, receptors), immune (antibodies, complement), transport (haemoglobin, albumin), signalling (growth factors, cytokines)
  • Nitrogen balance: Unique among macronutrients in containing nitrogen (~16% by mass); nitrogen balance is the index of protein adequacy

docs.title: Complete vs Incomplete Proteins
docs.text:
Category Definition Examples Complete protein Provides all 9 essential amino acids in sufficient amounts relative to needs Eggs, meat, poultry, fish, dairy, soy, quinoa, buckwheat Incomplete protein Low in one or more essential amino acids (limiting amino acid) Most plant proteins: wheat (low Lys), rice (low Lys), legumes (low Met/Cys), corn (low Lys, Trp) Complementary proteins Two or more incomplete proteins that together supply all EAAs Rice + legumes (classic combination); wheat + dairy

The concept of "protein combining at every meal" is outdated — the body maintains an amino acid pool; complementary proteins consumed within the same day are sufficient. However, whole-day adequacy of all EAAs matters.

docs.title: Protein Quality Metrics
docs.text:
Metric Description Strengths / Weaknesses DIAAS (Digestible Indispensable Amino Acid Score) Score for each EAA: (digestible dietary AA / reference AA pattern) × 100; uses ileal digestibility Current gold standard (WHO 2013); accounts for intestinal bacterial use of AA PDCAAS (Protein Digestibility-Corrected Amino Acid Score) Older version; uses faecal digestibility, scores capped at 1.0 Can overestimate plant protein quality; being replaced by DIAAS BV (Biological Value) Proportion of absorbed nitrogen retained by the body Measures utilisation, not digestibility; rarely used clinically now

High DIAAS foods (>100% = exceeds reference): Eggs (~113), whey protein (~109), whole milk (~114), beef (~111) Moderate DIAAS: Soy protein isolate (~98), pea protein (~75–82) Lower DIAAS: Wheat (~40–45), rice (~59), most plant proteins

docs.title: Dietary Requirements
docs.text: Population Protein Requirement Adults (sedentary) 0.8 g/kg/day (RDA; minimum to prevent deficiency in 97.5% of population) AMDR 10–35% of total energy intake Older adults (>65 years) 1.0–1.2 g/kg/day (PROT-AGE recommendation); anabolic resistance requires higher EAA to stimulate MPS Resistance training athletes 1.6–2.2 g/kg/day for muscle accretion (meta-analytic ceiling ~1.62 g/kg/day for MPS; higher intakes during caloric restriction may prevent muscle loss) Endurance athletes 1.2–1.6 g/kg/day Pregnancy Add ~25 g/day above baseline (RDA ~1.1 g/kg/day) Lactation Add ~25 g/day above baseline Critical illness / trauma 1.2–2.0 g/kg/day (ASPEN/SCCM guidelines)

docs.title: Metabolism
docs.text: Step Details Digestion — stomach Pepsinogen → pepsin (HCl activation); pepsin cleaves Phe, Tyr, Trp peptide bonds → polypeptides; denatures proteins (exposing peptide bonds) Digestion — small intestine Pancreatic proteases: trypsin, chymotrypsin, elastase (endopeptidases); carboxypeptidases A and B (exopeptidases); brush-border peptidases → di/tripeptides and free AAs Absorption Free AAs: specific transporters (e.g., EAAT for acidic, CAT-1 for basic, SNAT for neutral AAs); Di/tripeptides: PepT1 cotransporter (H⁺-dependent) — more efficient than free AA uptake Amino acid pool Absorbed AAs → portal vein → liver → distributed to systemic AA pool; liver extracts ~60% of first-pass AAs for hepatic protein synthesis Muscle protein synthesis (MPS) Leucine is the primary anabolic signal → activates mTORC1 → phosphorylates S6K1 and 4E-BP1 → increased ribosomal translation of muscle proteins; ~3 g leucine per meal is the threshold dose Muscle protein breakdown (MPB) Ubiquitin-proteasome system (main); autophagy-lysosome pathway; regulated by insulin (suppresses MPB), IGF-1, testosterone, cortisol (promotes MPB during stress/fasting) Transamination Excess AAs: amino group transferred to α-keto acids (via ALT, AST); produces glutamate + new α-keto acid; carbon skeletons enter glycolysis or TCA Urea cycle Ammonia (toxic) → carbamoyl phosphate → citrulline → argininosuccinate → arginine → urea; urea excreted renally; requires adequate hydration Glucogenic vs ketogenic Glucogenic AAs (Ala, Gln, Asp, Pro, etc.): carbon skeletons → glucose precursors; Ketogenic AAs (Leu, Lys): → acetyl-CoA/acetoacetate → ketone bodies; Both (Phe, Tyr, Trp, Ile): yield both

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text: Food Serving Protein (g) DIAAS / Notes Chicken breast (cooked) 100 g 31 ~110; complete, high leucine Eggs (whole) 2 large 13 ~113; reference standard protein Greek yoghurt (plain, full-fat) 200 g 17 ~114 (milk-based); high in casein Whey protein (powder) 30 g 24–25 ~109; fast-digesting; ideal post-exercise Tuna (canned in water) 100 g 26 ~120; high BV, complete Salmon (cooked) 100 g 25 Complete; EPA/DHA bonus Tofu (firm) 100 g 8 ~79 (soy); complete but lower digestibility Lentils (cooked) 200 g 18 Low Met; incomplete; high fibre Quinoa (cooked) 185 g 8 ~76; complete plant protein; all EAAs Black beans (cooked) 1 cup (172 g) 15 Low Met; pair with grains Pea protein (powder) 30 g 21 ~75–82; low Met; better than older estimates

docs.title: Sarcopenia and Ageing
docs.text:
• Muscle mass peaks in the 3rd decade; loss accelerates after age 60 at ~1–2%/year. Anabolic resistance in older adults means more protein (and especially leucine) is needed per meal to achieve the same MPS response as younger adults.
  • Leucine threshold rises in ageing — 0.4 g leucine per kg (vs ~0.24 g/kg in young adults) to maximally stimulate MPS.
  • Practical threshold: 30–40 g high-quality protein per meal in older adults; 3–4 meals/day; combined with resistance exercise.

docs.title: Protein and Bone Health
docs.text:
• The "acid-ash hypothesis" (protein acidifies urine and leaches calcium from bones) is largely refuted. Higher protein intakes are protective of bone density, particularly in older adults (reduces risk of hip fracture).
  • IGF-1 (stimulated by dietary protein) promotes osteoblast activity; calcium absorption from the gut is enhanced by protein.

docs.title: Kidney Disease
docs.text:
• In established CKD (eGFR <30 mL/min without dialysis), protein restriction (0.6–0.8 g/kg/day) may slow progression by reducing urea load and glomerular hyperfiltration. Dietitian-supervised management required.
  • In dialysis patients, protein requirements increase to 1.2–1.4 g/kg/day to compensate for dialysate losses.
  • High protein intake does not cause CKD in healthy individuals with normal kidneys — epidemiological and RCT evidence does not support this concern in the absence of existing renal disease.

docs.title: Weight Management
docs.text:
• Protein has the highest thermic effect of food (TEF): 20–30% of ingested protein energy is expended in digestion, absorption, and metabolism (vs ~5–10% for CHO, ~0–3% for fat).
  • Protein is the most satiating macronutrient per calorie — increases GLP-1, PYY, CCK secretion; suppresses ghrelin.
  • High-protein hypocaloric diets preferentially preserve lean mass during weight loss.

docs.title: Phenylketonuria (PKU)
docs.text:
• Autosomal recessive deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) → phenylalanine accumulates → neurotoxicity (intellectual disability, seizures).
  • Management: lifelong low-phenylalanine diet + tyrosine supplementation (becomes essential); sapropterin (BH4 cofactor) for BH4-responsive PKU.

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Nutrient / Factor Effect Leucine Primary trigger of mTORC1-mediated MPS; 2.5–3 g leucine per meal recommended to maximise MPS (present in ~30 g whey or ~3 eggs) Carbohydrates (post-exercise) CHO + protein together post-exercise: CHO raises insulin (suppresses MPB) while protein supplies AAs (raises MPS); combined > either alone for net protein balance in initial recovery Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) Cofactor for all aminotransferases (transamination) and amino acid decarboxylases; B6 requirement scales with protein intake (~0.016 mg per gram protein) Iron Animal protein enhances non-haem iron absorption (the "meat factor" / flesh factor); haem iron in meat is absorbed via separate pathway (HCP-1) independently of pH Zinc Phytate in plant proteins chelates zinc → lower bioavailability from plant sources; animal protein increases zinc absorption; protein intake correlates with zinc status Calcium Protein increases urinary calcium excretion (hypercalciuria) — historically misinterpreted as bone loss; net effect on bone is neutral to positive (protein raises IGF-1 and intestinal calcium absorption) Insulin / IGF-1 Protein (especially BCAAs, Arg) stimulates insulin secretion; dietary protein correlates with IGF-1 — IGF-1 mediates anabolic effects on muscle and bone Kidney function (CKD) In CKD, restrict protein to reduce urea/creatinine load and slow progression; in dialysis, increase protein to compensate for losses

docs.title: Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• Whey protein: Derived from milk (cheese-making byproduct); fast-digesting (~90 min to peak plasma AA); highest DIAAS food protein; ideal post-exercise; ~24 g protein/30 g serve; contains β-lactoglobulin (high leucine), α-lactalbumin, lactoferrin
  • Casein protein: Slow-digesting (clots in stomach → sustained AA release over 5–7 h); ideal pre-sleep protein (40 g casein pre-sleep increases overnight MPS in RCTs); lower leucine/g vs whey
  • Soy protein isolate: Closest plant protein to animal protein in quality (DIAAS ~98); complete AA profile; contains isoflavones (weak oestrogen-like activity — not a clinical concern at food amounts)
  • Pea protein: Popular vegan alternative; DIAAS ~75–82; low in Met/Cys; usually combined with rice protein to complete the AA profile; well tolerated
  • Creatine (related): Not a protein supplement but supports protein synthesis indirectly by enhancing phosphocreatine resynthesis → more training volume → greater MPS stimulus
  • EAA/BCAA supplements: Useful in clinical settings (pre/post-operative, cancer cachexia) or for those unable to meet protein targets through food; whole protein foods are superior for muscle-building in healthy individuals (contain micronutrients, phytonutrients, varied AAs)
  • Protein timing: Post-exercise protein (within ~2 h) is beneficial; total daily protein intake is the strongest determinant of MPS over time; "anabolic window" is wider than once thought

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Water is the most abundant compound in the human body, comprising ~60% of body weight in adult men and ~55% in adult women (varies by body composition — lean tissue is ~73% water, adipose tissue ~10%). Although not a source of calories, water is universally classified as an essential nutrient: survival without it is limited to days, compared to weeks without food. Water serves as the universal biological solvent, enabling all biochemical reactions, nutrient transport, thermoregulation, joint lubrication, waste elimination, and cellular homeostasis. Hydration status profoundly affects cognitive function, physical performance, kidney function, and gut health.

  • Classification: Essential nutrient; 0 kcal; sometimes classified as the "forgotten macronutrient"
  • Body distribution: Intracellular fluid (ICF) ~60% of total body water (TBW); Extracellular fluid (ECF) ~40% TBW (plasma ~7.5%, interstitial fluid ~25%, transcellular fluids ~7.5%)
  • Regulatory hormones: ADH (vasopressin), aldosterone, ANP (atrial natriuretic peptide), renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS)
  • Unique property: High heat capacity (4.18 J/g·°C) and heat of vaporisation (2,430 J/g) makes it an ideal thermoregulatory medium via sweat evaporation

docs.title: Inputs
docs.text: Source Volume (approximate) Beverages (all fluids) 1,400–2,000 mL/day Water in food 700–1,000 mL/day Metabolic water (oxidative metabolism) 200–300 mL/day Total intake ~2,300–3,300 mL/day (typical sedentary adult)

docs.title: Outputs
docs.text:
Route Volume (approximate) Urine 1,000–1,500 mL/day (regulated by ADH) Insensible losses — skin (diffusion) ~350–400 mL/day Sweat (active evaporation) 0–several litres/hour (highly variable) Respiratory losses 250–350 mL/day Faecal losses 100–200 mL/day Total output ~2,100–2,500 mL/day (non-exercise, temperate)

Metabolic water is produced by oxidative phosphorylation: oxidation of 100 g fat → ~107 g water; 100 g carbohydrate → ~55 g water; 100 g protein → ~41 g water. Camels exploit this (fatty hump) — but humans cannot meaningfully rely on it for hydration.

docs.title: Dietary Requirements (Adequate Intakes)
docs.text:
Population Total Water AI (all sources) Adult men (19–50 yr) 3.7 L/day (IOM) Adult women (19–50 yr) 2.7 L/day Pregnancy +0.3 L/day (3.0 L total) Lactation +0.7 L/day (3.8 L total) Children 1–3 yr 1.3 L/day Children 9–13 yr (boys) 2.4 L/day Older adults (>65 yr) Same or higher need; impaired thirst sensation increases dehydration risk Athletes / hot climate Highly individual — 0.5–1.0 L sweat per hour during exercise; replace based on body weight change

The "8×8 rule" (8 glasses × 8 oz = ~1.9 L/day) has no scientific basis — the IOM AIs above are evidence-based. Needs vary by body size, activity, climate, diet composition (high fruit/vegetable intake provides significant water), and health status. Pale yellow urine is the practical indicator of adequate hydration.

docs.title: Physiological Functions
docs.text: Function Mechanism Universal solvent Water's polarity (dipole moment) enables dissolution of ionic compounds (electrolytes), polar molecules (glucose, amino acids, vitamins), and protein hydration shells — prerequisite for all biochemical reactions Thermoregulation Sweating: ~580 kcal removed per litre of sweat evaporated; core temp maintained within a narrow range (36.5–37.5°C); without this, core temperature would rise ~1°C per 5–8 min during moderate exercise Nutrient and oxygen transport Plasma (blood = 55% plasma by volume; plasma = ~92% water) carries O₂ (dissolved + haemoglobin-bound), glucose, fatty acids, amino acids, hormones, immune cells, vitamins Waste elimination Kidneys filter ~180 L plasma/day → excrete ~1–2 L urine containing urea, creatinine, uric acid, drug metabolites; minimum urine output ~500 mL/day to excrete daily solute load Digestion and absorption Saliva (~1.5 L/day), gastric juice (~2 L/day), pancreatic secretions (~1.5 L/day), bile (~1 L/day), intestinal secretions (~1 L/day) — ~7 L secreted into GI tract daily, almost entirely reabsorbed Lubricant and cushion Synovial fluid (joint lubrication — predominantly water + hyaluronan); cerebrospinal fluid (cushions brain/spinal cord); pleural, pericardial, amniotic fluids Cellular volume regulation Osmotic pressure drives water between ICF and ECF; AQP (aquaporins — water channels) regulate trans-membrane water movement; cell swelling/shrinkage alters enzyme activity and gene expression Hydrolysis reactions Water is a reactant in hydrolytic cleavage of peptide bonds, ester bonds, glycosidic bonds — fundamental to digestion and many metabolic pathways Acid-base equilibrium Water acts as both acid (donates H⁺) and base (accepts H⁺); H₂CO₃/HCO₃⁻ buffering system (Henderson-Hasselbalch); maintains blood pH 7.35–7.45

docs.title: Electrolyte Balance and Osmolality
docs.text:
Electrolyte Compartment Normal Serum Range Key Role Sodium (Na⁺) ECF dominant 135–145 mEq/L Principal ECF osmole; determines plasma osmolality; regulated by ADH and aldosterone Potassium (K⁺) ICF dominant 3.5–5.0 mEq/L Resting membrane potential, action potentials, cardiac rhythm Chloride (Cl⁻) ECF 98–106 mEq/L Charge balance for Na⁺; HCl production in stomach Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) ECF 22–29 mEq/L Primary blood buffer Calcium (Ca²⁺) ECF (ionised) 1.1–1.4 mmol/L Neuromuscular excitability, cardiac function, clotting Magnesium (Mg²⁺) ICF 0.7–1.0 mmol/L Enzyme cofactor; cardiac and neuromuscular stability

Plasma osmolality = 2×[Na⁺] + [Glucose]/18 + [BUN]/2.8 ≈ 285–295 mOsm/kg - ADH released when osmolality rises >290 or volume drops >10% → renal water retention → dilutes osmolality - Aldosterone released (via RAAS) when Na⁺ low or volume low → renal Na⁺ retention → water follows osmotically

docs.title: Dehydration
docs.text:
Level % Body Weight Lost as Water Signs and Symptoms Mild 1–2% Thirst, slight reduction in cognitive performance, ~10% decrease in aerobic capacity Moderate 3–5% Headache, dry mouth, reduced urine output, irritability, impaired attention, ≥20% aerobic capacity decrease Severe 6–8% Muscle cramps, rapid heart rate, dizziness, confusion, oliguria Critical >10% Delirium, organ failure, death if untreated

Thirst lags dehydration by 1–2% — by the time you feel thirsty, performance is already mildly impaired. Athletes and older adults should drink proactively, not reactively. However, drinking to thirst is appropriate for most sedentary people and for preventing overhydration.

docs.title: Overhydration and Hyponatraemia
docs.text: Condition Mechanism Clinical Significance Exercise-associated hyponatraemia (EAH) Excess hypotonic fluid intake (outpaces renal excretion) + ADH non-suppression during exercise dilutes plasma Na⁺ Can occur in slow endurance athletes overdrinking plain water; prevents by drinking to thirst or using electrolyte drinks; Na⁺ <135 mEq/L → cerebral oedema → seizures (severe) Psychogenic polydipsia Compulsive water drinking (often in psychiatric illness); >1 L/hour overwhelms renal max clearance (~0.8–1 L/hour) Chronic dilutional hyponatraemia SIADH Inappropriate ADH secretion → excessive renal water retention → dilutional hyponatraemia Caused by CNS disease, pulmonary disease, drugs (SSRIs, carbamazepine, cyclophosphamide, NSAIDs)

docs.title: Kidney Stones
docs.text:
• Adequate hydration is the most effective preventive measure for all kidney stone types; target urine output >2 L/day (requires total fluid intake ~2.5–3 L/day).
  • Dilute urine reduces calcium oxalate, uric acid, and calcium phosphate supersaturation.
  • Lemon juice (citric acid → urinary citrate) is specifically beneficial for calcium oxalate stones (citrate chelates calcium, inhibits crystallisation).

docs.title: Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)
docs.text:
• Increased water intake (1.5 additional litres/day over baseline) reduces UTI recurrence by ~50% in women with recurrent UTIs (JAMA 2018 RCT).
  • Mechanism: More frequent urination flushes bacteria from the urethra.

docs.title: Constipation
docs.text:
• Adequate fluid intake combined with dietary fibre is required for fibre to have its stool-bulking effect; fibre without water can worsen constipation.
  • Carbonated water marginally superior to still water for constipation relief in some trials.

docs.title: Cognitive Function and Mood
docs.text:
• Dehydration of 1–2% body weight impairs attention, working memory, and psychomotor speed — particularly in the elderly and in heat; relevant for academic performance and occupational safety.
  • Headache is a common symptom of mild dehydration.

docs.title: Cardiovascular and Renal Disease Management
docs.text:
• In heart failure, free water may need restriction (<1.5 L/day) to prevent volume overload and dilutional hyponatraemia.
  • In CKD, fluid management is individualised — early CKD benefits from high fluid intake (reduces progression); advanced CKD or anuria requires restriction.

docs.title: Interactions
docs.text: Factor Effect Sodium Na⁺ is the primary osmotic determinant of ECF volume; high sodium intake proportionally increases water requirement and retention; WHO recommends <5 g NaCl/day Caffeine Mild diuretic effect at high doses (>250 mg/day); at habitual intake levels, coffee and tea contribute to net hydration (the diuresis is less than the fluid delivered); tolerance develops rapidly Alcohol Suppresses ADH release → diuresis → net dehydration effect; drinks above ~4% ABV cause net fluid loss; explains post-alcohol dehydration/headache (exacerbated by vasodilation) Dietary fibre Soluble fibre absorbs water in the gut → requires adequate water intake to maintain GI motility; insoluble fibre absorbs water → stool bulking; fibre + inadequate water → constipation Protein (high intake) Increases renal urea load → obligatory water needed for urea excretion; high-protein diets may slightly increase water requirement (~0.5–1 mL/kcal from protein = ~300–500 mL extra/day) Exercise / heat Sweat losses highly variable: 0.5–2.5 L/hour depending on intensity, heat, humidity, acclimatisation state; sodium losses 0.5–2 g/L sweat; electrolyte replacement essential during prolonged exercise (>1 hour) ADH / vasopressin Antidiuretic hormone is the central bottleneck of water regulation; many drugs and conditions impair ADH regulation (lithium causes nephrogenic DI; SSRI → SIADH) Diuretics Loop diuretics (furosemide), thiazides, acetazolamide — all increase urinary water and electrolyte losses; careful monitoring of hydration and electrolytes required

docs.title: Practical and Supplementation Notes
docs.text:
• Plain water remains the optimal hydration beverage for most people; no supplement is needed for routine sedentary hydration
  • Electrolyte drinks / oral rehydration salts (ORS): WHO ORS formula for diarrhoeal dehydration: 75 mEq/L Na⁺, 75 mmol/L glucose, 20 mEq/L K⁺ — isotonicity drives active co-transport absorption via SGLT1; superior to plain water for rehydration in significant diarrhoea/vomiting
  • Sports drinks (isotonic, 6% CHO + electrolytes): Evidence-based for endurance exercise >60–90 min; replenish glycogen + sodium + fluid simultaneously; unnecessary for <60 min exercise or casual activity
  • IV fluids (clinical use): Normal saline (0.9% NaCl), Lactated Ringer's, Hartmann's solution for volume resuscitation; 5% dextrose for hypoglycaemia/energy; choice depends on clinical context
  • Coconut water: Natural hypotonic beverage; moderate K⁺, low Na⁺; insufficient Na⁺ for prolonged exercise rehydration (add a pinch of salt); suitable casual hydration alternative
  • Hydration monitoring: Urine colour (pale yellow = adequate; dark yellow = dehydrated; clear = possibly over-hydrated); urine specific gravity 1.010–1.025 (adequate range); body weight pre/post exercise (1 kg loss ≈ ~1 L fluid deficit)
  • Carbonated water: Safe; does not damage tooth enamel with normal consumption (very low carbonic acid concentration); some evidence of slight constipation benefit; may increase satiety marginally; does not impair hydration
  • Hydrogen-rich water: No credible clinical evidence of benefit beyond ordinary water; classified as a dubious wellness product

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Calcium is the most abundant mineral in the human body, with approximately 99% stored in bones and teeth as hydroxyapatite crystals, and the remaining 1% in blood, muscles, and extracellular fluid. This 1% is metabolically vital — calcium is a universal intracellular second messenger and is essential for muscle contraction, nerve signalling, enzyme activation, and blood coagulation.

  • Atomic number: 20; divalent cation (Ca²⁺)
  • Category: Macromineral (required in hundreds of mg/day)
  • Body content: ~1,000–1,200 g in average adult
  • Bone reservoir: Acts as a dynamic calcium buffer — constantly remodelled to maintain serum calcium within a tight range (2.1–2.6 mmol/L)

docs.title: Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA Infants 0–6 months 200 mg/day (AI) Infants 7–12 months 260 mg/day (AI) Children 1–3 years 700 mg/day Children 4–8 years 1,000 mg/day Children 9–18 years 1,300 mg/day Adults 19–50 1,000 mg/day Adult Men 51–70 1,000 mg/day Adult Women 51–70 1,200 mg/day Adults 71+ 1,200 mg/day Pregnant / Breastfeeding Women 1,000 mg/day (1,300 if <19 yrs)

Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL): 2,500 mg/day for adults 19–50; 2,000 mg/day for adults 51+.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Bone and Teeth Mineralisation: Forms structural hydroxyapatite [Ca₁₀(PO₄)₆(OH)₂] in skeletal tissue; critical for peak bone mass development in adolescence.
  • Muscle Contraction: Ca²⁺ binds troponin C in cardiac and skeletal muscle, initiating actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling. Required for smooth muscle tone.
  • Nerve Impulse Transmission: Regulates neurotransmitter vesicle release at synaptic terminals via Ca²⁺-driven exocytosis.
  • Blood Clotting: Multiple coagulation factors (II, VII, IX, X) require Ca²⁺ as a cofactor; essential in the clotting cascade.
  • Enzyme Activation: Activates calmodulin-dependent protein kinases, phospholipases, and protease calpain.
  • Cell Signalling: Acts as a second messenger in cell proliferation, apoptosis, and gene expression.
  • Hormone Secretion: Stimulates insulin release from beta cells; regulates parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion inversely.
  • Vascular Function: Involved in contraction and dilation of blood vessels.

docs.title: Cofactors Needed
docs.text: Cofactor Role Vitamin D (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D₃) Upregulates intestinal TRPV6 calcium channel and calbindin-D9k; essential for active absorption Parathyroid Hormone (PTH) Increases renal calcium reabsorption, stimulates bone resorption, activates vitamin D Vitamin K2 (MK-7) Activates osteocalcin and matrix Gla protein — directs calcium into bones and away from arteries Magnesium Required for PTH secretion and vitamin D activation; deficiency impairs calcium metabolism Phosphorus Forms Ca:P ratio in bone; ratio of 2:1 (Ca:P) is optimal

docs.title: Pharmacokinetics
docs.text: Parameter Details Absorption Active (duodenum/jejunum, vitamin D-dependent) and passive (throughout intestine); overall 25–35% of intake absorbed Factors increasing absorption Vitamin D sufficiency, acidic gastric pH, lactose, low calcium intake Factors decreasing absorption High oxalate (spinach), high phytate (bran), achlorhydria, excess phosphorus, high caffeine or sodium Distribution 99% bone/teeth; 0.9% intracellular; 0.1% extracellular fluid Regulation PTH, calcitonin, and 1,25-(OH)₂D₃ tightly maintain serum Ca²⁺ at 2.1–2.6 mmol/L Excretion Primarily renal (~200 mg/day); some faecal; renal reabsorption enhanced by PTH and vitamin D; increased by high sodium intake

docs.title: Effects of Deficiency (Hypocalcaemia)
docs.text:
Acute hypocalcaemia is a medical emergency (serum Ca²⁺ <2.1 mmol/L corrected).

Symptoms: - Neuromuscular: Tetany, muscle cramps, paraesthesiae (tingling in extremities and perioral area) - Neurological: Seizures (hypocalcaemic), carpopedal spasm, Chvostek's sign (facial twitch), Trousseau's sign (carpal spasm with blood pressure cuff) - Cardiac: Prolonged QT interval → arrhythmias; cardiac failure in severe cases - Skeletal (chronic): Rickets (children), osteomalacia (adults), osteoporosis (long-term inadequacy) - Dental: Enamel hypoplasia, impaired dental development

At-Risk Populations: - Vitamin D-deficient individuals - Post-menopausal women (oestrogen loss accelerates bone resorption) - Elderly (reduced intestinal absorption, less sun exposure) - Hypoparathyroidism and post-thyroidectomy patients - Those with malabsorption (coeliac, Crohn's, short bowel syndrome) - Vegans (especially if avoiding fortified foods)

docs.title: Treatment Protocols
docs.text:
Condition Protocol Acute severe hypocalcaemia IV calcium gluconate (10 ml of 10% solution) over 10 minutes; ECG monitoring Hypoparathyroidism Oral calcium carbonate 1–3 g/day + calcitriol (active vitamin D) 0.25–1 µg/day Dietary deficiency / osteoporosis prevention 1,000–1,200 mg/day dietary + supplement if needed; co-administer vitamin D 800–2,000 IU/day Rickets / Osteomalacia High-dose vitamin D + calcium (regimen depends on cause) Post-menopausal osteoporosis Calcium + vitamin D + bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate)

Calcium carbonate is cheapest but requires stomach acid; calcium citrate is better absorbed in achlorhydria or with PPIs.

docs.title: Drug Interactions
docs.text: Drug / Class Effect Bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate) Calcium impairs absorption — separate by ≥2 hours Fluoroquinolone / tetracycline antibiotics Calcium chelates drug → reduced antibiotic absorption Levothyroxine Calcium reduces absorption — separate by ≥4 hours Thiazide diuretics Reduce urinary calcium excretion → may cause hypercalcaemia if calcium intake is high Loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide) Increase urinary calcium loss Corticosteroids Impair intestinal calcium absorption; increase bone resorption Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) Reduce gastric acid → impair calcium carbonate absorption Calcium channel blockers High-dose calcium supplements may blunt their antihypertensive effect

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Calcium (mg) Parmesan cheese 28g ~336 mg Milk (cow, whole) 240 ml ~300 mg Plain yogurt (low-fat) 245g ~415 mg Canned sardines (with bones) 85g ~325 mg Fortified plant milk (soy, almond) 240 ml ~300 mg Tofu (set with calcium sulfate) 85g ~250 mg Kale (cooked) 90g ~95 mg White beans (cooked) 90g ~80 mg Bok choy (cooked) 85g ~79 mg Broccoli (cooked) 90g ~60 mg

Note: Calcium from high-oxalate foods (spinach, beet greens, Swiss chard) has poor bioavailability (~5%) due to oxalate binding. Low-oxalate greens (kale, bok choy) offer much better absorption (~50%).

docs.title: Storage & Stability
docs.text:
• Calcium itself is a mineral element — it is not degraded by cooking, light, or storage.
  • Bioavailability from food can be affected by cooking methods (e.g., boiling greens reduces oxalate content, improving Ca absorption).
  • Calcium in supplements is stable indefinitely when stored dry.

docs.title: Toxicity (Hypercalcaemia)
docs.text:
Cause Details Primary hyperparathyroidism Most common cause; excess PTH increases bone resorption and renal Ca reabsorption Excessive supplementation UL of 2,000–2,500 mg/day may be exceeded by over-supplementation Vitamin D toxicity Excess 1,25-(OH)₂D₃ drives intestinal hyperabsorption Granulomatous diseases Sarcoidosis, TB produce excess active vitamin D

Symptoms of Hypercalcaemia: "Bones, stones, groans, moans" — bone pain, nephrolithiasis (kidney stones), abdominal pain/constipation, fatigue/confusion. Severe cases: cardiac arrhythmia, renal failure, coma.

Milk-Alkali Syndrome: Excessive calcium carbonate intake (antacids) combined with milk → hypercalcaemia, metabolic alkalosis, and renal impairment.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Chloride is the principal intracellular and extracellular anion. In the extracellular fluid, it is the main counter-ion to sodium, playing a critical role in maintaining osmotic balance, blood volume, and electrical neutrality. Chloride also participates directly in gastric acid production, carbon dioxide transport, and cell volume regulation.

  • Atomic number: 17; monovalent anion (Cl⁻)
  • Category: Macromineral / Electrolyte
  • Body content: ~115 g in average adult
  • Normal serum range: 98–106 mmol/L
  • Key fact: Consumed almost entirely as sodium chloride (table salt) and other chloride salts in food.

docs.title: Requirements (AI)
docs.text:
Age / Group Adequate Intake (AI) Infants 0–6 months 180 mg/day Infants 7–12 months 570 mg/day Children 1–3 years 1,500 mg/day Children 4–8 years 1,900 mg/day Children 9–13 years 2,300 mg/day Adolescents 14–18 years 2,300 mg/day Adults 19–50 2,300 mg/day Adults 51–70 2,000 mg/day Adults 71+ 1,800 mg/day Pregnant Women 2,300 mg/day Breastfeeding Women 2,300 mg/day

No Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL) is established for chloride separately — the AI reflects combined intake as NaCl (sodium chloride), and sodium UL governs clinical guidance.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Extracellular Osmolality: Along with Na⁺, Cl⁻ is the primary determinant of extracellular fluid tonicity and volume.
  • Gastric Acid Production: Cl⁻ is secreted by gastric parietal cells via H⁺/K⁺-ATPase combined with apical Cl⁻ channels to form hydrochloric acid (HCl, pH 1.5–3.5). Essential for protein digestion and pathogen killing.
  • Carbon Dioxide Transport (Chloride Shift): In RBCs, CO₂ is hydrated to bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) by carbonic anhydrase; HCO₃⁻ exits the cell in exchange for Cl⁻ (the Hamburger/chloride shift) — moves CO₂ from tissues to lungs.
  • Nerve and Muscle Excitability: GABA_A receptors are Cl⁻ channels; Cl⁻ influx hyperpolarises neurons (inhibitory post-synaptic potential). Glycine receptors also operate via Cl⁻.
  • Cell Volume Regulation: Cl⁻ influx/efflux with Na⁺ or K⁺ regulates cell swelling and shrinkage.
  • Electrical Neutrality: Balances cation charge across cell membranes and in plasma.
  • Bile and Pancreatic Secretion: Component of digestive secretions; CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) is a Cl⁻ channel essential for mucus and secretion hydration.

docs.title: Cofactors Needed
docs.text: Cofactor Role Sodium Principal paired cation (NaCl) — chloride excretion/retention shadows sodium handling by kidneys Hydrogen (H⁺) / Carbonic anhydrase Drives chloride shift in RBCs and gastric acid formation CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) Cl⁻ channel required for secretion hydration in lungs, pancreas, GI tract Potassium K⁺/Cl⁻ co-transporters (KCC) regulate cell volume and neuronal inhibition

docs.title: Pharmacokinetics
docs.text: Parameter Details Absorption Nearly completely absorbed in the small intestine; passive paracellular and active transport Distribution ~70% extracellular fluid; 20% intracellular; 10% bone Regulation Closely linked to sodium regulation via kidneys (RAAS, aldosterone); follows sodium reabsorption in most nephron segments Excretion Primarily renal; can be conserved below 1 mmol/day under severe restriction Sweat Significant losses in excessive sweating; cystic fibrosis patients have abnormally high sweat Cl⁻ (>60 mmol/L — diagnostic)

docs.title: Effects of Deficiency (Hypochloraemia)
docs.text:
Serum Cl⁻ <98 mmol/L. Usually secondary to sodium depletion, vomiting, or excessive diuresis.

Causes: Prolonged vomiting (loss of HCl), prolonged nasogastric suction, loop/thiazide diuretics, metabolic alkalosis, SIADH.

Symptoms: - Metabolic alkalosis (most characteristic consequence — loss of HCl leaves net bicarbonate excess) - Muscle weakness, cramps, tetany - Respiratory compensation (hypoventilation — retains CO₂ to buffer alkalosis) - Confusion, lethargy in severe cases

At-Risk Groups: Patients with recurrent vomiting (eating disorders, hyperemesis gravidarum), prolonged NG tube drainage, high-dose diuretic users.

docs.title: Treatment Protocols
docs.text: Condition Protocol Mild hypochloraemia Oral NaCl (dietary salt restoration or saline tablets); treat underlying cause Hypochloraemic metabolic alkalosis IV 0.9% NaCl (isotonic saline) to provide Cl⁻ and correct volume; KCl added if hypokalaemic Severe alkalosis refractory to saline Acetazolamide (promotes HCO₃⁻ excretion); rarely HCl infusion via central venous line

docs.title: Drug Interactions
docs.text: Drug / Class Effect Loop diuretics Promote urinary Cl⁻ loss → hypochloraemia and metabolic alkalosis Thiazide diuretics Renal Cl⁻ loss; less pronounced than loop diuretics Proton pump inhibitors Reduce gastric HCl secretion — clinically, not a major factor in serum Cl⁻ Acetazolamide Promotes HCO₃⁻ excretion → relatively increases serum Cl⁻ (hyperchloraemic acidosis)

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Chloride is consumed almost exclusively as sodium chloride (salt) and potassium chloride (salt substitute). Most natural foods contain minimal amounts.

Food Serving Approximate Chloride (mg) Table salt (NaCl) 1 tsp ~3,550 mg Canned soup 240 ml ~450–900 mg Processed deli meats 85g ~500–1,000 mg Soy sauce 1 tbsp ~950 mg Sea vegetables (seaweed, kelp) 28g ~400–600 mg Milk 240 ml ~170 mg Bread (white) 1 slice ~100–200 mg

docs.title: Storage & Stability
docs.text:
• Chloride (as a mineral anion) is not degraded by cooking, heat, light, or storage.
  • Content in food is directly tied to added salt (NaCl) during processing or cooking.

docs.title: Toxicity (Hyperchloraemia)
docs.text:
Serum Cl⁻ >106 mmol/L. Usually associated with hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis.

Causes: Excessive normal saline (0.9% NaCl has supraphysiological Cl⁻ at 154 mmol/L); renal tubular acidosis; diarrhoea (HCO₃⁻ loss proportionally raises Cl⁻); acetazolamide; ammonium chloride.

Clinical significance: Hyperchloraemic acidosis is associated with renal vasoconstriction and reduced GFR. Balanced crystalloids (Ringer's lactate, Plasma-Lyte) reduce hyperchloraemia risk vs. normal saline in critical care.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Chromium is an essential trace mineral that potentiates the action of insulin and plays a role in the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. It exists in biological systems as trivalent chromium (Cr³⁺) — the only biologically relevant and nutritionally important form. The function of chromium in insulin action has been attributed to a low-molecular-weight chromium-binding oligopeptide (LMWCr or chromodulin).

  • Atomic number: 24; biologically active as Cr³⁺ (trivalent); Cr⁶⁺ (hexavalent) is industrial/toxic
  • Category: Trace mineral
  • Body content: ~4–6 mg in average adult; widely distributed, highest in liver, kidney, muscle, spleen
  • Key fact: Chromium requirements are among the smallest of all essential minerals; deficiency in healthy free-living adults is rare.

docs.title: Requirements (AI)
docs.text:
Age / Group Adequate Intake (AI) Infants 0–6 months 0.2 µg/day Infants 7–12 months 5.5 µg/day Children 1–3 years 11 µg/day Children 4–8 years 15 µg/day Males 9–13 years 25 µg/day Females 9–13 years 21 µg/day Males 14–50 years 35 µg/day Females 14–18 years 24 µg/day Adult Women 19–50 25 µg/day Adult Men 51+ 30 µg/day Adult Women 51+ 20 µg/day Pregnant Women 29–30 µg/day Breastfeeding Women 44–45 µg/day

No Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL) has been established for trivalent chromium from food or supplements due to low toxicity and poor absorption. Cr⁶⁺ (hexavalent) has a separate UL of 0.1 mg/day from water.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Insulin Sensitisation (Chromodulin): Chromium is incorporated into chromodulin (LMWCr) — an oligopeptide consisting of glycine, cysteine, aspartate, and glutamate that binds 4 Cr³⁺ ions. Upon insulin receptor activation, chromodulin is released from stores and amplifies insulin receptor tyrosine kinase activity.
  • Glucose Uptake: By potentiating insulin signalling, chromium facilitates GLUT4 translocation to cell membranes → enhanced cellular glucose uptake.
  • Lipid Metabolism: Chromium supplementation has been associated with modest improvements in triglyceride and HDL profiles in some studies, attributed to improved insulin sensitivity.
  • Protein Metabolism: Chromium was used in livestock for muscle protein accretion — evidence in humans is weak.
  • Chromium and Exercise: Claims about chromium picolinate for muscle building are largely not supported by robust human trials.

docs.title: Cofactors Needed
docs.text: Cofactor Role Insulin receptor Chromium amplifies insulin receptor tyrosine kinase activity — functional only when insulin pathway is intact Transferrin Primary chromium transport protein in plasma (alongside albumin) Nicotinic acid (B3) Early hypothesis that chromium formed a "glucose tolerance factor" (GTF) complex with niacin and amino acids — subsequently disproved; separate processes

docs.title: Pharmacokinetics
docs.text: Parameter Details Absorption Very low: 0.5–2% of dietary Cr³⁺; organic chromium (picolinate, nicotinate) slightly higher ~2–5% Absorbed as Cr³⁺ transported via transferrin in blood Distribution Liver, kidney, muscle, bone, spleen Excretion Primarily urinary; renal excretion increases with high carbohydrate intake and strenuous exercise Half-life Varies by tissue — short (~1 day) in plasma, longer in tissues

docs.title: Effects of Deficiency
docs.text:
The evidence base for chromium essentiality is less robust than for other trace minerals.

Clinical deficiency (documented only in patients on total parenteral nutrition without chromium): - Impaired glucose tolerance resembling type 2 diabetes - Elevated fasting glucose and insulin - Impaired lipid metabolism - Peripheral neuropathy

In free-living populations: Chromium deficiency based on dietary intake is not well-documented; it is difficult to measure chromium status accurately (contamination confounds blood/urine measurements).

docs.title: Treatment Protocols
docs.text: Condition Protocol Proven TPN-associated deficiency IV chromium 10–15 µg/day in TPN formulation Standard TPN maintenance 10–15 µg/day IV (optimal long-term may be lower — reassessed given potential nephrotoxicity risk) Type 2 diabetes / insulin resistance (controversial) Chromium picolinate 200–1,000 µg/day studied; modest, inconsistent evidence; not a standard of care

docs.title: Drug Interactions
docs.text: Drug / Class Effect NSAIDs (aspirin, ibuprofen) May increase chromium absorption (mechanism unclear) Antacids Alkaline pH reduces Cr³⁺ absorption Iron supplements Compete with chromium for transferrin binding; high iron may reduce chromium transport Insulin / hypoglycaemic agents Theoretical potentiation — monitor blood glucose if combining chromium supplements with insulin therapy

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Chromium (µg) Broccoli (cooked) 90g ~22 µg Grape juice 240 ml ~8 µg English muffin (whole wheat) 1 muffin ~4 µg Potatoes (mashed) 1 cup ~3 µg Garlic (dried) 1 tsp ~3 µg Turkey breast 85g ~2 µg Beef (ground) 85g ~2 µg Orange juice 240 ml ~2 µg Apple (with peel) 1 medium ~1.4 µg Green beans 90g ~1.1 µg

Note: Chromium content of foods is poorly characterised — values in databases have high variability due to soil and analytical contamination issues.

docs.title: Storage & Stability
docs.text:
• Chromium mineral content is stable to cooking and storage.
  • Stainless steel cookware (which contains chromium) can leach small amounts of Cr³⁺ into acidic foods — generally considered safe and may contribute to intake.

docs.title: Toxicity
docs.text:
Trivalent Cr³⁺ (dietary/supplemental forms): - Very low toxicity; no UL established from food sources - Chromium picolinate at high doses (>1,000 µg/day) has theoretical concerns — picolinic acid may enhance cellular uptake beyond regulation; very rare reports of renal failure and rhabdomyolysis

Hexavalent Cr⁶⁺ (industrial form — NOT dietary): - Potent carcinogen and mutagen; classified as IARC Group 1 (lung carcinogen via inhalation) - Causes DNA strand breaks and oxidative damage - Found in industrial settings (chrome plating, tanning, welding on stainless steel) and contaminated groundwater

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Copper is an essential trace mineral and a transition metal that functions as a redox cofactor, cycling between Cu⁺ (cuprous) and Cu²⁺ (cupric) states. It is a key component of several critical enzymes involved in energy production, iron metabolism, antioxidant defence, neurotransmitter synthesis, and connective tissue formation. Total body copper is approximately 75–150 mg, distributed primarily in muscle, bone, liver, brain, and blood.

  • Atomic number: 29; cycles Cu⁺ ↔ Cu²⁺
  • Category: Trace mineral
  • Normal serum range: 70–140 µg/dL (increases in pregnancy and inflammation as copper is an acute-phase reactant)

docs.title: Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA Infants 0–6 months 200 µg/day (AI) Infants 7–12 months 220 µg/day (AI) Children 1–3 years 340 µg/day Children 4–8 years 440 µg/day Children 9–13 years 700 µg/day Adolescents 14–18 years 890 µg/day Adults 19+ 900 µg/day Pregnant Women 1,000 µg/day Breastfeeding Women 1,300 µg/day

Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL): 10,000 µg/day (10 mg/day) for adults.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Cytochrome c Oxidase (Complex IV): Copper is essential in this terminal enzyme of the ETC — transfers electrons to O₂ to form water; critical for aerobic ATP synthesis.
  • Iron Metabolism (Ceruloplasmin): Ceruloplasmin (a copper-containing ferroxidase) oxidises Fe²⁺ to Fe³⁺, enabling iron loading onto transferrin for transport. Copper deficiency → functional iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Antioxidant Defence (SOD1): Cu/Zn-superoxide dismutase (SOD1) dismutates superoxide radicals (O₂⁻) to H₂O₂; found in cytoplasm. SOD2 (manganese-dependent) in mitochondria.
  • Connective Tissue Crosslinking (Lysyl Oxidase): Copper enzyme crosslinks collagen and elastin fibres; deficiency causes aortic aneurysm, joint laxity, and fragile bone (Menkes-like effects).
  • Neurotransmitter Synthesis (Dopamine β-Hydroxylase): Converts dopamine to norepinephrine; copper deficiency can impair the sympathetic nervous system.
  • Tyrosinase: Copper enzyme required for melanin synthesis from tyrosine — deficiency → hypopigmentation.
  • Peptidylglycine α-Amidating Monooxygenase (PAM): Activates neuropeptides (substance P, vasoactive intestinal peptide) and peptide hormones.
  • Mitochondrial Biogenesis and ETC assembly: Copper chaperone proteins (COX17, SCO1) are required for Complex IV assembly.

docs.title: Cofactors Needed
docs.text: Cofactor Role Zinc Copper and zinc compete for absorption via metallothionein; balance is critical (Cu:Zn ratio normally ~1:10 in serum) Iron Operates downstream of copper in iron metabolism; functional iron deficiency occurs in copper deficiency Albumin and ceruloplasmin Copper transport proteins in plasma; ceruloplasmin carries ~95% of plasma copper Vitamin C (high dose) Can reduce copper absorption when taken in very high doses (>1,500 mg)

docs.title: Pharmacokinetics
docs.text: Parameter Details Absorption 25–45% of dietary copper absorbed in stomach and proximal small intestine; via Ctr1 transporter Absorbed as Cu⁺ (cuprous); dietary Cu²⁺ reduced by stomach acid Distribution Liver (primary hub); bound to ceruloplasmin (~95% plasma copper); also albumin and macroglobulin (~5%) Metabolism Liver — excreted in bile (~95% of body copper turnover); ATP7B transporter essential for biliary copper export Excretion Primarily biliary/faecal; urinary copper minimal (<60 µg/day) unless chelation therapy Half-life ~2–5 weeks for hepatic copper pool

docs.title: Effects of Deficiency
docs.text:
Copper deficiency is uncommon but clinically important.

Causes: Prolonged high-dose zinc supplementation (most common — zinc induces metallothionein which preferentially binds Cu), malabsorption (bariatric surgery, coeliac disease), excess formula-based feeding without copper supplementation.

Symptoms: - Haematological: Anaemia (normocytic or macrocytic, sideroblastic — iron can not be loaded onto transferrin), neutropenia - Neurological: Myelopathy (copper deficiency myelopathy — demyelination of posterior and lateral spinal columns, mimics subacute combined degeneration of vitamin B12 deficiency), peripheral neuropathy, ataxia, cognitive impairment - Connective tissue: Weakened collagen and elastin — aortic aneurysm risk, skeletal abnormalities - Immunological: Lymphopenia, increased infection susceptibility - Hypopigmentation: Reduced melanin production

docs.title: Treatment Protocols
docs.text: Condition Protocol Mild copper deficiency Copper gluconate or copper sulfate 2 mg/day oral Neurological copper deficiency 2–4 mg/day elemental copper; may require IV copper initially Zinc-induced copper deficiency Stop or reduce zinc; copper 2 mg/day; neurological recovery partial Wilson's disease (copper overload) Penicillamine chelation (D-Pen), trientine, or zinc therapy (50 mg elemental TID blocks Cu absorption) Menkes disease (Cu transporter defect) SC copper-histidine injections (bypasses defective intestinal Ctr1)

docs.title: Drug Interactions
docs.text: Drug / Class Effect Zinc (>50 mg elemental/day) Induces intestinal metallothionein → sequesters copper → deficiency Penicillamine Chelates copper: used therapeutically in Wilson's; causes deficiency with long-term use Vitamin C (>1,500 mg/day) May reduce copper absorption and ceruloplasmin activity Antacids Alkaline pH may reduce Cu²⁺ absorption partially

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text: Food Serving Copper (µg) Beef liver (cooked) 85g ~12,400 µg Oysters (cooked) 85g ~4,850 µg Crab (Dungeness, cooked) 85g ~630 µg Cashews 28g ~620 µg Sunflower seeds 28g ~519 µg Hazelnuts 28g ~496 µg Dark chocolate (70–85%) 28g ~501 µg Baked potato (flesh + skin) 1 medium ~610 µg Mushrooms (shiitake, cooked) 86g ~650 µg Lentils (cooked) 90g ~249 µg

docs.title: Storage & Stability
docs.text:
• Copper content in foods is stable to cooking and storage.
  • Copper can leach from copper pipes into drinking water — particularly in households with new copper plumbing and acidic water.

docs.title: Toxicity
docs.text:
Condition Details Acute copper toxicity Accidental ingestion of copper salts → nausea, vomiting, haemolytic anaemia, hepatic necrosis Wilson's disease Autosomal recessive (ATP7B mutation) — impaired biliary copper excretion → copper deposits in liver (cirrhosis), brain (neuropsychiatric symptoms), cornea (Kayser-Fleischer rings), kidneys Indian childhood cirrhosis High copper intake from brass vessel-stored milk → severe early hepatic copper overload Chronic supplemental excess (>10 mg/day UL) Hepatic injury, GI symptoms, haemolysis

Serum markers: Ceruloplasmin and serum copper are usually low in deficiency (except in inflammation/pregnancy where they rise); 24-hour urine copper >100 µg/day + low ceruloplasmin + Kayser-Fleischer rings = Wilson's disease triad.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Fluoride (the ionised form of fluorine) is a trace mineral that is unique in that its primary biological function is prevention of dental caries rather than acting as an enzyme cofactor. It is incorporated into the crystalline structure of tooth enamel and bone, enhancing resistance to acid dissolution. Fluoride is found naturally in water, soil, and some foods; it is also widely added to drinking water and toothpaste as a public health intervention.

  • Atomic number: 9 (fluorine); exists in biological systems as fluoride ion (F⁻)
  • Category: Trace mineral
  • Body content: ~2.6 g in average adult; primary storage in bone and teeth (as fluorapatite)
  • Key fact: Water fluoridation is one of the ten greatest public health achievements of the 20th century (CDC); optimal concentration is 0.7 mg/L.

docs.title: Requirements (AI)
docs.text:
Age / Group Adequate Intake (AI) Infants 0–6 months 0.01 mg/day Infants 7–12 months 0.5 mg/day Children 1–3 years 0.7 mg/day Children 4–8 years 1.0 mg/day Children 9–13 years 2.0 mg/day Adolescents 14–18 years 3.0 mg/day Adult Men 19+ 4.0 mg/day Adult Women 19+ 3.0 mg/day Pregnant Women 3.0 mg/day Breastfeeding Women 3.0 mg/day

Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL): 10 mg/day for adults; 1.3–2.2 mg/day for children (age-dependent), based on dental/skeletal fluorosis prevention.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Dental Caries Prevention: F⁻ incorporates into hydroxyapatite of tooth enamel → forms fluorapatite (Ca₁₀(PO₄)₆F₂) which is more resistant to acid (pH threshold 4.5 vs. 5.5 for hydroxyapatite). Fluoride also inhibits glycolysis by mutans streptococci, reducing acid production.
  • Remineralisation: Fluoride enhances remineralisation of early carious lesions by promoting mineral deposition from saliva.
  • Bone Structure: Fluoride in bone (as fluorapatite) increases crystal size and density; high-dose therapeutic use briefly explored for osteoporosis (limited due to adverse effects on bone quality).
  • Enzyme Inhibition: At high concentrations, F⁻ inhibits enolase (glycolytic enzyme) — basis for its antibacterial effect; at toxic concentrations, inhibits multiple enzymes in human cells.

docs.title: Cofactors Needed
docs.text: Cofactor Role Calcium Required for fluorapatite formation ([Ca₁₀(PO₄)₆F₂]) Phosphate Co-structural in fluorapatite Saliva Provides calcium and phosphate for remineralisation promoted by fluoride

docs.title: Pharmacokinetics
docs.text: Parameter Details Absorption ~80–90% of soluble fluoride absorbed rapidly in stomach and small intestine Absorption reduced by Calcium, aluminium, and magnesium (form insoluble complexes) Distribution 99% in mineralised tissues (bone and teeth); rapid initial distribution to hard tissues Plasma peak ~30–60 minutes after ingestion Excretion Primarily renal (~50–60% within 24 hours); remainder deposited in bone; sweat and faeces minor Half-life (plasma) ~2–9 hours

docs.title: Effects of Deficiency
docs.text:
Fluoride deficiency is not associated with essential biochemical dysfunction beyond dental effects.

Manifestations: Increased susceptibility to dental caries (cavities) — the primary and most clinically important consequence. Communities without water fluoridation or fluoride in diet have significantly higher caries rates.

Note: Unlike other minerals, fluoride deficiency does not cause a characteristic clinical syndrome beyond dental caries — it is therefore often termed a "conditional essential" mineral with primary dental rather than metabolic essentiality.

docs.title: Treatment Protocols
docs.text: Condition Protocol Caries prevention (community) Water fluoridation at 0.7 mg/L; fluoride toothpaste (1,000–1,500 ppm for adults, 1,000 ppm ages 3–6) Caries prevention (high-risk child) Fluoride varnish (22,600 ppm NaF) applied 2–4×/year by dental professional Children in non-fluoridated areas Fluoride supplements prescribed by dentist (0.25–1 mg/day based on age and water fluoride level) Severe acute fluoride ingestion Induce vomiting; calcium gluconate or milk to bind fluoride; IV calcium gluconate for hypocalcaemia

docs.title: Drug Interactions
docs.text: Drug / Class Effect Calcium antacids / milk Reduce fluoride absorption (form insoluble CaF₂) — avoid co-ingestion with fluoride supplements Aluminium and magnesium antacids Similarly reduce fluoride absorption Ciprofloxacin and fluoroquinolones Contain fluorine but not fluoride — unrelated to dietary fluoride toxicology

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Fluoride (mg) Fluoridated tap water 1 L ~0.7 mg Tea (black, brewed) 240 ml 0.1–0.6 mg Canned sardines (with bones) 85g ~0.2 mg Shrimp 85g ~0.17 mg Crab 85g ~0.21 mg Grape juice / raisins 240 ml / 145g ~0.07–0.17 mg Potatoes (boiled in fluoridated water) 1 medium ~0.05–0.10 mg

Most dietary fluoride comes from fluoridated drinking water and beverages made with it. Foods prepared with fluoridated water also contribute.

docs.title: Storage & Stability
docs.text:
• Fluoride is not degraded by cooking or storage. However, foods cooked in fluoridated water absorb additional fluoride.
  • Fluoride concentrations in tea increase with steeping time.

docs.title: Toxicity
docs.text: Type Detail Dental fluorosis Exposure during tooth development (0–8 years) → white spots, pitting, or brown staining of enamel; primarily cosmetic at mild–moderate levels Skeletal fluorosis Chronic very high intake (>10 mg/day for years) → bone pain, increased density, calcification of ligaments, osteosclerosis; seen in areas with naturally high fluoride water (>4 mg/L) Acute toxicity ~5 mg/kg body weight is lethal; as low as 1 mg/kg causes GI symptoms; symptoms: nausea, vomiting, hypocalcaemia, tetany, cardiac arrhythmia Thyroid Controversy exists; very high endemic fluoride areas associated with altered thyroid function in some studies; not established at public health fluoridation levels

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Iodine is an essential trace mineral required exclusively for the synthesis of thyroid hormones — thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3). Thyroid hormones regulate metabolism in virtually every cell in the body, making iodine indispensable for normal growth, development, and metabolic rate. Iodine deficiency is the world's leading preventable cause of brain damage and intellectual disability.

  • Atomic number: 53; biologically active as iodide (I⁻)
  • Category: Trace mineral
  • Body content: ~15–20 mg; ~70–80% in the thyroid gland
  • Key fact: Iodine deficiency affects approximately 2 billion people globally; iodisation of salt is one of the most cost-effective public health interventions.

docs.title: Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA Infants 0–6 months 110 µg/day (AI) Infants 7–12 months 130 µg/day (AI) Children 1–8 years 90 µg/day Children 9–13 years 120 µg/day Adolescents 14–18 years 150 µg/day Adults 19+ 150 µg/day Pregnant Women 220 µg/day Breastfeeding Women 290 µg/day

Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL): 1,100 µg/day for adults (includes all sources).

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Thyroid Hormone Synthesis: Iodide is actively transported into thyroid follicular cells (via NIS — sodium-iodide symporter), oxidised to iodine by thyroid peroxidase (TPO) (selenium-dependent enzyme), incorporated into thyroglobulin at tyrosine residues to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT), coupled to form T4 and T3.
  • Metabolic Rate Regulation: T3 binds nuclear thyroid hormone receptors → regulates transcription of genes controlling basal metabolic rate, thermogenesis, and oxidative phosphorylation capacity.
  • Growth and Development: Essential for normal linear growth, bone maturation, and organ development.
  • Brain Development: Critical in fetal and neonatal periods — T3 is required for neuronal migration, myelination, synaptic development, and dendritic growth. Deficiency → cretinism.
  • Cardiac Function: T3 regulates heart rate and cardiac contractility.
  • Reproductive Function: Required for ovulation and pregnancy maintenance.
  • Antimicrobial Properties: Topical iodine (Lugol's, povidone-iodine) has direct bactericidal, virucidal, and fungicidal activity.

docs.title: Cofactors Needed
docs.text: Cofactor Role Selenium (deiodinases) DIO1 and DIO2 convert T4 → active T3; selenium deficiency impairs T3 production Iron (thyroid peroxidase) TPO is a haem-containing enzyme; iron deficiency reduces its activity and impairs thyroid hormone synthesis Zinc Required for thyroid hormone receptor function and T3 binding Tyrosine Amino acid substrate for iodination (thyroglobulin tyrosine residues)

docs.title: Pharmacokinetics
docs.text: Parameter Details Absorption Essentially 100% of dietary iodide absorbed in stomach and small intestine NIS (sodium-iodide symporter) Concentrates iodide 20–40× in thyroid tissue against gradient; also in breast and salivary glands Thyroid uptake Radioiodine uptake (RAIU) is ~10–30% of administered dose normally; used diagnostically and therapeutically Thyroid hormone half-life T4: 5–7 days; T3: 1–2 days; rT3: 4 hours Excretion Primarily urinary (>90%); 24-hour urinary iodine is the best population-level marker of iodine status

docs.title: Effects of Deficiency
docs.text:
Iodine Deficiency Disorders (IDD) — a spectrum by life stage:

Stage Manifestation Fetal / neonatal Cretinism (intellectual disability, deafness, spastic diplegia, short stature), stillbirth, miscarriage Neonatal / infant Neonatal hypothyroidism; impaired brain development Child Goitre, impaired mental and physical development, poor school performance Adult Goitre (compensatory thyroid enlargement), hypothyroidism, fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation Pregnancy Foetal brain damage; increased perinatal and neonatal mortality

docs.title: Treatment Protocols
docs.text: Condition Protocol Dietary iodine deficiency Iodised salt; potassium iodide supplementation 150–300 µg/day; Lugol's iodine where necessary Pregnancy iodine deficiency 220 µg/day via iodine-containing prenatal supplement Neonatal hypothyroidism IV levothyroxine initiated immediately; iodine supplementation if cause is deficiency Thyroid storm (emergency) Potassium iodide (SSKI) given 1+ hour after thionamide to block thyroid hormone release (Wolff-Chaikoff effect) Radiation emergency (nuclear fallout) Potassium iodide tablets to saturate thyroid NIS and block radioiodine uptake: 130 mg KI for adults

docs.title: Drug Interactions
docs.text: Drug / Class Effect Amiodarone Contains 37% iodine by weight; causes drug-induced thyrotoxicosis (excess iodine → Jod-Basedow effect) or hypothyroidism (Wolff-Chaikoff) Lithium Inhibits thyroidal iodide uptake and thyroid hormone secretion → hypothyroidism Goitrogens (thiouracil, propylthiouracil, methimazole) Block TPO → reduce thyroid hormone synthesis; used therapeutically in hyperthyroidism Perchlorate / thiocyanate Compete with iodide at NIS → reduce thyroid uptake (cigarette smoke contains thiocyanate) Radioiodine (¹³¹I) Used therapeutically for hyperthyroidism and thyroid cancer; requires stopping interfering medications Soy isoflavones High doses may interfere with iodine absorption and thyroid hormone synthesis

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text:
Food Serving Iodine (µg) Seaweed (nori, dried) 10g 116–2,984 µg (highly variable) Cod (baked) 85g ~99 µg Iodised salt 1/4 tsp ~71 µg Milk (cow, whole) 240 ml ~56 µg Plain yogurt 245g ~75 µg Shrimp 85g ~35 µg Eggs 1 large ~24 µg Canned tuna 85g ~17 µg Prunes (dried) 5 prunes ~13 µg

Note: Non-iodised sea salt and gourmet salts do not contain meaningful iodine. Seaweed can provide dangerous iodine excess — excess iodine paradoxically inhibits thyroid (Wolff-Chaikoff effect).

docs.title: Storage & Stability
docs.text:
• Iodine in food is relatively stable. Cooking causes some losses (10–50% depending on method).
  • Iodised salt loses iodine gradually when exposed to air, moisture, and light — store covered and dry.

docs.title: Toxicity
docs.text: Intake Effect >1,100 µg/day (UL exceeded) May trigger hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism (Jod-Basedow) in susceptible individuals Wolff-Chaikoff effect Acute iodine load transiently inhibits thyroid organification — normally escaped; failure in neonates / diseased glands Jod-Basedow phenomenon Iodine excess → hyperthyroidism in glands with autonomous nodules or Graves' disease Seaweed-induced thyrotoxicosis Reported from excessive seaweed consumption (particularly kelp supplements)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Iron is the most abundant trace mineral in the human body, with approximately 2.5–4 g in average adults. It exists in two functional pools: functional iron (in haemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochromes, and iron-containing enzymes) and storage iron (ferritin and haemosiderin in liver, spleen, and bone marrow). Iron's primary biological role is oxygen transport and electron transfer, enabled by its reversible Fe²⁺ ↔ Fe³⁺ redox cycling.

  • Atomic number: 26; exists as ferrous (Fe²⁺) and ferric (Fe³⁺) forms
  • Category: Trace mineral
  • Key fact: Iron deficiency is the most prevalent nutritional deficiency worldwide, affecting ~2 billion people.

docs.title: Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA Infants 0–6 months 0.27 mg/day (AI) Infants 7–12 months 11 mg/day Children 1–3 years 7 mg/day Children 4–8 years 10 mg/day Children 9–13 years 8 mg/day Adolescents 14–18 (male) 11 mg/day Adolescents 14–18 (female) 15 mg/day Adult Men 19–50 8 mg/day Adult Women 19–50 18 mg/day Adults 51+ (both sexes) 8 mg/day Pregnant Women 27 mg/day Breastfeeding Women 9–10 mg/day

Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL): 45 mg/day for adults.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• Oxygen Transport (Haemoglobin): Fe²⁺ in haem of haemoglobin binds O₂ reversibly — each haemoglobin carries 4 Fe atoms and 4 O₂ molecules. ~70% of body iron is in RBCs.
  • Oxygen Storage (Myoglobin): Iron in myoglobin stores and releases O₂ in muscle cells during exercise.
  • Electron Transport Chain: Iron-sulfur proteins (Complexes I, II, III) and cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV) require iron for electron transfer — fundamental to ATP synthesis.
  • DNA Synthesis: Ribonucleotide reductase (converts ribonucleotides to deoxyribonucleotides) is an iron-dependent enzyme.
  • Catalase and Peroxidases: Haem-iron enzymes that decompose hydrogen peroxide — antioxidant defence.
  • Neurotransmitter Synthesis: Tyrosine hydroxylase (dopamine, norepinephrine) and tryptophan hydroxylase (serotonin) are iron-dependent.
  • Thyroid Hormone Synthesis: Thyroid peroxidase (iodination of thyroglobulin) is a haem enzyme.
  • Immune Function: Required for neutrophil bactericidal activity (myeloperoxidase) and T-cell proliferation.

docs.title: Cofactors Needed
docs.text: Cofactor Role Vitamin C Reduces Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺ in gut lumen → enhances non-haem iron absorption (2–4× increase) Gastric acid / pepsin Releases iron from food matrix; reduces Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺ Copper (ceruloplasmin) Ceruloplasmin oxidises Fe²⁺ to Fe³⁺ for transferrin binding; copper deficiency → functional iron deficiency Vitamin A Mobilises iron from ferritin stores; deficiency impairs iron utilisation Ferritin / transferrin Storage and transport proteins; iron loading requires these apoprotein backbones

docs.title: Pharmacokinetics
docs.text: Parameter Details Forms absorbed Haem iron (Fe²⁺, from meat/fish) — absorbed ~25%; non-haem iron (mainly Fe³⁺, plant foods) — absorbed 2–20% Absorption site Duodenum and proximal jejunum; DMT1 (divalent metal transporter) for non-haem; separate receptor-mediated for haem iron Enhancers Vitamin C, meat factor, acidic pH Inhibitors Phytate, polyphenols/tannins (tea, coffee), calcium, oxalate, egg yolk phosphoproteins Distribution ~70% haemoglobin; ~10% myoglobin + enzymes; ~20% stored as ferritin/haemosiderin Regulation Hepcidin (liver-derived hormone) is the master regulator — blocks ferroportin export from enterocytes and macrophages Excretion Minimal — 1–2 mg/day lost via gut cell sloughing, sweat, menstruation; no active excretion mechanism

docs.title: Effects of Deficiency
docs.text:
Iron deficiency progresses through three stages: 1. Iron depletion: Ferritin falls, no anaemia 2. Iron-deficient erythropoiesis: Low transferrin saturation, elevated TIBC, microcytosis emerging 3. Iron deficiency anaemia (IDA): Microcytic, hypochromic anaemia — Hb <12 g/dL (women) or <13 g/dL (men)

Symptoms: - Fatigue, pallor, exertional dyspnoea, palpitations - Glossitis, angular cheilitis, koilonychia (spoon nails) - Pica (craving non-food items — ice, clay, dirt) - Restless leg syndrome - Impaired cognitive development (especially children <2 years) - Impaired thyroid hormone synthesis → secondary hypothyroidism

Diagnosis: Serum ferritin (best early marker), transferrin saturation, TIBC, reticulocyte haemoglobin content, peripheral smear.

docs.title: Treatment Protocols
docs.text:
Condition Protocol Mild-moderate IDA Ferrous sulfate 200 mg (65 mg elemental Fe) oral 3×/day; alternate-day dosing may reduce GI side effects Alternate oral agents Ferrous gluconate, ferrous fumarate, ferric maltol (better GI tolerance) Poor oral tolerance / severe IDA IV iron — ferric carboxymaltose, iron sucrose, low-molecular-weight iron dextran Functional iron deficiency (CKD, inflammation) IV iron + erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (ESAs) Iron deficiency in pregnancy 27 mg/day dietary + 30–120 mg/day supplemental as indicated

Take oral iron with vitamin C, on an empty stomach if tolerated. Separate from calcium, tea, and coffee by ≥2 hours.

docs.title: Drug Interactions
docs.text: Drug / Class Effect Antacids / PPIs Reduce gastric acid → impair non-haem iron reduction and absorption Tetracycline / fluoroquinolone antibiotics Iron chelates drug → reduced antibiotic absorption; separate by ≥2 hours Levothyroxine Iron reduces absorption — separate by ≥4 hours Bisphosphonates Iron reduces absorption — separate by ≥2 hours Calcium supplements Compete at DMT1 transporter → reduce iron absorption Deferoxamine / deferasirox Iron chelators — used in iron overload Methyldopa Iron reduces absorption Cholestyramine Binds iron in gut; impairs absorption

docs.title: Food Sources
docs.text: Food Serving Iron (mg) Type Beef liver (cooked) 85g ~5.2 mg Haem (~40%) Oysters (cooked) 85g ~8 mg Haem White beans (cooked) 90g ~3.9 mg Non-haem Fortified breakfast cereal 1 cup 2–18 mg Non-haem Dark chocolate (70–85%) 28g ~3.4 mg Non-haem Lentils (cooked) 90g ~3.3 mg Non-haem Beef (ground, 85% lean, cooked) 85g ~2.2 mg Haem (~40%) Tofu (firm) 85g ~2.0 mg Non-haem Kidney beans (cooked) 90g ~2.0 mg Non-haem Spinach (cooked) 90g ~3.2 mg Non-haem (low bioavailability)

docs.title: Storage & Stability
docs.text:
• Iron mineral content in food is not degraded by cooking.
  • Cast-iron cookware can increase iron content of acidic foods significantly.
  • Vitamin C in the same meal significantly improves non-haem iron absorption.

docs.title: Toxicity (Iron Overload)
docs.text:
• Acute toxicity (children): Adult iron supplement ingestion is a leading cause of poisoning in children; >20 mg/kg elemental iron can cause GI haemorrhage, metabolic acidosis, liver failure.
  • Hereditary haemochromatosis: Autosomal recessive (HFE gene mainly) — unregulated iron absorption leads to systemic iron deposition (liver cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy, bronze diabetes, arthropathy, hypogonadism). Treatment: phlebotomy.
  • Transfusional iron overload: Frequent transfusions in haemoglobin disorders → chelation with deferoxamine or deferasirox.
  • Serum markers: Elevated ferritin (>300 µg/L men, >200 µg/L women) + transferrin saturation >45% suggests overload; liver biopsy or MRI liver iron quantification for confirmation.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Magnesium is the fourth most abundant mineral in the body and the second most abundant intracellular cation after potassium. It is a cofactor for over 300 enzymatic reactions, including all reactions involving ATP (which must be complexed as Mg-ATP to be biologically active). Approximately 60% of body magnesium is in bone, 39% in soft tissues, and less than 1% in serum.

  • Atomic number: 12; divalent cation (Mg²⁺)
  • Category: Macromineral
  • Body content: ~25 g in average adult
  • Key fact: Serum magnesium accounts for <1% of total body magnesium — serum levels are a poor marker of total body status.

docs.title: Requirements (RDA)
docs.text:
Age / Group RDA Infants 0–6 months 30 mg/day (AI) Infants 7–12 months 75 mg/day (AI) Children 1–3 years 80 mg/day Children 4–8 years 130 mg/day Children 9–13 years 240 mg/day Adolescents 14–18 (male) 410 mg/day Adolescents 14–18 (female) 360 mg/day Adult Men 19–30 400 mg/day Adult Men 31+ 420 mg/day Adult Women 19–30 310 mg/day Adult Women 31+ 320 mg/day Pregnant Women 19–30 350 mg/day Pregnant Women 31+ 360 mg/day Breastfeeding Women 310–320 mg/day

Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL): 350 mg/day from supplements only (food magnesium has no established UL). The UL applies to non-food sources only due to osmotic laxative effect.

docs.title: Functions
docs.text:
• ATP Activation: Mg²⁺ chelates ATP to form the biologically active Mg-ATP complex required by all ATPases, kinases, and energy-transducing enzymes.
  • DNA Synthesis and Repair: Cofactor for DNA polymerases, ligases, and repair enzymes; essential for RNA transcription.
  • Protein Synthesis: Required by ribosomes for ternary complex formation during translation.
  • Glycolysis: Cofactor for phosphoglycerate kinase, phosphoglycerate mutase, pyruvate kinase, and enolase.
  • Bone Mineralisation: Incorporated into bone hydroxyapatite; stimulates osteoblast activity and regulates bone crystal size.
  • Calcium Channel Blockade: Acts as a physiological antagonist of voltage-gated calcium channels — the basis for its anticonvulsant and antiarrhythmic effects.
  • Neuromuscular Transmission: Regulates pre-synaptic calcium entry and inhibits acetylcholine release; magnesium deficiency causes neuromuscular hyperexcitability.
  • Cardiovascular: Vasodilation; inhibits platelet aggregation; antiarrhythmic (prolonged refractory period).
  • Insulin Signalling: Required for insulin receptor tyrosine kinase activity; deficiency associated with insulin resistance.
  • PTH and Vitamin D Metabolism: Required for PTH secretion and for hydroxylation steps in vitamin D activation.

docs.title: Cofactors Needed
docs.text: Cofactor Role Vitamin B6 Needed for magnesium transport into cells (PLP-dependent processes) Vitamin D Reciprocal: magnesium is required for vitamin D activation, and vitamin D may improve Mg absorption Potassium Hypomagnesaemia causes potassium wasting; both deficiencies often co-occur ATP Required target for Mg²⁺ complexation — linked in all enzymatic activity

docs.title: Pharmacokinetics
docs.text: Parameter Details Absorption 30–40% of dietary intake absorbed; primarily paracellular in ileum and colon; TRPM6/TRPM7 channels for active transport Absorption increases Low dietary intake, vitamin D sufficiency, protein intake, fermentable fibre Absorption decreases High phytate, oxalate, high calcium intake, alcohol, chronic PPI use Distribution ~60% bone; ~39% muscles/soft tissue; <1% serum (0.75–0.95 mmol/L normal) Excretion Kidneys are principal regulators; ~120 mg/day filtered; reabsorbed primarily in thick ascending loop of Henle Renal conservation Deficiency triggers up to 95% tubular reabsorption (highly efficient) Half-life (serum) Not applicable — serum levels reflect renal handling, not true stores

docs.title: Effects of Deficiency (Hypomagnesaemia)
docs.text:
Serum Mg <0.75 mmol/L. Often concurrent with hypokalaemia and hypocalcaemia.

Causes: - Excessive alcohol consumption (major cause) - Poorly controlled type 2 diabetes (urinary Mg wasting) - Chronic diarrhoea, malabsorption syndromes - Loop/thiazide diuretics - Prolonged PPI use - Post-surgery (refeeding, bowel resection) - Medications: cisplatin, amphotericin B, aminoglycosides

Symptoms: - Early: Anorexia, nausea, fatigue, weakness - Neuromuscular: Tremor, muscle cramps, tetany (Trousseau's/Chvostek's sign) - Cardiac: Prolonged PR/QT intervals, arrhythmias (PVCs, VT, VF) — especially dangerous - Neurological: Confusion, depression, personality changes; seizures in severe deficiency - Bone: Hypomagnesaemia → hypocalcaemia (impairs PTH secretion and action) - Electrolyte: Refractory hypokalaemia and hypocalcaemia that cannot be corrected until Mg is replete

docs.title: Treatment Protocols
docs.text: Condition Protocol Mild deficiency (asymptomatic) Oral magnesium glycinate/citrate/malate 200–400 mg/day (better tolerated than oxide) Moderate deficiency Oral 400–800 mg/day elemental Mg; correct underlying cause Severe / symptomatic IV magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) 1–4 g over 15–60 minutes; repeat as needed Eclampsia/pre-eclampsia IV MgSO₄ 4–6 g loading dose then 1–2 g/hour maintenance (gold standard) Torsades de pointes IV MgSO₄ 2 g over 1–2 minutes (regardless of serum Mg level) Severe asthma (acute) IV MgSO₄ 2 g over 20 minutes (bronchodilator effect) Migraine prophylaxis Oral 400–600 mg/day — evidence-supported

docs.title: Drug Interactions
docs.text: Drug / Class Effect Loop diuretics (furosemide) Increase urinary Mg excretion → hypomagnesaemia Thiazide diuretics Increase urinary Mg wasting Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) Long-term use impairs intestinal Mg absorption → clinically significant hypomagnesaemia Cisplatin Nephrotoxic magnesium wasting (tubular damage) Amphotericin B Renal Mg wasting Aminoglycosides Tubular damage → Mg loss Digoxin Hypomagnesaemia increases digoxin toxicity risk Bisphosphonates Mg may reduce absorption; separate by ≥2 hours Calcium channel blockers Magnesium potentiates hypotensive effects Magnesium antacids/laxatives + antibiotics (quinolones, tetracyclines) Chelation reduces antibiotic absorption — separate by ≥2 hours

docs.title: Food Sources
